PARA.TAB: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—Please proceed.

—I thank the House. In this morning's Sydney Morning Herald there is a story written by the journalist Michael Millet, for whom I have some personal as well as professional regard. Regrettably, this story is inaccurate in at least two references. He said in the course of the article, which discusses the government's stand in relation to the amendments moved to the land fund bill, that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Mr Tickner, confirmed the Government's position without viewing the detail to the Opposition's 37 draft changes.
It goes on to say that I `declared the government position before seeing their detail'. I simply wish to place on record a categorical denial of those two statements.

PARA.TAB: The following bill was returned from the Senate without amendment or requests:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1994

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Clause 3.
Consideration resumed from 31 August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rose last night to speak on the first amendment which has been proposed by the opposition, but unfortunately—or fortunately, from some points of view—I had only 35 seconds in which to speak. When listening to opposition members during this debate, I wondered whether they had done any research and looked at the nature of title which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have argued for over many years in Australia and which has been the subject of a number of very formal inquiries.

PARA.TAB: I took the liberty last evening of going to the library, which is not too far away; even opposition members can access it. If they had gone there, they would have seen the Woodward royal commission report and, for the benefit of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), a report of Paul Seaman QC, in the Aboriginal land inquiry which was undertaken in his state of Western Australia in 1984. The first term of reference of that inquiry was this:

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically the Inquiry shall consider the most appropriate form of title over land reserved for the use and benefit of Aborigines or leased for Aboriginal Communities.
In the context of the recommendations of the report, it is very clear what they have said. I quote from the body of the report:

PARA.TAB: The persistent claim by Aboriginal people at the hearings throughout the State was for a "strong title" which cannot be sold.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on:

PARA.TAB: In both strongly traditional and less traditional areas land is seen as a base upon which to re-build Aboriginal society and culture which must therefore be passed onto future generations of Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: Aboriginal witnesses at the hearings constantly expressed concern for the future of Aboriginal people and said that granted land should not be able to be sold. Aboriginal people are keenly aware that, in their present situation, they do not normally wish to hold the title which they might be tempted to sell because sale would defeat the whole purpose of the benefits which they look for in land rights. That is the guts of what this amendment is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is paternalism.
—`Paternalism', he says. This is an Aboriginal inquiry set up by the Western Australian government, by Paul Seaman QC. I turn to the Woodward Aboriginal Land Rights Commission. Justice Woodward said:

PARA.TAB: I have no doubt about the nature of the title which should be granted.

SPEECH.PARA: He continued:

PARA.TAB: The views which I expressed in my first report that title must be communal and inalienable . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members should understand that it is about communal rights—collective rights—and that is the way in which Aboriginal people have consistently expressed their view to this government. That is the view Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory have expressed to me whilst I have worked with them. I have never once heard the view being espoused by the honourable member for O'Connor or the shadow spokesperson, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus). I do not know whether these people do not give me their views, but I suggest that the views I have been given have been given very forthrightly, as they were given forthrightly to the shadow spokesperson and her erstwhile temporary leader when he was at Utopia and other areas of Central Australia and made a goose of himself.

PARA.TAB: It is very clear that the nature of this amendment goes to undermine the very essence of the form of land holding which Aboriginal people have been aspiring to, and have continually argued for, in this country. The fact is that not one Aboriginal submission to the government has espoused the views which have been put by the opposition. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As many would be aware, my electorate contains the Maralinga and Pitjantjatjara lands. They account for something like 20 per cent of South Australia and 30 per cent of my electorate. There is a very strong view emerging from some within those Aboriginal communities that land rights, as they have evolved over the last decade or 20 years, have been denying people access to their own land. All we are asking for in this amendment is that there be greater flexibility given so that the land fund may be able to grant money to individuals or family groups. The government is strongly objecting to this.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) said that he had never heard of it; he had never heard that individuals or families may want to have individual title or family title. I inform the member for the Northern Territory that Mr Donald Fraser, former chairman of the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Land Council, assures me that that is exactly what he wants. Donald has fought for this right for many years and has been denied it by successive Labor governments.

The great tragedy is that, as we play politics in this place with Aboriginal people, we deny them the opportunity to make progress. I have visited those areas many times. Perhaps when people see the frustration Aboriginals feel with the system which has denied them access to their own lands in the name of land rights, they might step down from their ivory tower; they might step down from the arrogance of urban paternalism, from the arrogance of a rather intellectual argument.

All we are asking is that the corporation be given the right or the machinery to be able to grant funds to individuals or family groups. It is still up to the corporation to be able to grant this money. I specifically asked Mr Fraser last night for his permission to talk about this matter this morning. He said to me, `We have been denied access to our land.' He further said, `We had greater access before the land rights legislation went through.' It is time that we stopped playing politics, that we looked for genuine bipartisanship, that we offered the responsible hand—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to vote against it.
—You are the people voting against it. The member for Leichhardt knows damn well that he is the one voting against it.
—You are voting against the bill.
—You are voting against it. I will put it through the chair—
—You are voting against the bill.
—We are offering amendments for you people to agree with.
—You are voting against the bill.

—I will not be provoked by the member for Leichhardt; I am obviously touching a raw nerve. I am talking about the interests of Aboriginal people, about Aboriginal people having access to their own land so that family groups might have access to their own land. This parliament has denied them that and it has denied them that for too long. That is the practical effect of the academic approach of the Australian parliament. In conclusion, I plead with the government to consider our amendments and not to be distracted—
—Cross the floor.
—Cross the floor to us, my friend. I ask the government not to be distracted by the member for Leichhardt. (Time expired)

—Government members have considered the amendments put forward by the opposition. They have considered them and they have got no merit at all. In contrast, the government has detailed time, effort and consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The opposition drafted their amendments overnight.

—You had a debate in your party room and the opposition leader said, `I have changed my mind.' Senator Panizza said, `That is not what you told me when you asked me to vote for you as coalition leader.' So you said, `Oh, well, we will get some amendments.'

—Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Yesterday we were reminded in detail by a deputy speaker in the chair that we were looking at the detail of the bill and that we must address directly the issues relating to these matters. I can assure you that comment in the Liberal party room is not a rebuttal of the proposal put quite properly by the opposition, and I think the member might demonstrate that he knows what he is talking about.

—The honourable member for Leichhardt will go to the actual amendment being proposed to clause 3 of the bill. I understand that extraneous matters have been thrown across the chamber but, to the extent that the honourable member for O'Connor reminds the House of the process of consideration in detail, I invite the honourable member for Leichhardt to address the amendment before the chair.
—I will, Mr Acting Speaker. I am referring to the context in which these amendments have been drafted. I ask the honourable member for O'Connor: where do they come from?
—They come from a lot of people who have a genuine interest in Aborigines.
—Do they come from consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people? They came from your party room brawl.
—They came from our party room, not from outside interests.
—That is exactly where these amendments came from. They came from your brawl and you are trying to shore up a dead duck opposition leader.
—There is nothing wrong with the amendments. Tell us what is wrong with them.

—I will tell you what is wrong with them. You just do not understand the history of the dispossession of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in this country. In my electorate, people have been dispossessed; Aboriginal people have been taken out of their home country and put in penal settlements and reserves.
—How long have you lived in Leichhardt?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will stop interjecting.
—He should address his remarks through the chair.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell will remain silent.

—Thank you for your protection, Mr Acting Speaker. How can we possibly give economic independence to Aboriginal people without recognising that land has to be held collectively so that economic independence can be achieved? That is the very nature of the government's bill before the House; that is the very nature of the consultations that the government held with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders want the land held communally so that it benefits the widest range of their people.
—Why are they different from other individuals?

—The coalition spokesman does not understand her portfolio. ATSIC provides subsidised loans to individual people and to Aboriginal corporations for business ventures. We do that already. This bill is about something else that you do not understand because you have not discussed it with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. You do not understand the issue. There is a very clear distinction. We do not want to stop Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people from owning land individually, but this bill is about dispossession and compensation for dispossession. Opposition members do not know that because they have not spoken to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. This bill was introduced into the parliament two months ago. Those opposite have had two months to come up with this nonsense. What did they do in that time?
—We talked about it.
—You talked about it! All you have said in two months is that you would oppose the legislation. That is all we have heard. (Time expired)

—I want to speak about amendment No. 1, which is the subject of debate at the moment. I am rather disappointed with the degree of rancour that has occurred in this debate both last night and this morning. Obviously there is some excitement on both sides of the House. I think we need to calm down a bit and consider the objectives of the legislation and the amendments: that is, to do things better for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I say to my friends on the other side, `Don't be consumed with self-righteousness, which is the way that you are coming across. You are not the repository of all wisdom on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs.' A great many people on this side of the House have a high degree of sensitivity about the aspirations, problems and needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

PARA.TAB: There are 37 amendments being proposed by the opposition, and I am speaking to amendment No. 1. To those members of the government who are here and to others who may be listening, I say, `You may not like some of them, but if you are fair you will admit that not all of them are bad.' I believe that this amendment is fair. Last night the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) said that he was concerned with the substance of the legislation. I agree that we all need to be concerned with the substance of the legislation. This is why I support this amendment. Last night the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), who has just entered the chamber, made reference to sound administrative practice. I support him in the need for sound administrative practice in the administration of this bill when it becomes an act—hopefully, with some amendments accepted by the government.

This amendment provides for the corporation to grant interests in land to Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders, to grant money to Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders, and to guarantee loans to Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders. I cannot, for the life of me, see what is wrong with this amendment. After all, we were just told by the last speaker, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd), that ATSIC makes loans to individuals for business ventures.

Why, if it is all right for Commonwealth money to be made available as loans for business ventures or grants, is it not equally valid for individual Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders to receive benefits under this particular bill when land is so important to them? I am afraid I cannot understand the logic of those on the other side who just reject it out of hand.

I am sure that Australian Commonwealth taxation money is made available in grants to individuals from most portfolios in this parliament, whether it is for sporting activities, for the arts, or for a variety of other purposes. The principle of making grants, guaranteeing loans, or whatever, for individual Australians is in place, it is a reality. I suggest, with all respect to my friends on the other side, that they have blinkers on in relation to this. Do not, for heaven's sake, reject everything out of hand just to get back at the opposition. There are some good things in the amendments.

Amendment No. 1 is a sound amendment. It extends the benefits of the legislation to Aboriginal individuals. I see nothing wrong with that. I see nothing wrong with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders being treated equally with other people right around Australia who do get grants, who do get guaranteed loans, from every portfolio in this parliament. I ask the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) to reconsider this amendment. I think it is a very sound one which will benefit Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the genuineness of the contribution today of the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). It is good to see that there are some rational people on his side after all. I understand that the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), who was in here yesterday, is not going to speak on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander matters in this place again, which is rather unfortunate. I think the member for Cowper is trying to get across some genuine points of view. He always has a genuine point of view, and has been known to get excited from time to time as well. It is interesting to see him today showing such restraint on such an important matter.

PARA.TAB: It is an important matter. I have to admit that I feel extremely sorry for some of those members opposite who have been forced into the position of supporting amendments that they very well know do not get to the heart of what the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's the heart? It's the health issues; it's the education; it's the jobs.

—That is the sort of useless interjection I know I should not respond to, but the member for Mitchell is one of those people who obviously find it necessary to interject all the time to make their presence known in this place. Let us put the member for Mitchell aside. Perhaps if he ceased interjecting—
—Tell us what your objections are.

—And, of course, the member for O'Connor is always interjecting as well. The point you are trying to get at here is corporations versus individual points. This amendment was put forward as just another futile diversion from the opposition. There is no genuineness about it from the people who put this amendment forward, particularly the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus).

PARA.TAB: The intention of the land fund is clearly to acquire land, and the acquisition of funds is to provide community benefits. That is one of the important aspects of this bill which cannot be implemented if it is provided for individuals. The opposition is always going on about so-called individual rights, but we are talking about accountability. If you give the funds to individuals, you will not be able to maintain the accountability that is required in this legislation. Accountability is extremely important.

I come back to the points raised here yesterday. I believe the member for Chisholm—and I have to admit that I feel extremely sorry for him because he has been forced into a position by the rednecks in the opposition—is another member of the opposition who really has a genuine interest in Aboriginal people. He has tried extremely hard, and you could see his frustration here yesterday. He was not angry with this side of the House; he was angry with his own side.

If you were really fair dinkum about this, you would allow the honourable member for Chisholm and others to have a clear vote, and they would come across and vote with us. Clearly, you are causing a lot of pain to honourable members, such as the honourable member for Chisholm, who have a genuine interest. That is your nature. You really do not have a genuine interest in bringing true reconciliation to the Aboriginal people.

All these things come back to the Aboriginal deaths in custody royal commission and dispossession. We are not going to achieve genuine reconciliation unless we get to the stage of actually addressing the question of land. You are not doing that by your amendments. Your amendments, particularly this one—and I have looked through the 37 amendments and others are similar to this—are obviously put forward, as I said before, as a futile diversion, and they are not going to achieve our aims.

TALK.START.PARA: —I resent that.

—The honourable member for Hindmarsh interjects again. We watched her here the other day and she really has no idea about anything in her shadow portfolio. That was seen clearly by the problems that she caused when she gave some advice to her leader. Between them what a disaster!
—Politics again. You can't address the issue.

—The honourable member for O'Connor keeps interjecting because that is about the only thing he can do here. We know what his contribution was all about in the debate yesterday on the League of Rights.
—Order! The honourable member will stick to the amendment.

—The amendments that you are proposing here, particularly amendment No. 1 and others that are consequential to this, do not address the issue. The ownership by corporations provides accountability, and that is important to all of us in this place. We all know that. We all argue for accountability all the time. You cannot possibly do what you are talking about here. We are about providing assistance to Aboriginal people.
—So you are going to support the rest of our amendments on accountability? Good!
—The honourable member for Hindmarsh continues to go on. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Traditionally, the members of the government have today failed to give one substantial reason why this amendment, which, I repeat, slightly expands the opportunities of the ILC to allow individuals or family groups to directly own land—and I want to come back to that because I am determined to address the issue—should not succeed. The honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) said that we cannot possibly have that because we have to have accountability.
—Yes.
—He says, `Yes.' Today in the Telegraph Mirror there is an example of how your structures and bureaucracies are being accountable. I will give the honourable member a copy. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Aborigines' bungling `costs $12m'

PARA.TAB: The NSW Aboriginal Land Council has lost more than $12 million of taxpayers' money—

SPEECH.PARA: I would prefer to say Aboriginal people's money—
which the NSW Auditor-General blames on poor management skills.
The article went on to say—and this is the important point:

PARA.TAB: This effectively had retarded the Council's ability to establish economic self-sufficiency for the Aboriginal community, it said.
The exact losses could not be calculated accurately `due to the unreliability of accounting records'.

SPEECH.PARA: For an ex-bank manager, what do you think of that? You put an argument for accountability. We say that there is more opportunity for accountability when individuals or small family groups are directly involved; it is easier to decide who might be at fault. They see themselves as having something to protect; it is theirs, and they do not rort the system.

PARA.TAB: That blows your accountability by the land council argument completely out the window. The evidence is legion that the Aboriginal bureaucracy is soaking up all the money and, after $10 billion or $11 billion worth of expenditure directed towards health, education and other things, people are still in abject poverty. The system is wrong. We stand here in the Aboriginal interest and, in my case, I stand on behalf of the Aboriginal people I represent.

Let me remind you what you said about this fund in the budget and what you said at the time of Mabo. You said that this fund was aimed at assisting those people whose Aboriginal title had been extinguished according to the High Court ruling. I happen to represent those types of people. There is a large Aboriginal community in O'Connor and practically no unalienated land. I thought this piece of legislation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Un-what land?
—Unalienated land. Don't you know what that means? I am not surprised, with drongos like you. Just be quiet and it will save me time.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The honourable member will withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw. I am the owner of my own opinion, nevertheless.
—Order! The honourable member should withdraw without qualification.

—I withdraw. The facts of life are that the Aboriginal people in my electorate have come along to me personally with correspondence going back years saying to me: `Why can't we have some land and, when we get it, why can't we have some control of it?' Let me give you the sort of information I have got talking to grassroots Aboriginals—not your Aboriginal bureaucrats. Do you know one of their worries? They are told they have land in this great collective that the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) wanted to mention. They can actually lose their rights in a political coup. If there is a change at the top and their family is on the outer; they have nothing. That is your plan and that is all you understand.

PARA.TAB: I just hope the next speaker gets up and puts some substantive reasons as to why the Labor Party believes that individuals or family groups of Aboriginals cannot be trusted with personal land ownership. That is all this amendment does. It is not overriding the provisions of the act; it is an addition to the act. The people in my electorate, whom I do consult and whose circumstances I know, have farms with no farm machinery on them. But it is not really their land—they are told to occupy it, as Stalin would have told them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) asked whether we could present some substantive reasons why we are not prepared to accept this amendment. I believe that speakers, particularly the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) have already done that.
—No.

—Alan, you wouldn't know anything about it. Let me give three reasons in particular why we cannot and will not accept this amendment. The first reason is that there is a need to provide for the continuity of Aboriginal ownership. If you are going to provide land under some type of freehold title for Aboriginal individuals, Torres Strait Islander individuals, families or partnerships, it will also entitle them to dispose of that land. I do not believe the Australian people would take too kindly to the proposition that in 10 years time, as a result of this arrangement having been put into place, there will be in real terms, in today's dollars, $45 million being made available every year for the purchase of land for Aboriginal communities and for Aboriginal purposes which, at least in part, might go to individuals and to families and to partnerships which they can then dispose of because it would be their freehold land. That is the No. 1 reason.

PARA.TAB: The second reason—and this has been emphasised—is that one of the purposes of this legislation is to provide land for Aboriginal community purposes. It is a recognition, not of the guilt of European Australians for the past, but a recognition by European Australians—the whole Australian community, including the Aboriginal community at present—of the reality of the past and the dispossession. As we emphasised before, the provisions of Mabo will not make any difference for about 70 per cent of the Australian Aboriginal population because they are the most dispossessed, they are the most displaced, they are the people who have been dissociated from their land to the greatest extent.

The third reason is one of accountability. This was emphasised by the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott). Points were made by the member for O'Connor in referring to the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council and to the reference in the newspaper today. I mention in passing that that is a New South Wales creature. It has nothing to do with the Commonwealth.

The important thing about the point you made was that developments of that kind do give the rednecks in Australia the opportunity to come down—I did not say you were a redneck, but if you feel guilty—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I have pointed out a number of times—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Does the member for O'Connor have a point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do. It has been ruled by previous occupants of the chair that in the consideration in detail stage we have to deal with the actual propositions. I cannot see any reference to rednecks. That is making the issue blatantly political.
—The member for O'Connor does not have a point of order. In my view, the member for Charlton was not being offensive when using that term.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. That is a perfectly wise judgment on your part, as we always expect and as we always get. On the question of community benefit, I refer to an interview on the ABC radio program PM on 30 August 1994 when the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), said—and I quote from the transcript of that program:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . when land is bought, and we support the purchase of land, that it must show benefit to the community, there must be a reason for that land being bought that will somehow benefit the Aboriginal community . . .
She repeated the word `community'. Later in the same interview, she went on to say:

You don't want to create new problems, so if a community is going to be set up, you have to look, what is going to be the end effect on that community and I think this is a very reasonable thing to expect.
And so do we. I notice that she is not snapping and snarling across the chamber as she generally does in order to camouflage her inadequacy in handling this shadow portfolio responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House would be aware that, in the recent past, I have put a lot of time and effort into this area of interest and I have travelled and consulted extensively around the country. I have to say, with some considerable sadness this morning, that I believe the events from both sides in this chamber during this debate have not advanced the welfare, the cause or the benefit of the indigenous people of this country. The attitudes displayed on both sides—I found the attitude of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) particularly disappointing—have not helped the reconciliation process.

PARA.TAB: The coalition does not disagree with what the government has said in the detailed amendment that is before us at the moment but has sought to give it more flexibility and to extend it a bit. I find it particularly upsetting and disturbing—as did those who were in the chamber yesterday when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) spoke—that the minister, quite clearly, without seeing the detail of those amendments, rejected them out of hand.

We could say that is the government's right. I think that is a point of view. If the government is going to continually talk about wishing to improve the situation of this country's indigenous people, then it is far better done with some cooperation. I have not heard anything from the government side in the general debate or in the consideration in detail stage that makes sense to me as to why the government cannot move at least a little on some of these amendments. It seems to me that the government is saying that reconciliation and cross-party support is fine provided it is on the government's terms but if other people want to make some constructive suggestions, they are just being obstructive.

There is no doubt at all that the coalition has taken a substantially different position on this issue from that which it has been advocating for a long time. We have moved our position quite considerably. I would have thought that, if all of us in this place were genuine about trying to improve the lot of indigenous people in this country, we would have dealt with some of these issues rather than indulging in the somewhat unedifying spectacle that we have seen during the last few hours of debate on this bill. In the short time that I have been a member of this chamber, which is about 4 1/2 years, I do not think that I have seen a more personally acrimonious debate than this. If we are to advance the cause of indigenous people in this country, it seems to me that it behoves us all to try to show a little more generosity of spirit. I urge the government, particularly the minister at the table, to draw back a little bit.

TALK.START.PARA: —You weren't listening to me.
—Sorry?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! It would be helpful if both the minister and the honourable member for Aston conducted this debate through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise, Mr Deputy Speaker. I did not catch the minister's interjection. My point is that I thought the government could have picked up parts of our amendments without too much difficulty. The government has taken the view, as it has with other issues under this portfolio in the recent past, that it is all or nothing. In the long-term, that will not benefit the people whom we are all concerned about in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: This amendment is relatively innocuous in what it attempts to do. It takes up what the government is proposing, but it gives a bit more flexibility and it allows a few more categories. What is the harm in that? You can come up with all sorts of scenarios as to how it might be abused, how it might be misused or how it is against the cultural appropriateness. However, many Aboriginal people around the country to whom I have spoken would see this as a very reasonable amendment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sympathy with the position of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent). I certainly respect the work he has put into resolving issues which face the indigenous people of this country. However, he ignores the genesis and the purpose of the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill as drafted by the government. The genesis of the legislation is the historic Mabo decision of the High Court where the High Court said that the indigenous people of this country were unlawfully dispossessed of their land by white settlers. In speaking of the indigenous people of this country, the High Court was referring to a class of people—not individual people.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the High Court decision, the government has very properly recognised, through the Mabo native title legislation, that those indigenous people who have access to land which has not been alienated by title or leasehold have native title rights over that unalienated land. The High Court also pointed out that there are many in that class of people whose land has been alienated by either leasehold or title.

This bill should be seen as complementary to the Native Title Act; it is not in isolation of the Native Title Act. We should view it as having the same function as the Native Title Act, which is to give land back to a class of people, the indigenous inhabitants of this country, who have been dispossessed of rights as a collective group. That is exactly what it does. How can one separate land rights by individual grants to individual Aboriginals? If we did that, it would defeat the purpose of the Native Title Act, which is the genesis of this bill, and it would ignore the collective nature of land ownership in the culture of the indigenous people of this country.

Those who have bothered to read the evidence given to the High Court or the judgment of the High Court would know that it is unarguable that the culture of the Aboriginal people of this country is, of its very essence, collective. It is just an unarguable, anthropological proposition to put.

If by this legislation we say that individual tribal people and collective tribal people have the right to fragment collectively viewed owned land, then we defeat the very purpose and the structure of what the High Court has pointed out to us as Australians. We have just destroyed it. That is why the legislation cannot be accepted—not by the government but by this House. I have to say without any rancour or bitterness that the suspicion of all of us on this side of the House is that the opposition comes into this debate too late with too little.

For months the position of the government has been known. The indigenous people, through their representatives, have made it very clear what sort of legislation they want and the government has put forward the legislation that they support. Then at the very last moment, because of internal party politics, because of the moderates having to be seen as getting a bit of a win over the conservatives, a solution is found whereby you come into this House and say, `We've found a solution, we suddenly want to join you in resolving this problem.' But, because you have no real position to put, you try to expand the class of persons that can benefit and you try to throw in other issues such as health to give yourself some credibility. It just does not work like that.

In conclusion—I notice I am running out of time, and I am sorry I have not got more time—if the opposition really viewed this matter seriously, it would not have the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) apparently leading the debate. If it were really serious, he would not have been in the House last night or this morning carrying on, as he normally does in this place, leading the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do not see this as addressing the amendment; I see it as a personal attack on the member for O'Connor.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—That is not a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I were going to personally attack the honourable gentleman, I would. I have not. I am making a very valid point. (Time expired)

—The government has made its precipitate decision on the Mabo legislation and said, `If you want bipartisanship, you will agree with us.' It staked out its ground and then dared people to disagree with what it thought was an impeccable position. The opposition, unlike the government, has taken the total period since that time to consult with the Aboriginal people, to visit their areas, to talk to them and to determine what their wishes are.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has a structure in his mind of land councils and ATSIC. I would like to inform the House and the community that land councils are not traditional owners and that ATSIC is not a traditional owner. Those structures are artificial structures put in place by government. They have nothing to do with the real life and lifestyles of the Aboriginal people—the tribes, the clans or the families. They have nothing to do with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you know?

—I lived in northern Australia for many years, my friend, and I lived there for two weeks just a month ago. That is more than you have done. You have not mixed with the people you claim you want to defend. You have not lived there at all. You have got no claim of expertise. What do you have? You have the record of a government over an 11-year period spending $11 billion, $6 billion of which gets through to the people it wants to help. Here is another program of a similar type.

PARA.TAB: Why does the minister not take action with the Central Land Council and see that the people who actually own the land—those six people—actually get their land? Why does he not take action in Kalgoorlie where the only traditional holder is living on the rubbish dump and the land council says he does not own the land? Why does he not take action with the Northern Land Council which again and again by bureaucratic process overrides the traditional, rightful owners of the land?

Claim after claim has been made, but you have failed to support the rightful owners; you support the bureaucracies and you support your friends. You would rather see wealthy, southern legal firms take their commission and their fees in this sale process that you are proposing than deal with the real issues.

I am amazed at the way in which the government is handling this process. We have agreed that there should be a land fund. That is what the government wants, and we have not quibbled about whether or not there should be one. All we have said is this: `Drop the paternalistic attitudes and give those tribes, clans and groups an opportunity for rightful ownership instead of making it filter down through the land councils and ATSIC.' That is the problem. Why do you not allow a little bit of diversity? It is obvious that the minister has not really sat down and talked to anybody except the bureaucracy. Why do you not just get out there and live with normal families for a while and see what they say and who are the rightful owners?

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister finds it a funny idea to live with Aboriginal families; he is laughing.

—I would imagine that he would. The paternalism of the Labor Party comes through in this legislation. Government members are not prepared to trust people. They are not prepared to give the rightful owners an opportunity. They would rather have a structure in place, waste a lot of money and then destroy the objectives they claim to adhere to. The Labor Party has had 11 years to prove this philosophy and to put these structures in place. You have failed all the way. Point to your successes! Point to the massive change in lifestyle or the massive advantage to the Australian Aboriginals from the huge resources that you have put in!

PARA.TAB: All we are proposing in this simple amendment is that we extend the grant of land to corporations—as the government wishes—to persons, to trustees and to groups. The amendment is a small extension to what you are proposing, yet it seems to turn people on about accountability. Show me the record of accountability. Show me how this will destroy the accountability. Prove that it will. The accountability in some instances is extremely bad. In other areas it is very good.

The Aboriginal people are trying. You are not prepared to trust them. That is the bottom line. You would rather work through the bureaucracies, which in many instances are notorious for their failure, and the rip-off merchants who have been in them—all appointed by governments. You are not prepared to change that. You are not prepared to give people a go. Look around Australia and see those who are deserving and should be considered as rightful owners!

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder you are losing.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The parliamentary secretary! The member for Mitchell is as entitled to be heard as anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —He had to go to the library to look up the content of the act this morning, he said. (Time expired)

—I want to make a few comments on this amendment and to respond to some of the comments that have been made. The points that have been made by the opposition speakers clearly demonstrate their total ignorance of Aboriginal culture and Aboriginal community life. In this amendment they are seeking to set in place a requirement on or capacity for the Indigenous Land Corporation to grant individuals title over land that the corporation has purchased.

PARA.TAB: The whole purpose of this land acquisition fund is to give Aboriginal communities the opportunity to own land. That is a reflection of the reality of Aboriginal culture and the structure of their society. The purpose of this fund is to build a fund that for many years to come will have the capacity to continue to purchase land that can advance the interests of Aboriginal people as a community. If we allow individuals to own land, the whole process of alienation of sections of that land from the community title will occur.

When those opposite say, `What is wrong with a family having it?' or `What is wrong with an individual having it?' they are ignoring the fact that individual family circumstances or individual relationships in a community may change. There is a whole range of reasons why a particular individual may leave that community or may wish to be divided from that community. What you are suggesting by this amendment is that that land be lost to that community, because that individual will be the one with the title to it. Therefore, there is no community benefit; there is just one individual's benefit.

The purpose of this fund is not necessarily to benefit an individual person but to benefit the community as a whole so that the corporate interests of that community are advanced and that land belongs to the whole community. That is a reflection of the way in which Aboriginal society operates, and that is a reflection of what the Aboriginal people in this country have said that they want through this land acquisition fund. They do not want individual ownership, because they understand the divisions that will occur by that process. If you had had any sort of rational or reasonable consultation with Aboriginal communities, as we on this side of the House have, you would understand that.

The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) referred to his past activities when he lived in northern Australia. I lived on an Aboriginal community for two years and I have worked with Aboriginal people. In my four years as a member of the House of Representatives standing committee, of which I am now chair, I have visited probably more than 100 Aboriginal communities around this country. So I have probably had far more extensive consultation with Aboriginal people than certainly the shadow minister and most other members, except the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), who has been a very active worker in this area and who has participated with me in a lot of those visits.

The honourable member for Aston can tell you, as I can, that Aboriginal people have a very strong sense of community. They do not want the parcels of land that may be purchased for them through this corporation being able to be divided off, because that will lead to division in those communities. It is your ignorance of that culture and structure in Aboriginal society that is reflected in this amendment and in most of the amendments that you have put forward today.

It is a pity that you have not been prepared, in the two months that the government gave you, to do some work and to try to find out what Aboriginal people think about this. Instead of using these cheap political lines about Aboriginal bureaucracy and industry, how about trying to get to the bottom of the issue and talking to Aboriginal people? You claim that these people do not represent—

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The honourable member for Moreton keeps referring to `you' and `your'. The reference should be `the opposition', and the speech should be delivered through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —My apologies. It is a great pity that the opposition, particularly the shadow minister, has not been prepared to do the work that it is required to do to find out the reality of Aboriginal life. Instead of coming out with all these cliches and pursuing the line about wanting to benefit individual Aboriginal people, it should find out what Aboriginal culture and society are about. If it does, it will understand that, to them, the land is not something that should be owned by an individual. It belongs to the whole community and is passed down from generation to generation. That is what they want. They do not want individuals owning that land who could then alienate, sell or do something else to it that might divide the community. (Time expired)

—I draw the attention of the Minister and the government to one aspect of the first amendment. As we have pointed out right throughout this debate, this amendment widens the range of potential recipients. Everybody on the government side of the House has argued that it should not be widened and that it should go only to Aboriginal corporations.

PARA.TAB: If I read the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 correctly, page 16 describes those who can be directors. Without any amendment from us, the bill lists at least four indigenous ordinary directors. Another director is to be a commissioner. I suggest that that person would most likely be an Aboriginal. So the certainty is that four out of seven will be indigenous. The chances are that five out of seven will be indigenous. They have to at least have knowledge of Aboriginal community life. It is quite possible that all seven will be indigenous Australians. We are only opening up the possibility of that board choosing not to give land to corporations.

Under our amendment, if that board does not want to, it does not have to. What you are saying is that these directors, at least five of whom always will be indigenous—maybe four, but I think five and maybe more—are not to be trusted with making those decisions. Under any circumstances in Australia, they are not to be trusted with making a decision to give land to a family, to a trust administering for a family or to a private corporation involving families or individuals. That is what you are saying. That is exactly the effect of what you are saying. They do not have to give one acre—not a square metre—because they have the choice, do they not? Who makes these decisions?

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! I remind the member for Barker, as I reminded the honourable member for Moreton, that it would be helpful if he addressed his remarks through the chair and referred to the government rather than individually to the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that these directors have the choice. Under this amendment, which you obviously have not read carefully enough, they do not have to give an acre to any body other than a corporation. If the minister reads the amendment carefully, he will find that the board has absolute choice as to what it does. It was drafted that way specifically. In other words, we are not saying that this board should be restricted, that it is limited or does not have the abilities to make these sorts of choices. If the minister is right, the board will not give any land to anybody other than corporations. I will guarantee that, if you pass these amendments, you will be wrong. Nevertheless, it will be the board's choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: I rise only to explain a very significant point to the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) that he appears to be unaware of. I simply make the point that the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 quite clearly spells out a minimum number of indigenous representatives on the board. The honourable member ought to have regard to clause 191X(2).
—I did.
—You did not refer to that.
—I just read it out.

—On my hearing and on that of my colleagues, you did not refer to it. Otherwise, the comments of the honourable member for Barker are utterly without substance and the government stands by its reasoned arguments for opposing this amendment. I repeat: this would effectively be the overturning of the announced and firm policy position of every government that has been in power in the Commonwealth—Liberal, coalition and Labor governments—going right back to 1971. It is a radical proposal to overturn consistent cross-party bipartisan policy in indigenous affairs. It has not been discussed with any indigenous person before it was brought into this parliament and the government rejects it absolutely.

—I have never heard so much nonsense as what was just said by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Is the minister's hearing defective or is there something wrong with his understanding? The honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) clearly pointed out that this amendment in no way changes the ability of the board to give all of the land to corporations. The board can still give all of the land to corporations. This amendment simply widens that so that, if in any circumstance the board wishes to give land to individuals, an Aboriginal trust or an Aboriginal partnership, the board has the flexibility under this bill to do exactly that.

PARA.TAB: This clause has not narrowed the board's ability or the instructions to the board in any way; it has simply widened them to allow for an occasion when the board says, `In this situation, we wish to provide a loan to an Aboriginal partnership or a trust for this piece of land.' How can the minister object to that? How can he actually object to a clause in the bill which widens the powers of the board to enable it to deal with any situation?

I have been totally and utterly disillusioned by the actions of the minister. Earlier in the week I said that there was not time to go through all these amendments and that they had not been widely seen, and I asked the minister whether we could delay the debate. Had that debate been delayed—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—Yes, it is true. We talked about it and the minister said that it was in train and could not be changed.
—You never asked me to adjourn it.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! If the minister wants to participate in the debate, there will be another opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister informed me that everything was in train and that there was no time to do that. Later, when the amendments were finished, I handed the minister 37 amendments. Mr Deputy Speaker, you may tell me that the minister may be extraordinarily capable, but I find it extraordinary that he can read through 37 amendments in an hour or less and ring up and say, `We will not negotiate on any of these amendments. We will not accept any of those amendments. That is it.' In a previous conversation in which I outlined the amendments to the minister, he actually seemed quite pleasantly surprised with them. But, no. We received a phone call from him saying, `We simply will not discuss any of these amendments.'

PARA.TAB: I will briefly address the comments of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). He said that I should travel to the communities. I have been to the communities. I have been a shadow minister for only two months, but I have spent as much of those two months as possible in Aboriginal communities in both Western Australia and the Northern Territory. I have taken on board what people in those communities have said. I have visited many women in those communities. This amendment has come about as a consequence of talking to the previous two shadow ministers in this portfolio, who have travelled far more widely than I and have heard over and again from Aboriginal people that they would like the opportunity individually to own land. But, as I have said, we have not required that the board actually do this; we have simply given the board the opportunity to do it. Out of hand, this minister—this hypocrite at the table—has said that it will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —No matter what personal abuse the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) might sling at me, the House can be assured that I will not be retaliating. But I take the opportunity to set the record straight in an absolutely categorical and unambiguous way about the process the government used to deal with these amendments, and to put firmly on the public record the time frame and the history of the opposition's preparation of the amendments.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that when I debated the honourable member for Hindmarsh on the 7.30 Report the night before last—which was not shown in Canberra—she said to Paul Lyneham, in response to my persistent requests for the amendments, that she thought the amendments had already been circulated. When I went back to my office, I asked my staff whether we had received the amendments. My staff informed me that we had been told by the office of the honourable member for Hindmarsh that `the amendments would not be ready tomorrow'. I know for a fact—not from any private conversation with her, but independently—that the honourable member for Hindmarsh was later that night in the company of a number of opposition members and staff of the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Yesterday, when there was another Deputy Speaker in the chair, the minister jumped to his feet and asked us reasonably politely to address the amendments. We are dealing with amendment No. 1. I ask that you bring the minister to exactly the same set of conditions that he asked of us yesterday.
—He was talking about where they came from.
—Order! I need no assistance from the members on my right.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: I make the observation that the purpose of the consideration in detail stage is to provide an unlimited number of five-minute occasions for members on each side of the chamber to respond to what is said on the other side. That is what the minister is seeking to do.

—Order! The honourable member for Charlton is assisting with a decision I do not need assistance with. I indicate to the chamber that I heard what the minister was saying. I also heard the shadow minister. It did strike me that, in both instances, we were moving into the area of personal explanation, which could have been a separate part of the debate. In that sense, the member for Barker is right. I had, however, allowed the minister some tolerance because I felt that the shadow minister had injected into the debate something of a question about the way in which the minister had dealt with the amendments. I think the minister has had an opportunity to address that; I now invite him to draw closer to the amendments.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you to allow me to complete my answer with about four sentences. I make it clear that yesterday, right from the minute I walked into this building, I did nothing else but work to get a copy of the opposition amendments. I got the first draft, then the second draft, one of which was marked `confidential'—hot off the press. I did nothing else but examine the detail of each and every one of the amendments that are now before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is about the only thing the minister has been right about. I have known for the last X number of weeks that there would be a minimum of five indigenous members of the board. Proposed new section 191X(2) states:

PARA.TAB: The Indigenous Land Corporation Chairperson and at least 4 other Indigenous Land Corporation Directors must be Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

SPEECH.PARA: The minimum was five, not four. It simply reinforces my point that this board, with a minimum of five indigenous people, is given a choice under this amendment of granting interests in land to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations, or to Aboriginal persons, or to Torres Strait Islanders, or to trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islanders, and some other people.

PARA.TAB: The logic of this is that the board is not to be trusted. Therefore, the government is saying that it is not going to give the board the latitude, if it so wishes, to have a wider range of recipients. I say to the minister that, if he is right, this board, which has a majority of five indigenous people, will allocate all of the land to corporations, so the government will be absolutely safe.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of what was said before, this amendment simply widens the power of the corporation; it does not force it to award to individuals. It simply gives the board the right, if the situation arises, to award to an Aboriginal individual or to a trust. Why is that such a non-acceptable amendment to the minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only repeat what I have painfully put on the public record in the course of this debate, supported so ably by my colleagues.

—I am afraid that that is not a satisfying explanation from the minister. He says that the government is prepared to trust the Indigenous Land Corporation—the central group that the government is establishing—to decide on the allocation of funds or to decide on land ownership for corporations. He is not prepared to go to the extent that the government has sufficient confidence in the corporation for it to make grants to individuals, clans, tribes or groups of people. Many of the minister's colleagues have argued that they do not in fact trust those individuals, groups, tribes or clans to fulfil the purposes of the act.
—That is not true. He did not say he did not trust them.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! If the honourable member for Moreton wishes to participate, he will have the opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is the purpose of the government to allocate land collectively, the government will only be prepared to accept that land is allocated to corporations. Does this mean that every group of half a dozen people of a remaining tribe have to incorporate in order to be eligible to gain their own land, where they have lived? They may not be able to gain Mabo title to their land, but they have lived there for a long period. Is the government going to force them to incorporate? Is that what its intention is?

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the structure and accountability the government is looking for is a very legalistic, European way of doing things. It is not a process that, in the minister's terms, is suitable for the Aboriginal people. The government is saying that it is going to force a European type structure, a legalistic structure, which complies with what the government defines is a suitable structure.

The government is not prepared to accept that the Indigenous Land Corporation has got the capacity to make decisions about anything other than corporations. The government has precluded it from deciding that. What gives the government the confidence that the corporation can make decisions of a competent nature about corporations? The government appears to say, `Yes, we will trust you as the Indigenous Land Corporation to make decisions for groups that are incorporated but for no-one else.'

All we are seeking to do with this legislation is give the corporation the option to make other decisions. We are just providing the option; we are not making it mandatory. For goodness sake, why not have a bit of flexibility? The minister has a set mind about structures and pinnacles and dealing with peak bodies, because those things are easy for ministers to deal with. It is a bureaucratic process. Why does the government not deal with the people and let the Indigenous Land Corporation have some capacity for judgment as to what is the right decision in the circumstances?

To give a small illustration, if a group of related Aboriginal people living in Redfern want to buy some land in the bush, the government is saying to mum and dad and the kids and the few relatives, `You can buy that land because you originally came from the Casino area. But you have to incorporate first. We cannot allocate that land under this legislation through the Indigenous Land Corporation to your families or to an individual or to a group. We want you to have a company structure.' The government is not even prepared to give the Indigenous Land Corporation an option.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong further consideration of this amendment. All of the reasons the government has for maintaining the integrity of this clause of the bill have been more than adequately explained. I will briefly take up two issues that were raised by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). He said that we were subjecting Aboriginal Australians, indigenous Australians, to, in effect, the white man's corporate law. That is the only type of property law which exists in Australia. It is not just a means by which a group of Aboriginals can make a claim or seek to get ownership of that land. The honourable member for Mitchell will understand—as we all do—the protective devices which are built into the incorporation process. That will provide them with protection. The other point I want to make is simply this: there has been an attempt on the part of the opposition in connection with this amendment to suggest that we will have no confidence in the Indigenous Land Corporation and that we will not trust it to make decisions. That is not fair. It is not correct. The point is that the provisions that the opposition wishes to build into this legislation through its amendment will expand the purposes of the legislation and the purposes of that land fund and the way in which that land fund will be making land available for groups of Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is suggesting that, the government having determined the parameters of the legislation on the basis of sound reasons, we will not then allow the Indigenous Land Corporation to move outside those parameters and make decisions which do not go to the purpose of that legislation. The opposition is suggesting that we do not have confidence in the corporation and that we do not trust it. Let me assure those opposite that we do. That is the reason that we are establishing this arrangement—because we do have confidence in the corporation and we do trust it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the coalition's amendment No. 1 to the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill is one of the most progressive options ever offered to Aboriginal people. I am disappointed that the government is choosing to reject it. It seems that the government does not believe that individual Aborigines should be allowed to own land or that any government assistance should be provided to individual Aborigines to own land. The government talks about land rights but, when individuals want to purchase property on their own, no assistance is available. Assistance is available only to remote corporations.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me fairly strange to argue, on the one hand, that Aborigines feel the land is part of their soul and is so important to their daily life, health, wellbeing and every other aspect but then, on the other hand, to say to them that they cannot actually own that land; that it has to be owned by some remote corporation, a part of the Aboriginal industry; that only those people in land councils can have title to the land. I believe that if, on the one hand, we talk about land rights and the importance of land to Aborigines and then, on the other hand, say that we will not help them buy land we are being utterly inconsistent.

As I mentioned yesterday, the government has developed an extraordinary Aboriginal industry. Real power in Aboriginal affairs is concentrated in a few people to the exclusion of others, and nepotism is rife. There is an extraordinary concentration of grants to a small group of people. Yesterday the minister said that he rejected these amendments because he had spoken to a list of people who did not want them. Then he read the list which consisted of a whole group of land councils. These are the very people who are at the heart of the Aboriginal industry; the sorts of people that under this legislation will get all the money. It seems as though they do not want to share their honey pot with the Aborigines who want to own the land.

If there is a real spiritual association with the land, I think we should be facilitating individual Aboriginal groups and families to purchase the land and hold the title for themselves. That would really give Aboriginals the closeness to and responsibility for their land. I think that would not only re-establish those links between Aboriginal people and their land but also give them responsibility for that land. They would have some reason for hope in the future that they could build a better lifestyle for themselves and their families. They do not feel that association with the land when somebody in Canberra—or an organisation such as the Northern Land Council, over which they have little or no influence—has title to that land.

I think that this amendment offers a real opportunity for a turnaround in the hopes and aspirations of ordinary Aboriginals. They will no longer have to rely on nepotism or the goodwill of a land council and its white advisers in the Aboriginal industry in order to get title to or have an association with the land that is important to them. They will have the opportunity to receive funding from taxpayers to acquire land in their own names. Yesterday I likened this a little to the way in which the old agricultural banks used to help farmers get established on the land—young farmers purchase schemes. I think this land fund would be really valuable if it were able to provide funding, particularly on a loans basis, to assist Aboriginal people to get established on a parcel of land of their own in an industry of their own. That would give them an opportunity to build for their own future.

It seems that the government does not want Aborigines to own land. The only people who are allowed to own land are those who are part of the Aboriginal industry—the Aboriginal corporations and the like. I think we will make real progress in the health, welfare and education of Aboriginal people when they have an opportunity to possess the title to their land. Then they can identify with a particular parcel of land that is theirs, not a corporation's. They can take responsibility for that land and pass it on to their children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to rise again, but it is extremely difficult to remain seated when some matters are raised that are entirely inaccurate and do not reflect the government's position. Let me make it very clear that every single one of these amendments that come before the House advanced by the coalition was drafted by the coalition without any consultation with a single indigenous person in this country. The reason I know this is that the shadow minister told the Australian media that she had not talked to anyone. It was then up to me to send to the indigenous people as much of the coalition information as was publicly available. It was up to me to try to consult with indigenous people—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I addressed this matter before—that it seemed like the minister and I were giving personal explanations. I am happy for the minister to give what seems to be a personal explanation as long as I can do the same.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! That is not a point of order. Furthermore, I am very sensitive to the matter of personal explanations, given the reasonable point of order taken by the honourable member for Barker. I do not believe that the minister was entering the area of a personal explanation. In my opinion, he was elaborating on the state of the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of my rising is to make it very clear that it was up to the government—can you believe it!—to take some steps to consult indigenous people around this country about the opposition amendments. What an extraordinary way to run an opposition. I did my best, and the opposition could have done the same. It took a phone and a fax to send out the publicly available information that I had that had been put forward by the coalition. If members opposite want me to table my letter to indigenous organisations, I will.

PARA.TAB: The main point of my rising is to knock on the head this myth that somehow or other I just consulted appointed people. My first port of call, and the government's first port of call, in seeking advice from indigenous people is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. I consulted the Chief Executive Officer of ATSIC, Patricia Turner, for her independent professional advice. But, more importantly, my first port of call was to the Acting Chairperson of ATSIC, Commissioner Charles Perkins. I picked up the phone; it was very easy.

Charles Perkins has put forward a very clear articulation of ATSIC's view on this bill. I read it into Hansard yesterday and will not read it all again. The concluding paragraph is pretty damning. Mr Perkins stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The time has come for the Coalition to get behind this Bill, to declare in unequivocal terms its commitment to land acquisition with no strings attached.
That is the view of the highest elected indigenous person in this country. It is about time that those opposite listened to indigenous people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very briefly want to address the matters just raised by the minister. If the minister had given us a delay in debating this bill, it is possible that those amendments could have been circulated for discussion.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want at this point to enter into this debate on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. The opposition has had two months to consult with any number of Aboriginal people anywhere in Australia about these particular issues, and it failed to do so. A caravan, comprising the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and his shadow spokesperson, went to Central Australia to discuss issues of importance. They could have used that opportunity to discuss their amendments with not only Charles Perkins but also the land councils and indigenous people around the Northern Territory. It could well have been done, but they failed to do so.

PARA.TAB: They come into this House and bleat because the government has said that it will not accept their propositions and has criticised them for not bothering to consult with Aboriginal people. They have had the opportunity of consultation, and they have not chosen to use it. They stand condemned for the fact that they have not bothered to work with Aboriginal people on these amendments. Then they say to us, `You're only talking to Aboriginal bureaucrats.' The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) talked to us about these bureaucrats overriding Aboriginal views. That just shows the ignorance—I will not use the term that I would like to use—in the way in which he has approached these issues. Those people do represent Aboriginal interests. I have worked with them for years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The same ones all the time.

—Yes, the same ones all the time. Charles Perkins and I do not agree on everything. The opposition person sitting at the table is saying that we choose to speak to the same ones all the time. If we did not speak to the ATSIC commissioners, as the supreme elected body of indigenous people in Australia, we would stand condemned as you are condemned. It would be totally inappropriate not to consult. Are you saying to us that it is wrong or inappropriate to speak to ATSIC commissioners? Are you saying that Aboriginal people should not choose Charles Perkins because he is the same person we spoke to last year? What are you saying to us?

PARA.TAB: We speak to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) every second day of the week. We have had numerous leaders of the opposition, and I suspect we will have a new one shortly. The fact is that we do consult with Aboriginal people. The difference between us and the opposition is that we consult and work with Aboriginal people throughout Australia. You should learn to do that and then come into this place and talk to us about something which is meaningful. But do not come in here and accuse the government for not accepting your amendments by saying that we ought to allow you the time to go and consult when it is your responsibility to consult, not ours. It is your responsibility to consult, and you have failed to consult.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory will address his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most certainly.
—Furthermore, he might address them to the amendment.
—And the honourable member for O'Connor will be quiet.

—A couple of opposition members last night—one being an ex-shadow minister—made accusations that we were not into bipartisanship over these particular amendments. I see merit in what he is saying, in that he is disconcerted with the way he is treated by the opposition—but not by the government. I can see that he would consider pushing these amendments within the opposition as a very difficult road to hoe and that he would be very frustrated by the fact that they were not allowed enough time to develop them in the first instance.

PARA.TAB: The opposition's first position was to oppose the land fund. It went on the public record and said, `We oppose the land fund.' So why does it want amendments, you ask? Because the Leader of the Opposition goes to Tasmania and all of a sudden decides that he is going to dump the member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), comes back in here and says, `We're now going to support in principle the land fund, but we have a range of amendments. If you don't accept them, we won't support the land fund.' What sort of position is that to adopt and then to blame us for the fact that they have not consulted? It is your responsibility to consult, not ours. The fact is you failed to consult. These amendments are inappropriate and will not be supported by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the five-minute speech of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) not one word was addressed to the issue of the opposition's amendment and why it should be rejected. It was just a nice, little political speech with, of course, references to the past. If you really want to debate the past, we may as well debate Arthur Calwell's view on the White Australia policy. We may as well; it is as relevant as remarks about the past.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about the present. The racist attitude of the old ALP is on the record. I will not quote the most despicable remark attributed to Arthur Calwell because you know it. Do not let us have this business about a decision of even some weeks ago. Let us talk about the amendment that is on the Notice Paper at this moment and which we argue acts in the interest of Aboriginal people.

I was watching the television when the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) was trying quite reasonably to explain why this matter should be rejected. Let me say, of the remarks of the member for the Northern Territory—and I am sure you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, would concur—that this business of consultation means, irrespective of the democratic fundamentals of ATSIC, that their own voters are entitled to be consulted too.
