In the rural areas of Western Australia, I frequently find the views expressed by individual farmers in grave contradiction even with the views expressed by that democratically elected leader of the NFF, the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan).
Mr McLachlan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I mean in those days. There are a lot of people who might even cast a vote. Their vote may not be successful, but they are entitled to be consulted. It is a fact that, in arriving at these decisions in our party room debate on this particular principle, speaker after speaker quoted the needs of the grassroot constituency they have been also elected to represent.

PARA.TAB: Many of us do not represent those extremely remote areas where, according to the native title decision of the High Court, native title will probably be claimed. These people live in areas such as the electorate of O'Connor, as huge as it is, where there is hardly an acre of land that could be defined in that fashion. I refer to it as unalienated land, and I believe that is what it is: land that nobody other than the Crown has any effect over.

They are good people, they have achieved quite a considerable degree of integration in their local communities, they are Aboriginal, they come from those areas, they can trace their heritage through those areas; and they would like some land. The simple fact of life is that they are not tribal any more. They cannot gather together 100 or 50 people and say, `We are a tribe. You should make us a corporation and by some process we will own some land per favour of the ILC.' They do not exist in that situation any more. In some of the areas, they even find themselves in conflict with other people because of old tribal problems.

My understanding of this legislation was that these were the people whose problem you were going to address; you were going to let native title take care of those who had traditional links with the outer area. It is totally impossible to address the requirements of these little groups of people by buying them—

TALK.START.PARA: —They can easily incorporate.

—We say that, but we say a family company. Your concept of a corporation is entirely different. I have that situation in my electorate now. We are told that the land council and ATSIC have bought farms for people in my electorate, but the people do not own them. They have no rights to mortgage them to buy plant. ATSIC did not buy them plant, and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and I have corresponded on this issue. He throws his hands in the air and cannot do anything about it. This amendment lets the ILC recognise the needs—and I understand that—of these sorts of people. That is what I thought your legislation was all about. For goodness sake, take a breath and think about it. (Time expired)

—I want to respond to a couple of the points made by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) in his response to my earlier remarks. I was not critical that he had chosen to speak to the land councils about the coalition amendments. It is reasonable that he should talk to that group. My comment was to reflect on the quality and objectivity of the advice he would have got from the land councils.

PARA.TAB: The land councils, as a key part of the Aboriginal industry, will be at the centre of acquiring land from this particular land fund. They are the bears that have their hands in the honey pot, and they do not want to share the honey pot with anyone else. It is these particular land councils that are the owners of vast areas of Australia—something like 16 per cent. They are the owners of the land, not the Aboriginal people.

I was trying to make the very important point that, if we really believed in land rights, if we really believed that the ownership of land is important to Aboriginal people, we should let them own the land and not put some kind of corporation in the way. We should give individual people the opportunity to purchase land and, if there is to be a fund, that fund should be able to direct some of its money towards assisting individual Aborigines, individual families or individual groups who want to acquire land for their own use.

The second point I want to make is in relation to a letter from Mr Perkins in which he said that he wanted the fund to be approved with `no strings attached'. If that is the case, the government should be supporting our amendment because we are seeking to reduce one of the strings that is currently attached: namely, that only corporations can own the land. We are seeking to grant them additional flexibility so that land ownership can also be provided to individuals.

As I said earlier, there would be very real advantages in attaching specific responsibility to specific parcels of land so that one Aborigine, as distinct from everybody else in the world, would be able to say that that is his land for which he has responsibility, instead of putting in place land councils and other corporations—which, as I mentioned earlier, are a key part of the Aboriginal industry—as the only ones that can be trusted with the ownership of land.

This is a most unfortunate attitude for the government to have taken; it is a most unfortunate approach to have developed in this whole area. Much more progress could be made for individual families. They could demonstrate to other Aborigines and to other Australians that they are able to carefully manage property, make it better and provide something for future generations to work towards. They could demonstrate that they are able to be worthwhile custodians of the land and, in addition, make it productive for our country.

I think the minister has misrepresented my concerns on the advice he sought. I discount the value of that advice because I believe it was vested interests speaking very strongly in defence of their own protected position. I am not saying anything about the validity of ATSIC elections. I will not make any comments at this stage about the irregularities associated with those elections and their legitimacy to fill those positions. I think that is irrelevant at this time.

The key thing is that the advice that was given came from a sector with a particular vested interest. I think many Aborigines would disagree with the view presented and would like to have access to the assistance that could potentially be available through this fund to help them acquire land in their own right.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition has laboured mightily and brought forth a mouse, but it does not even roar; it can only squeak.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is the consideration in detail stage. If the member can do no more than make those sorts of allegations instead of getting straight to the issue—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a point of order. The point of order is that we are in consideration in detail and references like `mouse' denigrate it.
—I understand where we are. There is no point of order.

—The coalition has called for more and more accountability, as it has on other occasions on other issues. Now it is proposing an amendment which, presumably, would give no accountability and which would open up the possibility of corruption—all the things it keeps arguing about in terms of accountability. One of the reasons things are put through incorporated bodies is so that there can be some sort of accountability.

PARA.TAB: Once again, the coalition is really imposing an Anglo-Celtic view of the world on Aboriginal people—another issue that goes to the heart of this amendment. This bill is about giving Aboriginal communities the opportunity to obtain land for those people who will not be able to benefit from Mabo. I do not want to rework all those arguments. This is absolutely irrelevant. The problem with these amendments is that they have been cobbled together for very different reasons to try to placate the moderates. We have heard a fascinating debate from the coalition—the bleeding hearts. My heart bleeds for the bleeding hearts of the Liberal Party. The best thing they can say to us is, as the shadow minister said—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the standing orders in relation to this type of debate on the matter of detail. The member has the opportunity to stand up here and give substantial reasons why this amendment should not be supported. They should not include references to bleeding hearts and political aspirations of certain people in the opposition. The amendment is very clearly defined. If she believes it is wrong—she has already said that you cannot trust Aboriginals as individuals; she said that—
—Get to the point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am asking you to bring her back to stating the reasons why this amendment should not pass. She should not give us a historical lesson on something that happened in the party room—

—Order! We are not going to have a debate on it. There is no point of order. The member for Capricornia may continue. Of course, she will use her best endeavours to speak specifically to the amendment.

—Indeed, I will. Once again, unfortunately, the coalition has not consulted with the Aboriginal people. They had two months. The shadow minister said, `You should have given us more time. We would like to play ball, but we are going to change the rules. If you do not change the rules we are going to take our bat and ball and go home.' If you were really concerned about the welfare of Aboriginal people, you would be out there consulting with them.

PARA.TAB: In this whole argument about the vested interests of the land councils and so on—this matter has been raised by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss)—I believe that it would be very sensible for the government, as it has done, to consult with the elected representatives, the people who represent the collectivity of the Aboriginal people. The reality is that all of the spokespeople have come out absolutely against this amendment because, at the end of the day, giving rights to individual families will not forward the aspirations and needs of Aboriginal people to be empowered to gain land. That is the bottom line.

This area of the bill is about making sure that we provide for those Aboriginal people who will not be given rights under the native title legislation an opportunity to have land. That is the issue at stake here. That is why we do not support the amendment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just one brief point of clarification about consultation. There has been considerable and lengthy consultation during the holiday break. The final amendments, in their drawn-up form, simply did not get to Aboriginal groups. That is the point I am making, not that there has not been consultation as the government keeps insisting. There has been extensive consultation by me and the previous shadow ministers that led us to draw up these amendments.
—And individual MPs.
—And all individual MPs on this side of the House who represent enormous Aboriginal constituencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just for the record, that is diametrically opposed to what the shadow minister has told the Australian media in conversations and public statements to the press gallery.

—In contradicting the minister, the simple fact is that both statements are true. The final amendments were not sent out to the Aboriginal bureaucracy, but they were based on the considered opinions of all the representatives of Aboriginal people who were elected—and probably by them—to come to this parliament via the Liberal Party. Those views were stated in our party room.

PARA.TAB: If that is not consultation and representation, I would like to know what is. We are being told about elected people. I kept asking the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) whether Noel Pearson, who seems to be the first spokesman she rings up on everything, was elected. The answer, of course, is no. Most of the other so-called spokesmen that you talk with are not elected; they are self-appointed. ATSIC is elected, and it forms a component of all of this.

The point I am making is that the opposition has been consulting on these issues and has arrived at this amendment on the basis of that consultation with grassroots people but, because of the pressures of time, did not eventually send out the fine print to the people whom you believe are the only people worth consulting—the Aboriginal bureaucracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to get back to the nature of the amendment and the utter confusion on the other side about Aboriginal affairs. It is possible for Aboriginal people, like other Australians, to purchase land. The government has provided, through the structure of ATSIC, a possibility for Aboriginal people, because they are disadvantaged, to benefit by way of loans through ATSIC. It is difficult for Aboriginal people to go through banks, so they get subsidised loans, just like the farmers get subsidised loans. That is the mechanism by which individual Aboriginal people can purchase land, like any other Australians.

PARA.TAB: The coalition at the last election wanted to cut ATSIC's funds by 10 per cent. That would have meant 10 per cent less money in this country for Aboriginal people to purchase individual land. What hypocrisy from the other side. This legislation is about compensation for dispossession—something completely different. Groups of Aboriginal people, clan groups, language groups, have been forced off the land with the complicity of governments and with the complicity in a lot of cases, I am afraid, of the European population in this country. Now they have to be compensated. We have to look towards the future to provide them with economic independence. As a responsible government we have to look towards providing benefit to the greatest number of Aboriginal people. To do that we have to accommodate groups of Aboriginal people that come to us and say, `We want to use this land for an economic purpose' or `Perhaps we did have some affiliation with this land. We cannot qualify under the Mabo legislation. We want to use this land, we want to develop this land, to build our future.' That is the nature of this legislation.

What a ridiculous situation it would be if a group of Aboriginal people came along wanting to buy a piece of land, then one Aboriginal person came along with no affiliation with the land wanting to buy it, then someone from Melbourne came to my electorate and said, `I like that bit of land; I want to purchase that bit of land' and then someone from Western Australia came along and said, `I like that bit of land, too. It is a good bit of land. I will purchase that bit of land.' What utter nonsense.

The corporation will clearly have a responsibility to look towards those very things that I thought the coalition was concerned about in this debate—the future economic independence of Aboriginal people, health, housing, all those things. We have used the words `collective' and `communal'. It can only be meant in a communal sense. How can the children of Aboriginals and their children's children benefit if you give land to one individual? The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) suggested in an injection earlier, `Let them buy a boat.' He talked about buying a boat. What utter rubbish.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might get a living out of that, some economic independence.

—If people want to buy a boat, like any other individual they can buy a boat. The government assists them to buy a boat through the ATSIC loans scheme. It is very different. You just do not understand.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—The honourable member for Leichhardt will not engage in discourse with the honourable member for O'Connor. He will address his remarks through the chair. The honourable member for O'Connor might stop talking long enough to hear the chair talk to him. The honourable member for O'Connor—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is just ignoring you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Just ignore him.

—You just watch your step, too. I suggest to the honourable member for O'Connor that the purposes of this House would be better served if he did not conduct himself like a Greek chorus every time a member of the government speaks.

—The display of the honourable member for O'Connor in debate has been a disgrace. I do not think he has kept quiet for more than two seconds. He is the bovver boy of the opposition in this debate. It is he who represents the real view of the coalition on this issue, not the shadow spokesman, not the people who have spoken. The honourable member for O'Connor represents the views—
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. He can now go and buy a boat.

—I want to respond to a couple of the quite extraordinary statements made by the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell). Her comment that to enable individual Aborigines to own land through the land fund would open up the possibility of corruption is an ill thought out and insulting statement. To suggest that individual Aborigines cannot be trusted to own land is an affront. To suggest that when individuals own land it is more likely to involve corrupt practices than is the case with the land councils is also a defiance of history. When you look at the very patchy record of some of the land councils, the qualified auditors' reports, the suggestions of nepotism and misuse of funds, it is remarkable to suggest that they are the pillars of virtue to protect the land fund from corruption. That has not been the experience.

PARA.TAB: Providing individuals with the responsibility for land, I would submit, improves accountability. Each individual would be responsible for their own land and the management of the funds that are provided to them. There would be a clear chain of responsibility and a clear capacity to report on the stewardship of the funds that have been available. So I utterly reject the suggestion that to provide individual ownership of land increases the risk of corruption. I submit that precisely the opposite is the case.

The second comment made by the honourable member for Capricornia which I would contest was that somehow or other individual ownership of the land is an Anglo-Celtic view of title. That tends to imply that corporations and companies and elections are a part of the Aboriginal old ways. They are not. If ever there is something that is a part of an Anglo-Celtic tradition it is the establishment of corporations and companies. That degree of complexity was by no means a part of the old Aboriginal ways and their way of dealing with the ownership of land.

I suggest again that individual and family ownership of land is much closer to the old ways than the establishment of complicated corporations, reports to central bodies in remote capital cities and the sort of system that is being proposed by the government under these arrangements. In every sense what is being proposed by the opposition in this amendment is much closer to the objectives espoused by the member for Capricornia than what is in the bill at present.

I would like to respond to the remarkable speech of the member for Leichhardt—remarkable for its enthusiasm rather than the legitimacy of its content. He suggested that Aborigines from far away may actually want to buy land in a particular area. That is precisely what the government is trying to set up in its proposals. It wants urban Aborigines to go out into country areas and buy land. Somehow or other it is all right if it is done through a corporation but it is not all right if it is done by an individual. Again, I reject that kind of concept.

Let us look at what is happening at present. I referred yesterday in my remarks to John Lee Jones in my own area, a person who is laying claim to most of my electorate at present. We had not seen him before the Fitzgerald inquiry opened up the possibility that there might be some role for Aborigines in the management of the Great Sandy Region. Now this man has appeared on the scene from who knows where to claim the area. This is the same man who is claiming $40 million worth of rewards from the Victorian government because his forefathers may have been associated with the capture of Ned Kelly. If that is the sort of remoteness that exists at present I suggest—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being fairly remote from the subject of the amendment. I would be grateful if you would come closer to it.

—I submit that local ownership of land is much more likely under the amendment that is put forward by the coalition than with what will occur under the remote corporation purchasing arrangements which the government will make compulsory under the proposals before the House.

—I do not wish to take up the time of the House unnecessarily, but I feel compelled to respond to what the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) had to say. The implication of his line of argument would turn not only government policy in this area but all government policy on its head. Are we now going to set up a style of government where we hand out money willy-nilly to people without any sort of due process or any sort of accountability?

PARA.TAB: My argument was that accountability is important. It was the coalition that again raised the issue that there should be more accountability in the area of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs than in other areas. But we have an amendment before us which seeks to throw all that to the wind. The result will be that we will have no accountability and no due process. The logical extension of the argument of the member for Wide Bay is that if someone says, `I would like to own this bit of land,' we will hand that person the money.

As the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) said, this part of the bill provides a process to deal with compensation for dispossession. It is not about giving a loan here or there so someone can get land easily. I hazard a guess that this amendment has been put forward to give the opposition a reason to participate in the debate, because there is not a great deal of logic in its essential element. The end result was that this ill thought out proposal hit the deck yesterday morning. We are being told that we should give the opposition more time. It had from 30 June. The opposition is having about as much trouble as the Russian space station is in getting its act together and getting an interlock device in place.

The member for Wide Bay made some pretty questionable remarks about backyards in his speech at the second reading stage yesterday. He got back to the old issue. At the bottom of this is the statement of the Leader of the National Party in Queensland which urges the coalition to go back to its original position and not to have the land acquisition bill at all. There is so much rhetoric on this issue coming from the opposition. The member for Wide Bay does not want any accountability. In my speech, I was trying to expose the lack of logic in the coalition's position.
Question put:
That the amendment (Mrs Gallus's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 3, page 3, omit proposed subsection 191D(2), substitute the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: " `(2) A grant or guarantee is subject to such terms and conditions as the Indigenous Land Corporation determines and the Indigenous Land Corporation must ensure that, in respect of each grant and guarantee, terms and conditions specify:

TAB.TAB: (a)time frames for the actions detailed, together with provisions to apply in the event that any of the terms or conditions are not satisfied, and

(b)that moneys granted must be used solely for the purposes for which they are granted and that where the Indigenous Land Corporation is satisfied that moneys granted are not being used for the intended purposes it must and will take steps to reclaim those moneys.' ".

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Clause 3, page 3, line 38, omit "have regard to the desirability of", substitute "give priority to".

These are not major amendments; they are minor amendments. The first of these amendments proposes `that moneys granted must be used solely for the purposes for which they are granted and that where the Indigenous Land Corporation is satisfied that moneys granted are not being used for the intended purposes it must and will take steps to reclaim those moneys'. This amendment obviously ensures that moneys given by the ILC are for the purposes intended. I would not have thought that this was such an absolutely outrageous amendment that the government could not support it.

PARA.TAB: We have asked that the moneys granted by the ILC be used for the purposes intended. If the moneys are not used in that way, there are ways to reclaim them. I will be absolutely fascinated to hear why the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) is not supporting this amendment. The second amendment ensures that, in its functions, the ILC must give priority to, and not just consider, the desirability of policy goals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked by the shadow minister, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), to explain to the opposition why we are not accepting these amendments to the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. I hope that she will give me the opportunity to do that. There are a great many reasons why we are not accepting the totality of the amendments before the House.

PARA.TAB: Some of the amendments would, on their face, dramatically undermine the fundamental integrity of the bill. For that reason they will not be accepted. In the government's view, there are other amendments which, while not in themselves undermining the integrity of the bill, add absolutely nothing of substance to the bill; therefore, the government requires a persuasive case before it will support any of those proposed amendments.

In response, the opposition says to the government, as the central tenet of its case, that the government ought to move to embrace the amendments so that we will have cross-party cooperation. While being the greatest advocate of cross-party cooperation in indigenous affairs in this parliament, I am never prepared to embrace agreement with the opposition if it means sacrificing principles that are important to indigenous people. In all the debates in the reconciliation process, that was always my bottom line. I will comment further on that question at a later stage.

The opposition has put the government in the position of having to make a decision about the bona fides of its amendments and having to make a decision about what the opposition would do if the government were prepared to accept amendments which, I repeat, add nothing to the bill or, alternatively, dramatically worsen the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pass the bill.

—The shadow minister interjects that the opposition would pass the bill. It is to this issue that I now wish to turn. Trying to reach agreement on this bill with the coalition is rather like trying to reach agreement with an octopus: you shake one hand but there are seven other hands floating around the parliament that are not part of the deal and are not prepared to agree with it. A demonstration of that fact is the way the opposition has presented its amendments to the parliament. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) said in this parliament—I refer to page 594 of the Daily Hansard of 30 August—that the coalition will support it—

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I stand corrected, if you would like to correct me, but I believe we agreed earlier that we were actually going to address each particular amendment and talk on that particular amendment. I would like a ruling from you on that so we can know the width of the debate on these particular amendments.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—The House in this part of the consideration of the bill will be dealing with each amendment. The debate will be restricted to the content of that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, I am seeking to address this very question of why the government is not accepting this particular amendment. The Leader of the Opposition put to the government, and I refer to the House of Representatives debate on page 594 of the Hansard of 30 August 1994, that the coalition will support the bill `subject to the government accepting our amendments'—not some of them or a negotiated outcome, but `accepting our amendments.' He went on:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the land fund and the Indigenous Land Corporation must be structured in such a way as to give priority to Aboriginal health, education and wellbeing overall.

He went on to say that the bill must be strengthened and enhanced in two other respects. He also said that the shadow minister will detail the amendments `upon which coalition support for the bill will rest'. So we were being presented, and we are still presented on the basis of what the Leader of the Opposition has said in Hansard, with a clear statement that we have to agree to all these amendments. We never could, and we never will.

PARA.TAB: But even more than that, the opposition is saying to the government that even if the government agreed to the great bulk of the amendments in the House of Representatives, or all the amendments moved, when the bill goes to the Senate it is going to start it all over again—there is another raft of amendments to be moved in the Senate and the threat of a parliamentary inquiry. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has provided absolutely no justification whatsoever for the government not accepting this amendment. He resorted to some recollections of previous speeches, but did not address the content of the amendments at all. It is no good just name-calling and saying processes within the opposition are a reason for rejecting an improvement to the bill.

PARA.TAB: Is the minister seriously suggesting that no matter what improvements the opposition could make to the bill, no matter how acceptable they might even be to the government, the government is still not going to vote for them because of some predetermined position? That is bloody-mindedness of the worst kind. Does this government want its legislation to be shoddy? Is it not prepared to accept genuine suggestions for improvements?

The minister is trying to imply in his comments that it does not matter how good a proposal the opposition puts up, the government will refuse to accept it. That is just plain stupidity. The government says, `It does not matter how wrong we are, we are going to use the might of numbers to push this legislation through and fail to correct its deficiencies.'

What the opposition is suggesting in these amendments is, I would have thought, perfectly reasonable and acceptable; namely, that money should be spent for the purposes for which it was provided. Surely that is a reasonable suggestion, yet the government is going to toss it out because it will not accept advice from anyone. The government says, `It does not matter how wrong our legislation is, how flawed it might be, it is going to stay that way because we are not prepared to listen to anybody else's advice. We are not prepared to make it better.'

If the government is entering into this debate with that kind of attitude, it really will be a pretty unproductive four or five hours we have ahead of us. No matter how good our arguments are and no matter how well we may win the argument around this chamber, the might of numbers is going to be used mercilessly, irrespective of merits. Frankly, that is not what democracy is about. That ought not to be what this chamber is about. It ought to be about making the best possible legislation for Australia; it ought to be about accepting worthwhile amendments; and it ought to be about making the legislation as good as it possibly can be.

The minister is not prepared to improve the legislation. I think that fact needs to be remembered by Australians when they are reviewing this issue. When we come back in a few months time to look again at this legislation, as we inevitably do when the government uses its might of numbers irrespective of the facts to force legislation through, a black mark will be placed very much against this minister and this government who have refused to accept the advice of others who believe that all wisdom rests on their side and that no-one else is entitled to make suggestions to make the legislation better. I think that is a very dangerous sign for our democracy. The minister should provide precise reasons why the amendment moved by the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) is to be rejected. He has failed to do this, and that is to his shame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am only going to make a few comments, but there are some very important things I wish to put on the public record. As I said in my earlier remarks, the government is prepared and was prepared to look at amendments on their merits, but the bottom line is that the amendments put forward either worsen the bill or add nothing material to it.

PARA.TAB: Ultimately, the government's objective is to get a bill through not only the House of Representatives but also the Senate. There is clearly evidence available to the government that whatever is said by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) in this chamber and elsewhere on the public record does not necessarily mean the delivery of a Senate majority. If you want any further example of that, you have only to look at the on the record statements of the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) in support of the actions taken by Cathy Freeman at the Commonwealth Games. When it got to the Senate, the senators from the coalition opposed the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. We are required in these detailed sections to deal with the precise nature of the amendments. Comments about Kathy Martin at the Commonwealth Games are in no way referred to in these amendments.
—I accept the point of order. The minister will speak to the amendments themselves.
—Kathy Martin is a great sport, but she was not at the Commonwealth Games.
—I accept the correction.

—In relation to amendment No. 2, the coalition is essentially seeking to constrain the role of the board of the Indigenous Land Corporation. I have to ask: in relation to a body that all members ought to be aware of, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, which exists under legislation now unanimously supported by the parliament, what is the position? Has the parliament constrained the board of ATSIC in the way that you are now seeking to do with the Indigenous Land Corporation? The answer is no, we have not sought to constrain it. I think that is a rather pertinent and important point. In the most significant indigenous organisation in this country, with a budget ultimately in the order of a billion dollars, there is no such constraint. Why do you seek to constrain the board of the Indigenous Land Corporation? It is for this reason that we are not accepting that amendment.
—It is providing it with more powers.

—If you want to intercede, I will give you another reason. There may well be very good reasons why the board of the corporation needs some flexibility in the terms and conditions that it makes in relation to decisions that are taken. It is important to give the board flexibility.

PARA.TAB: In relation to amendment No. 3, the fact is that this amendment also does not represent a real improvement to the bill. We see it as a step that, in fact, would undermine the flexibility that is given to the Indigenous Land Corporation's operation. We simply see no merit in the proposal. But the bottom line is: even if we accepted all the amendments that you want, the Leader of the Opposition is on the public record as saying that he is still not necessarily going to support the bill because there is another raft of amendments for the Senate. That is the kind of shambles that the Australian public sees as the way you are conducting the debate on this critically important legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have to refute what the minister has just said. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) has said no such thing. Let us look at the logic of this position. We have said in the past that we were going to oppose the land fund, but we are actually in here today debating it. It is no good saying, `Whatever you have said in the past, we know what is in your mind and what you are going to do in the Senate.' It has nothing to do with this amendment. Whatever excuse is used for drawing this conclusion, which is illogical—the proof of the pudding is that we are standing here debating amendments today—I do not think you should be able to get away with it.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—I am not trying to get away with anything. You are directing your remarks through the chair, are you not?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the minister should be able to get away with it, and I was trying to make sure that he did not. The main thrust of this amendment is that we change the words in the bill from `A grant or guarantee is subject to such terms and conditions as the Indigenous Land Corporation determines' to say that there should be some time frames detailed for the actions given; that moneys granted must be used solely for the purposes for which they are granted; and that if the board—that is, the board of directors—is satisfied that moneys are not being used for that purpose, it must and will take steps to reclaim them.

PARA.TAB: I have been involved in a few ventures in my time, some of which have been very successful and some of which have been not so successful. I cannot imagine that any director would oppose those propositions. No director that I have ever met would. They are reasonably minor, but particular. These sorts of amendments are very important, but government members say, `We will not agree to them because they are not important,' or `They do not add anything to the bill,' or `They reduce the powers of the board members.'

The minister said, `It is important to give the board flexibility.' In regard to financial matters, no board wants a lack of flexibility that is onerous. But this is not onerous. There is nothing onerous about this. It is just about accountability, which is the second main thrust of our amendments. The first amendment was about flexibility—something that the minister just said we should give the board. He just said, `It is important to give the board flexibility.' He did not want to give the board any of the flexibility in the first amendment. He wanted to tell it that it could give land only to corporations.

Now we want a bit of accountability. The problem we have encountered with all of these amendments is the absolute illogicality of your position in not dealing with them. When we dealt with the first amendment, I pointed out that the board would have the choice. We gave it a bit more flexibility—something that you are so keen on—and now we are asking for some accountability. It is something that no responsible board member would ever even quibble with. I will finish my speech before the allotted time expires, because many members wish to speak in this debate.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) fails to appreciate that no other piece of legislation in this Commonwealth parliament—that I am aware of—has such a provision as has been proposed in the opposition's amendment regarding clause 3. If there is one, will someone please find it for me?

PARA.TAB: The issue of flexibility is very simple. If by legislation we constrain the ability of the board to make decisions, instead of giving specifics about the terms and conditions, it might become very vague. So you will have the opposite effect of the intent of the amendment. I suggest that members opposite should understand that the accountability provisions which are in the act are already sufficient and are standard in terms of what the Commonwealth government requires.

The land fund will form part of the public account, which means that, amongst other things, investments for the land fund are regulated by the provisions of the Audit Act and that money held by the corporation can only be applied strictly in the performance of its functions. The general requirements which you seek are already in the legislation. The specific requirements you want about tying the terms and conditions are not appropriate. I say again: point out one other piece of legislation coming from this parliament which has such a requirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a couple of points in relation to what the minister said about why he is not addressing this matter in the House of Representatives because of what he thinks is going on in the Senate. The opposition supported this bill in principle. There was no opposition at the second reading, showing that the opposition gave it in principle support. We then asked the government to look at some amendments that we had to this bill. So, our having given in principle support and the bill having passed through the stage of the second reading, all the minister had to do was sit down, go through these amendments with us and look at them on their merits. He has not done this. He has wiped off this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! I hope you are speaking specifically to amendments 2 and 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I ask the minister why, if he thought this did not add to the bill or it in some way took away from the bill, he did not come and discuss this with me and say, `Look, Chris, why don't we talk about this and see why I don't want to put it in.' Could the minister also explain to me why flexibility for the board is appropriate in this amendment but was not appropriate in the last amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer the last question first. I find it extraordinary that the coalition seeks to advance an argument which is founded on two entirely different propositions. Earlier we were talking about an entirely different subject matter. In this case we are talking about an unprecedented attempt—as the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) so aptly reminded the House—in the legislation of this parliament to write in terms which are not in any other legislation, and in particular not in the legislation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

PARA.TAB: I want to make it very clear that, while the shadow minister is going around saying that the coalition has given in principle support, the coalition has given nothing of the sort. The coalition has introduced a whole raft of amendments, promised a further raft of amendments in the Senate and hung over the head of the bill the Damoclean sword of a Senate committee as the precondition for coalition support for the bill. There is no support in principle for this bill. There never has been. An examination of the track record of the coalition shows that is clearly manifest in all the public statements it has made.

I conclude with one further reference. I do not intend to prolong this aspect of the debate, because the government's views are very much on the record. I make it clear that, consistently, not only yesterday but in the course of the previous evening, I have sought the amendments from the shadow minister. I have examined each and every one of them. You will hear from the government cogent and detailed arguments why we do not believe that they are worthy of support. You will also hear from us as to what we understand to be the wider agenda of the coalition, which fortifies our convictions that these amendments should not be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to a couple of the comments that have been made by members of the opposition with regard to amendments 2 and 3. As has been outlined by the minister, neither amendment strengthens the accountability procedures in any effective way. What they do is bind the corporation's board in a way which is far more restrictive than is required in any other piece of legislation affecting either Aboriginal affairs or any other corporation or community organisation that this government has dealings with and gives grants of money or loans to.

PARA.TAB: That is one of the big problems we have with amendments 2 and 3 and the perception that the opposition is seeking to perpetrate in these amendments, which is that we expect Aboriginal organisations to be far more accountable than any other organisation that this government deals with. It is a problem that we have had too often in this parliament. This problem has been debated in this parliament and its relevant committees with regard to Aboriginal affairs.

Opposition members are being inconsistent in putting forward this amendment. As they said previously, they wanted to provide flexibility to the board in the determination of who was eligible to gain grants of land. We pointed out quite clearly that that was totally inconsistent with the basic purposes of this fund.

With this amendment, the opposition is now seeking to tie the board up in knots. It is seeking to put very restrictive clauses into this bill which outline what the terms and conditions should be. Rather than giving the board the capacity to make those judgments itself, the opposition, by this amendment, is seeking to constrain the board in a very difficult way which will result in enormous difficulties for the board in administering its responsibilities in these land dealings. That will not improve the bill.

The honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) made the point in his contribution that the government should respond when there are genuine amendments being put forward. I agree with him. If these were genuine amendments, I would be more than happy to say that the government should be looking at them. The government has looked at each one of them. We have looked at whether each proposed amendment strengthens the bill, makes the bill clearer and makes the process easier and simpler. The fact of the matter is that not one of these amendments passes that basic test. One therefore has to question the genuineness of this series of amendments. I do not believe they were motivated by a genuine desire to make the land acquisition fund work better.

The problem with the two proposed amendments is that they will not improve the operation of the land acquisition fund and the capacity of the board to administer the grants that it might make. These amendments are consistent with a position which some people in the community seek to espouse that says that Aboriginal organisations have to be three or four times more accountable for every dollar they are granted than any other department, corporation or community service organisation that the Commonwealth has dealings with or delivers grants to. That is the big problem that is behind these two amendments. They will not improve the fund or the opportunities for Aboriginal people to have access to land and to make good use of that land. They will make their job that much more difficult. That is why we are rejecting amendments Nos 2 and 3 as proposed by the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to these two amendments and to rebut the argument of the government that they in some way reduce the flexibility of the ILC and in some way make its functions much harder. In the debate, the minister raised the question of accountability and touched on similar requirements or non-requirements that are applicable to ATSIC. It is pertinent to this debate—it is obviously a matter that is integral to any discussion of accountability—to look at instances where ATSIC has failed, particularly in my state, to acquit properly some of the moneys that have been given to it.
—Oh, here we go again.
—We can see that the fascist Left of the ALP, which is quite clearly intolerant of any differing point of view, is now trying to interrupt or in some way stop my speech.
—Ha, ha!

—I note that the honourable member for Moreton is laughing. He would know, as we have seen continuously in this debate, that anybody of differing views is considered to be somehow racist, intolerant, a bigot or someone whose views are not worth considering. I happen to have changed my mind about this fund under the circumstances in which the legislation has been presented and the way in which my coalition colleagues and I have treated it—the proposed amendments are part of it—in the run-up to its being introduced into the House.

PARA.TAB: I was comfortable with the opposition's previous position, but I have changed my mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —You change that as often as you change your underwear, don't you?

—This is starting to become obscene. As I said, the fascist Left is totally unprepared to listen to another point of view. You ought to be thoroughly ashamed of yourself, because that is just typical thought police fascism on the part of the left wing of the ALP.

PARA.TAB: Mr Gibson interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —Order! The honourable member for Moreton might cease interjecting and the honourable member for Moore might like to direct his comments through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. The minister asked why we are treating the council in a different way from the way that ATSIC is treated. I argue in response that there ought to be more stringent requirements of accountability on the part of ATSIC. I hold that view strongly. It has come about as a result of looking at some of the ways in which moneys granted to ATSIC have not been properly acquitted, particularly in relation to housing projects in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I raise another matter of concern that has been raised by Aboriginals in Western Australia. A fund for a Rottnest Island deaths group meeting on Rottnest was made contingent by ATSIC on the group's agreeing to ATSIC's developmental proposals. In other words, it was told, `You won't get any money to organise this meeting unless you agree to putting our items on the agenda.' In other words, there is perhaps a need for greater accountability on the part of ATSIC in a range of areas, including in Western Australia and on the question of moneys that are being expended on housing, and training projects in relation to housing, for Aboriginals.

I am sure that the minister has an interest in ensuring that these types of activities are conducted properly. He should look more closely at the acquittal of moneys that have been granted in such a way. Many of the concerns have not been raised in the wider community; they have been raised within the Aboriginal community itself in Western Australia. The matters that I have referred to have gained some public notoriety in recent times.

In conclusion, I support these amendments because they form part of a framework of amendments that will make this legislation more accountable, more effective and, in the end, more of a service to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people whom it is supposed to serve. We in the coalition are adamant that those amendments must be agreed to before the legislation is carried. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The real reason behind these amendments is very simple. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) sacked the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). He needed to shore up the moderates in the party. The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) quite happily takes that label. He wanted to keep those few in the Liberal Party on side—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think it was agreed earlier that when going through these amendments we would address them as they are written and not go into a wider debate.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —The honourable member for Hindmarsh has a point. In this process, the requirement is that speakers stick to the matters before the chamber. I ask the honourable member to bear that in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting to that. Because he had to appease those elements—
—I am sure the honourable member will get to the substance of the amendments.

—He changed his mind and said that he would accept the bill and move the amendments. But then he had to appease the rednecks in the Liberal and National parties. That is what this amendment is about. This amendment is to appease the rednecks in the Liberal and National parties who take the view that Aboriginal people are less capable than other Australians of managing their financial affairs, so we have to put more stringent financial requirements on them than on other people in Australia. That is the view of the rednecks in the Liberal and National parties.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The debate is starting to be degraded by the honourable member terming anybody who is opposed. I said earlier that this is the fascist, thought-police, left-wing view of the world: if you do not agree with them, you are labelled a bigot or a redneck.

—Order! The member for Moore will resume his seat. He is now debating the issue. This particular matter before the House is a matter of some sensitivity and there have been insults passed across the chamber from time to time.

PARA.TAB: Mr Gibson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Moreton! As other deputy speakers in this position have said, members ought to restrain themselves as much as they can in this context.
—Let us have a look at the amendment. Proposed subsection 191D(2)(b) states:

SPEECH.PARA: that moneys granted must be used solely for the purposes for which they are granted and that where the Indigenous Land Corporation is satisfied that moneys granted are not being used for the intended purposes it must and will—
I have never heard those words in legislation—
take steps to reclaim those moneys.

What an absurd restriction to place on any financial institution. That completely takes away the right of any organisation to forgo a loan. It takes away its right to say, `Well, we can't pursue this, it's a commercial decision.' All commercial organisations make decisions from time to time to let a loan go. Any corporation must have that power.

PARA.TAB: I see the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) in the chamber. Obviously he has experience in business. I guess that all businesses in Australia make that decision from time to time. This amendment says `must and will', so businesses cannot make a decision to forgo reclaiming moneys for the loan. As the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) said, that restriction is unknown in any legislation. No member on the other side of the House can point to any legislation which says that anybody must and will take steps to recover moneys owing, because it is a quite unreasonable restriction on any financial institution and can be based only on a prejudice against Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member said that anybody who is opposed to that is prejudiced against Aborigines, and that is unparliamentary—or worse.

—I do not think it is. I think it has been said in the context of this debate, which has been an unfortunate debate in some ways. But I ask the member for Leichhardt to restrain himself in some of his comments. However, his time has now expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the second reading debate and earlier today I drew the attention of the House to the types of corporations this government and some other governments have appointed over time to protect the interests of Aboriginal people and their money. I drew the attention of the House a little earlier to the comments of the New South Wales Auditor-General in relation to a $12 million loss of the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council when he said:

PARA.TAB: This effectively had retarded the Council's ability to establish economic self-sufficiency for the Aboriginal community . . .

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, the opposition therefore has every right to put forward amendments of this nature to ensure the rules are tightened up on this type of operation. Some of these operations, unfortunately, have a bad reputation. I do not want to go back too much to the other debate. Our argument is simply that, if these grants were given to people representing much smaller interest groups, accountability would be enhanced by that process. But the government is determined that the ILC will administer these funds. I could almost write a list at this point of the people who are likely to be appointed to the ILC. Their names keep recurring.

PARA.TAB: The record of all of these groups is particularly bad. But, more importantly, nothing seems to be done about it. The real fundamental is that nothing seems to be done about it. The money which was meant to help a lot of grassroots Aboriginals is consumed in many ways—frequently improperly—and nothing is done about it. Obviously, the Australian people are entitled to know that the money is administered properly, and that is why we seek these additional demands.

In the second reading debate, I drew the attention of honourable members to the Aboriginal Homes Development Association in Western Australia—a recipient of $614,000—which chose in its budget, authorised by the then Premier of Western Australia, Carmen Lawrence, to spend $277,000 out of that $614,000 on salaries for two people. There are allegations, very commonly placed in Western Australia, that the project manager was at the same time in receipt of a full salary from the Public Service Commission because he had a five-year contract with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—That was Brian Easton. His wife, Penny Easton, suicided after allegations were made in the parliament about her. As the story goes, in the end, the Aboriginal people dumped this gentleman, but the fact is that he was imposed by the Premier of Western Australia on the project and no money was left for housing. Other costs incurred were travel and airfare costs of $8,600 per annum and sitting fees for other trust members of $12,000 a year. I have not added these figures to the $277,000. Just two people got that. There was also a project officer, who was an employee of the Public Service Commission and, to the best of our knowledge, was remunerated by it. In fact, before her suicide, his wife claimed that it was a kickback, but we are really talking about accountability.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—It is probably relating to the relevance of these comments to the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it relates to relevance.
—The member for O'Connor is well aware of the need to be relevant to the matters before the House. Could he just bear in mind how these comments are relevant to the amendments.

—The matter of relevance is that we are debating the issue of accountability of the ILC—this new corporation—to handle $1 billion. I am just giving two actual written examples. I might help by tabling the Premiers's signature on this issue. I am giving examples of how this has been run in the past.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Order! The member for O'Connor will need leave to table that document. Is leave granted to table that document?
—No.
—Leave is not granted at this stage.
—The document carries the signature of Carmen Lawrence approving this budget.
—The member for O'Connor may like to consult with the minister at a later stage if that is the case.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order relating to relevance. The member for O'Connor continues to talk about a Western Australian corporation. We are talking about a Commonwealth bill and Commonwealth legislation.
—The member for Leichhardt will resume his seat. The honourable member's time has expired anyway, but I think that the member for O'Connor was using it as a comparison.

—I do not want to hold the House for too long. I just make the observation that this is a silly amendment. There is no way in the world that opposition members could convince me that they sought and received any intelligent advice about the structure and the nature of public appropriations, public accounts and auditing procedures at national and state levels. The provisions which exist already are more than adequate to deal with the sorts of concerns they have expressed here today. It is a silly amendment and there is no reason for the government to adopt it. I am sure that the government will not be doing so.

—I want to address a couple of the thrusts that seem to be developing on the government side. Those opposite try to refute these amendments by saying that they really know what we have in mind, by quoting words from the Leader of the Opposition. In other words, they know what we think and, therefore, they are going to vote against every amendment, no matter what the amendments say. That is an excuse for not addressing the amendments. How do I know that? Even before this minister got to see the amendments—certainly before he saw the detail of them—the Prime Minister said that he was not going to have any amendments.

PARA.TAB: At least the honourable member for Leichhardt tried to address one of these amendments. The thrust of what he was saying was that if the directors lent some money or gave a grant or guarantee to somebody for a particular purpose, but it was used for some other purpose, they should say or could say that they were not going to do anything about it. That is a nonsense. They would not do that if they were proper directors, and they should not do that.

All we are doing in this amendment is trying to make sure that the rather loose wording of the bill—which, to paraphrase, is that the grants and guarantees should be as from time to time decided by the directors—is firmed up. Every time the minister gets to his feet he says that he knows what is in our minds because of things produced by people last June or last week, or whenever. That is no argument and it should be totally discounted. We do totally discount it.

If he says that because these amendments were late they were lightly put together, I remind him that the government's 200 amendments to the Native Title Bill turned up just before the start of the committee stage, and some of them turned up as the minister got up to speak. Let us not have that holier than thou stuff or any more of that sanctimonious effluent that comes from those on the other side of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to do something which is a little bit unfashionable in this place at the moment. I am going to again turn to the specific terms of the amendments before the House.

—It was a gentle, friendly comment. Take it in the spirit in which it was said. The coalition's proposed amendments suggest that there ought to be a requirement that the board of the corporation include a specification of time frames in relation to its decisions. Not only in this legislation but in other legislation established by the Commonwealth parliament, a board is entrusted with a range of responsibilities. That is why we appoint a board. We do not seek, in the form of legislation, to regiment each and every aspect of the daily activities of the boards that we appoint. That is why we appoint them. We have people with expertise in whom we repose trust and on whom we impose very stringent standards of accountability, such as those manifested in this bill.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the question of time frames and the associated requirement to specify terms and conditions, it would be my view that the specification of time frames could disadvantage Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups in negotiations with potential sellers. Anyone who knows the difficulties involved in buying properties and in some of the negotiations that occur ought to be aware that it may not necessarily always, if ever, be desirable to specify those kinds of time frames.

The further suggestion that the board `must and will take steps to reclaim moneys' might lead to circumstances where, for example, because of a change in interest rates or because of some other unforeseen change—totally unrelated to issues of accountability—there could be some mandatory requirement to reclaim those moneys. I would think that, as a result, there would be a great deal of uncertainty for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

This kind of clause is not in this legislation—the most important legislation relating to an indigenous organisation, namely, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act. This is not the legislation of Robert Tickner; of the honourable member for Hughes and Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. This legislation is now owned by us all. It is unanimously supported by the Australian parliament.

If we do not have this kind of clause in the ATSIC legislation—ATSIC with a budget of $1 billion, virtually now totally controlled by elected indigenous people—why on earth would we want to include such a clause in this bill? What does it add? In our respectful opinion, it does not add anything. Regrettably, for that reason, we will not support this amendment.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4)Clause 3, page 4, lines 1-10, omit paragraph (a), substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(a)pursuing a policy of:
(i)acquiring interests in land and granting the interests to:
(A)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(B)aboriginal persons; or
(C)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(D)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts;
(ii)in cases where the Indigenous Land Corporation grants money to:
(A)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(B)aboriginal persons; or
(C)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(D)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts;
for the acquisition of interests in land—acting as the agent of the relevant corporations or persons in connection with those acquisitions

(except where the circumstances make the pursuit of such a policy impracticable or inadvisable) with regard, at all times, to the need to ensure that the health, housing or educational needs or economic viability of aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and communities will be improved as a result of the acquisition of land or interests in land to which those persons may have access.".

SPEECH.PARA: This is one of the opposition's key amendments. This amendment has been so totally and utterly misrepresented by the government that one would wonder what its motives were—the motives of the minister and all those in the government—in addressing this matter. I have heard government members make some of the most ridiculous claims. They have said that, through this amendment, we are requiring that when land is purchased there should be a hospital or a school or something else unlikely on it. I do not know whether government members cannot read or simply whether government members are deliberately sending out misinformation so as to confuse the Australian public and to mislead Aboriginal people. This amendment states that the Indigenous Land Corporation should give priority to:
pursuing a policy of—
so it does not have to do anything—
with regard . . . to the need to ensure . . .

It is not forcing the Indigenous Land Corporation to do anything. It is asking that, when the corporation draws up its strategy and makes determinations on how to spend a large amount of money, it give consideration to the following: the need to ensure that the health, housing or educational needs or economic viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and communities will be improved as a result of the acquisition of land or interest in land in which persons have access. Is that such a terrible amendment? It is asking that when the Indigenous Land Corporation spends a large amount of money—it will have $45 million a year to spend—it should look at how purchasing a particular piece of land will improve the lot of the community and address the needs of that community. If there are two possible pieces of land to buy and one does not have a road—so the children cannot get to school and the women cannot leave the community—the corporation could say, `This purchase is going to be detrimental to the health and education of this community so it is preferable to look at the other piece of land.'

PARA.TAB: On occasions properties have been bought that have not been economically viable—at no fault of the Aboriginal communities that moved onto them. When those Aboriginal communities moved on to those properties and found that they were not viable, they were left with properties that could not be operated and that were worthless to them. The young men and women on those properties did not have jobs. The children were left isolated, without access to schools, and more often than not there were problems with the water quality and the sanitation.

We do not want that to happen again in the administration of this fund. That is why we have simply asked that, when the corporation is determining how it spends the money, it says, `How will the health needs of the community be met?' That does not exclude buying land for people because it is their traditional land. We understand that in many cases the health of Aboriginals will improve if they return to their traditional land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 4 is also not acceptable to the government because, in the words of the shadow minister, `it seeks to refocus the bill away from land to a broader agenda.' The government believes land is critically important. This change, probably more than any of the other changes, is the one most vehemently objected to by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

PARA.TAB: I make it clear that it has not been the government that has misrepresented the opposition's position. In the interests of an honest debate, I ask the shadow minister: which government member was she referring to as the person who said that the opposition was insisting upon a hospital being built before land would be purchased by the fund? I have been present for most of this debate—certainly while the amendments have been considered—and I have not heard anything of that sort, nor have I read anything in Hansard. If I am wrong, I will be happy to say that that is not the intention of the opposition amendment. I think a number of deliberately erroneous things have been said in the course of this debate. I am curious to know what the shadow minister was referring to.

The bottom line is that the coalition, by moving this amendment, is advancing an argument which deliberately seeks to fudge the issue. That is why the government so strongly objects to the amendment and why indigenous people are passionately opposed to this form of amendment. What the coalition seems unable to do is to recognise an unambiguous human right of dispossessed indigenous people to gain some land as an economic base—or for cultural, ceremonial or other reasons—for their future and that of their family. It is that lack of an unambiguous recognition of the rights of indigenous people that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this country find so disappointing. That is why Commissioner Perkins, speaking on behalf of ATSIC, has asked the coalition to rethink its position.

In the course of the debate on the coalition's proposed amendments, it is true that the Australian media have misunderstood some aspects of the amendments. But whose fault is that? Is it up to the government to explain the intention of the coalition amendments? I would have thought not. Surely that ought to be the responsibility of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer), or the shadow minister, or any one of the frontbench members of the coalition. The fact is that it suits the coalition to have the Australian media misunderstand this issue. It is seeking to give a much wider and very unsavoury appeal to a misunderstanding held by many people in the wider community about this issue of land.

The government, through the whole of the native title debate in 1993 and now in 1994 in relation to this bill, is sending a message to the Australian community. The message is one of justice, one of explanation about the rights of indigenous people, and one of the importance of land to indigenous people and the central place of land in the reconciliation process. If those opposite do not think that is an important view, they should go back and look at the act that set up the reconciliation council. They should look at the first word that is used concerning the commitments of the parliament and the Commonwealth to meeting the aspirations of indigenous people. I know what is there because I wrote it. The first word is `land'. Without land, people cannot establish an economic base. They cannot have housing, communities, or schools. It is the failure of the opposition to give a principled and unrestricted acknowledgment of that important human right for indigenous people that they feel is so disappointing about the coalition's current policy.

We have seen the Leader of the Opposition going around this country and telling Australians about the conditions of indigenous people. He talks about education, housing and employment. This is the same person and the same frontbench that in the last election campaign said they were going to slash programs for indigenous education and other key areas. I will speak more about this later. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a very brief comment on some of the minister's statements because I think he misunderstands the coalition. The coalition fundamentally accepts that land means a great deal to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Australia. We know that it is the central core of their wellbeing and psyche. That is why we supported the reconciliation council being established and land being the central tenet of that reconciliation. That is why we want to support this bill—we supported the motion that the bill be read a second time—but we are seeking to amend it to make it a better bill.

PARA.TAB: I want to comment on amendment No. 4, because I believe it shows the good faith of the coalition on this issue. It broadens, rather than narrows, the opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to benefit under this land scheme. The amendment widens the definition to include individuals, families, communities and trusts rather than corporations. Importantly, it seeks to give priority to, but not make compulsory, the need to ensure that at all times the health, housing and educational needs and the economic wellbeing and viability of ATSI people are catered for. Who could disagree with the aims of the coalition in that area?

I find it extraordinary that the government is opposing the proposed coalition amendments, particularly amendment No. 4. I have looked at the history of Aboriginal affairs in this country and have compared the record of the government with that of the coalition. I remind the government that in 1967 it was the coalition and the Labor Party that supported the 1967 referendum to give recognition to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It was both parties that supported the South Australian Pitjantjatjara land rights bill in 1979, as introduced by David Tonkin. Both parties supported the establishment of the reconciliation council and ATSIC. In the debate the coalition supported ATSIC in principle and wanted to amend the bill to make it better. That was the longest debate in the history of the parliament.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —Order! I draw the honourable member for Sturt back to the amendment before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking to the amendment, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate the opportunity to make my comments because they bear on the general thrust of the coalition's amendments and our intentions. We are acting in good faith in this respect. I believe that in the past the government and the minister have also acted in good faith and have sought to find middle ground so that together we can improve the lot of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dodd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that the honourable member for Leichhardt, who has been in the House all morning, is carrying on like a chipmunk. Quite frankly, I think he might have better work to do in his office.
—Order! The honourable member for Sturt will direct his comments through the chair and come back to the amendment, and the honourable member for Leichhardt will cease interjecting.

—Why is the government not acting in the same good faith as the coalition is on this matter? The answer is that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is seeking to make a political football of Aboriginal affairs. I am sad and disappointed in that, because in the community there is an overwhelming desire to improve the lot of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, who are the most disadvantaged group in society. In the past that has been recognised by the parliament but, since this Prime Minister came to power, it has changed—and it has changed for the worse.

PARA.TAB: What is wrong with widening and broadening this bill so that it allows all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to have the same opportunity to purchase land under this land scheme? What is wrong with trying to bring the basics to Aboriginal people by focusing the attention of the bill on the health, housing, welfare and educational needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people? I thought the government supported those aims and I am sorry that the minister is not supporting them.
