I think that the minister probably is not acting as he would wish to, but is under instruction from his cabinet to force this issue to put the coalition in a position where it cannot support the bill, when in principle it wants to support the bill. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to reply to the remarks of the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne). I commend at least part of what he said because I think he introduced a note of peace making into this debate. No doubt before the debate is over there will be a great deal more forceful language used in the course of the debate, including what I might say.

PARA.TAB: However, I think it is important that we do not give up on the dialogue that often occurs in the course of this parliament. There are some important lessons that can be learnt from history. I was privileged to be in the House when the very first motion on this matter was debated. I saw at that stage what a tragedy it was that the parliament was not able to reach a cross-party agreement on that first motion to recognise the rights of self-determination of indigenous people in this country.

In the course of that debate, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) made a statement that I happen to agree with. I think he was fundamentally wrong in his stand at that time and his views on the broader issue of the resolution, but he said, and I agree:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . bipartisanship—
I would use `cross-party cooperation' in deference to the good Senator Kernot and her colleagues—
is not an end in itself; bipartisanship makes sense only if we are bipartisan about the right policy.

In his very significant book called Sharing the country, Father Frank Brennan makes the point that, if the government had moved to accept the coalition's amendment on that occasion, the cost of bipartisanship would have been a resolution unacceptable to indigenous leadership.

PARA.TAB: I rise particularly on this occasion to inform the House that it is not because of any direction of cabinet or for any other extraneous reason that the government opposes this resolution. It opposes it because we have talked to indigenous leadership and, as we would not accept the coalition's watering down of that historic first motion in this House, nor will we accept this unprincipled amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. My recollection of the introduction of this bill and the speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) was that the amendments were rejected orally by the front bench of the government before they had even been spelled out. I can recall quite clearly that taking place. There was considerable noise and clamour going on. In fact, it was ironic that we listened in silence to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and yet, when the Leader of the Opposition spoke, there was all sorts of interjection and noise and clamour at the time.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) has made a very important point.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! The honourable member for Moore might come back to the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come back to the amendment. I think it is important to recognise that even the government's senior ministers, including the Minister for Human Services and Health, the honourable member for Fremantle, (Dr Lawrence) have interlinked and intertwined the issues of Aboriginal health and land, and together with that go the other issues of education, housing and the economic viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. It is quite clear that, in dealing with these amendments, the government now wishes to reject that interlinking—the same interlinking that we heard about the other day from the Minister for Human Services and Health.
—Double standards.

—It is a double standard. It reflects the modus operandi I spoke about earlier. The government was not intending to support any of our amendments, whatever they may have been, and they were rejected before the government had even heard them, purely and simply because, as the honourable member for Sturt correctly pointed out, it wanted to try to put the opposition in a position where it had to oppose the bill in what it considered to be its less workable, less effective and, of course, in the end, less beneficial form to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders.

PARA.TAB: There is a considerable amount of goodwill in the community and the community is continually seeing images of atrocious housing and health and other aspects of Aboriginal communities throughout Australia. That is something that distresses many Australians considerably. They are distressed because they know that considerable amounts of money have been expended in the past and yet that expenditure failed. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) shakes his head, but his party has been in government now for 11 years and it has failed to make measurable differences, notwithstanding the huge amounts of money that have been spent.

If we are to look at the intertwined issues of land, health, education and housing, we do not have to go very far from the Aboriginal Homes Development Association project in Western Australia. That particular project—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Again on the point of relevance, what has a corporation in Western Australia got to do with the amendment before the chamber?

—On the point of order: throughout this debate on the amendments the minister has made it quite clear that accountability and, as I have mentioned, the intertwining of land, health, housing and education issues are matters that are relevant to the debate of these amendments. I am trying to show quite conclusively, with an example—

—I will allow you to debate the issue in your own time. I take the point made by the honourable member for Leichhardt. It is important that speakers be relevant. It is a very thin line. I think you are trying to make a comparison, but I ask you to bear in mind the need to make your remarks relevant to the amendment.

—What I am trying to say is that the people of Australia want to see outcomes. They desperately want to see success. They are sick of failure; in particular, they are sick of 11 years of failure. They want to see successful outcomes of spending on Aboriginal health, land, education and other Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues. I am pointing out a specific example, an area of importance in that intertwining of land, health, housing and education. An amount of nearly $785,000 was spent by the AHDA and Palencia Pty Ltd in Western Australia, money that came from DEET and ATSIC and elsewhere, and all they did was construct one prefabricated house in Henley Brook, one prefabricated house in Laverton and two granny flats in Mulga Queen via Laverton. To me that is a clear example of where the community wants to see outcomes and that is the purpose of this amendment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I think you will see why we reject this proposal. As was pointed out by Commissioner Ross very well on the PM program on Tuesday evening, Aboriginal people see the issue of access to land as a question of human rights. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) said that these issues of citizenship rights—health, education and housing—are issues which ought to be addressed by state and territory governments, which have the direct responsibility for the delivery of those services.

PARA.TAB: It would be very instructive for the opposition spokespersons at the table to look back at the speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) in the second reading stages of this bill. He made the opposition's intentions very clear. To members of the opposition this is not an issue about land. They see this money being used, never mind what is being said now by the opposition spokesperson, for the improvement of health and housing—basic citizenship rights which are the direct responsibilities of state and territory governments. The Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: Is the government serious about the things that matter—
I emphasise, the things that matter—
including health, education and housing—
The government is serious. It is also serious about addressing the fundamental need in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community for land. That is the principal objective of this bill.

PARA.TAB: Is the opposition saying that the corporation will not take proper account of the wellbeing of Aboriginal people when it is allowing money to be spent on land purchases? What is the opposition saying about this corporation? The real issue with housing, education and health is that the state and territory governments have abrogated their responsibilities. The appalling state of Aboriginal health and housing can be sheeted home directly to the performance of state and territory governments.

For example, the Northern Territory government has reduced its health expenditure on Aborigines. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) portrayed this problem the other day. The minister pointed out that the Northern Territory government reduced expenditure on the Aboriginal health service on Bathurst Island at the same time as it received increased expenditure from the Commonwealth. That Aboriginal health service on Bathurst Island may have to close its doors. That is directly the responsibility of the Northern Territory government. It has nothing to do with this bill. If the opposition were concerned about addressing housing, education and health issues it would go with this government to the state and territory governments and say, `Accept your responsibilities.' To date, it has not.

It is instructive to look at the housing issue in terms of the accounts of the Northern Territory government. This financial year the Commonwealth government is providing to the Northern Territory government $19 million for Aboriginal housing. The Northern Territory government also gets around $850 million in general purpose grants, weighted for disadvantage, to provide services—including housing—to all its citizens. The disadvantage takes account of Aboriginality and dislocation, distance and disadvantage, and yet the contribution of the Northern Territory government this year to housing in Aboriginal communities is exactly $19 million—the amount given to it by the Commonwealth. It has spent none of its own money. Not one cent of that money is being spent by the Northern Territory government on housing in Aboriginal communities, and yet you are telling the community that Aboriginal people, who properly say that these citizenship rights are the responsibility of state and territory governments, should accept the responsibility in this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: I am unclear who the `you' is that the member is referring to. Perhaps he could be clearer on that.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—The honourable member for the Northern Territory is well aware that he needs to direct his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am referring to the loose array of individuals opposite, the opposition. If the opposition is serious about bipartisanship on education, health and housing, it should come to us and say, `Let's have more tied grants for state and territory governments to distribute so that we can ensure that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people get their fair share and that the needs that they have in these areas are properly and adequately addressed.'

PARA.TAB: We should not try to tie such expenditure to the land purchase fund, which is not for that purpose. The purpose of the land purchase fund is clear. Aboriginal people have said that they do not want the land purchase fund sullied by the opposition's proposals to have it tied to providing services in housing, health and education. The opposition ought to understand that the Aboriginal people have made it very clear that the responsibilities for these fundamental human rights, citizenship rights, lie with the states, not with this bill. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like, with your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, to address a matter that was raised by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Snowdon). He spoke about bipartisanship. One of the reasons why we have infiltrated the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill with some thoughts about health, housing, education and economic viability—which are very important—is that, despite all its rhetoric, the government has failed.

PARA.TAB: On the point that the parliamentary secretary raised about bipartisanship, it is possible for us to be bipartisan only if we have not already made up our minds about something. If we are going to have a bipartisan conversation, if we are going to make a bipartisan decision, if we are going to make a bipartisan contribution, then we have to have our minds open. The government has said to us that it has closed its mind on all our amendments. No matter what the amendments are, the government has closed its mind to every single solitary word of every amendment.

You have closed your minds to every single, solitary word of all of the amendments, no matter what they say. Not only have you closed your minds, but you had your minds closed for you. Not only did the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) pre-empt your decision but, if I heard you correctly—and excuse me if I am not addressing my remarks through the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker—the minister said it was the Aboriginal leadership who had made this decision. I think he said words to the effect, `We did not have to make the decision; the Aboriginal leadership made that decision about rejecting these amendments.' We will look it up in a minute.

Let us assume that you were vaguely true. I put it to you that there are a lot of things passed in this House that do not have the total acceptance of the future recipients. The future recipients of many grants and results of legislation passed in this House would like for themselves all sorts of beneficial things that are not granted by legislation from this House. In fact, there are some other responsibilities which you might like to address. Every time you get on your feet you quote what the Aboriginal community wants, but we assume that that is all expressed in the bill. I presume that everything that the Aboriginal community wants is in the bill. You certainly did not discuss the bill with us.

There are some people called taxpayers, and we are responsible for making sure that the taxpayers' money is properly spent. I put it to you, Minister Tickner, that there is no-one else in Australia who is likely to get $500 million to be spent on land acquisition in the next 10 years. You will say, `Well, they're not indigenous,' and I will say, `But some of those people have been totally dispossessed of everything that they ever had: their families, their livelihoods, their land and their freedom. They are in this country, having come here from wherever.'

Some of these people came from Ireland and Scotland and other places 150 years ago, but some have come in the last few months from countries where they had every single thing that they ever owned, including all their families, removed from them; yet those people are aspiring to be taxpayers in this country. So I say to you that there are some other responsibilities that we have to address, not just those of your Aboriginal leadership.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) leaves the chamber, I would like to respond to what he said. The government is, I stress, deeply conscious of its responsibilities to govern for all Australians. It just happens that this is a bill, a quite fundamental and historic bill, addressing the dispossession of indigenous people; so it is only appropriate that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) should consult and negotiate over a prolonged period with the indigenous people, whose human rights were to be enshrined in the proposed legislation which is now being debated in the parliament.

PARA.TAB: However, there is of course a much wider agenda of not only accountability to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Australia in communities and towns right across this country but also public accountability to all Australians. When we move to talk about other aspects of this bill that impinge upon those issues of public accountability, I will list in detail the very tight regime of accountability that this bill seeks to impose upon the expenditure of funds, upon the disclosure of information and upon the management practices of the Indigenous Land Corporation. No-one can suggest with any credibility that those public accountability provisions to the parliament and to the broader Australian community are not enshrined in this bill, because they certainly are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am pleased that I have the call. You would like me to have the call too, because I have to go into that chair and relieve you as soon as I finish speaking. I rise as a result of the invitation of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), who several interventions ago asked for somebody to please tell him who on the government side had actually made some sort of claim about our wanting to have a hospital or a school, or something of that nature, on land purchased under the fund.

PARA.TAB: The minister responded to the shadow minister when she refuted that particular suggestion. The minister then said, `Well, I have been here for almost all of the debate, and I have not heard anybody say that.' I know the minister will be highly delighted and absolutely pleased, because he is a searcher after truth, that immediately after he said that I accessed Hansard on the parliamentary database. I would like, in the interest of accuracy, to scotch once and for all the erroneous suggestion that some member of the opposition has said that land to be purchased under this fund must have a school, a hospital or a health service on it. The member who made the reference was the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding). He commenced speaking at 12.29 p.m. yesterday. I will not read the whole speech from Hansard, but he said, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: This is a land bill and the purpose of the fund is to acquire land for Aboriginal people . . . The funds are not all that extensive. The opposition is proposing that we dilute those funds. Those opposite say—
this is where he is putting a false quote into the mouths of those opposite him—

`We don't want to know about other funds or other legislation which might be relevant in these areas of education, housing and health. We insist that when you look at the question of land, you look at the question of health, housing and education.'
That was not what we said. The honourable member went on to say:

That sounds all right if we applied those standards to everybody in Western Australia or the Northern Territory who is a land developer. Do we say to a land developer who is using private funds, `Before you even acquire the land, let alone develop it, we have to be satisfied that the land is in close proximity to a school, which will deal with the problems of children, and that there is a level of medical service clearly and demonstrably available'? Of course we do not.

It is absolutely true that I and other members of the coalition are deeply concerned about the issues of health, education, employment and housing for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We have, it is true, raised those issues in connection with this fund. But it has to be pointed out that at no time—to my knowledge or, certainly, according to the Hansard record—has any member of the opposition made the rather silly suggestion that before people can buy land out of this fund there should be a school, a hospital or a health service. That is a nonsense, and it originated with the member for Melbourne Ports.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure what the outcome of the contribution made by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) will be. I would observe, however, that at that particular point of the debate the amendments that have now been circulated were not before the House and were not available to members.
—You rejected them before you saw them.

—The honourable member interjects to say that members of the government rejected the amendments before they saw them. Let me, once and for all, categorically refute that proposition. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) left this chamber after the Leader of the Opposition's speech and immediately gave a press conference. At that press conference, he quite publicly—the transcript is available, if the honourable gentleman would like to read it—made it clear that the government would consider each and every one of the opposition amendments. That is what we have done. Indeed, I made the same point myself, both publicly and privately.

PARA.TAB: I would like to return to the amendment before the chair. I would like to pose to the coalition a further reason why the proposed amendment is inadvisable. Remember, this is a fund directed towards the acquisition of land. It is a major social justice measure. It is the government's second stage response to the historic High Court decision in the Mabo case.

I put it to the honourable member that there could not be anything more important to many Aboriginal people than to have absolute control over sacred sites—sites of great spiritual significance. Of course, the spiritual values of indigenous people are not things that merely the government recognises. I am sure there are a great many members of the opposition who respect them. Might I say that those in the broader spectrum of Australian churches and religious faiths, to their very great credit, also acknowledge and respect the spiritual beliefs of indigenous people.

I put it to the honourable member for Cowper that this question of access to, and control through ownership of, a site of great significance is something that the board of the corporation would properly have great regard to. Yet in the amendment that is before us we are told that the issues that the board is supposed to focus on are health, housing, educational needs or economic viability. I just give this as merely one example of the inadvisability of this particular amendment.

As I have already said in the course of this debate, the amendment is all about politics, and it is the politics that the government rejects and indigenous people reject absolutely. Indigenous people want an unambiguous, ungrudging recognition of their human rights to land. They do not want the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) to trample all over that right and to send all the wrong messages to the wider Australian community about their aspirations to land. That perhaps more than anything else is why I am so deeply personally opposed to this amendment. It sends all the wrong messages to the Australian people, and the opposition fails to give unambiguous recognition of the essential and pivotal importance of land to indigenous people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) to be here to listen to my reply to his statement, but unfortunately the minister is moving around the chamber. I would like to answer him—through you, Mr Deputy Speaker—by saying that the coalition unambiguously recognises the importance of land to Aboriginal people: the importance of land in their traditions and in their culture, and the importance of land rights to Aboriginal people. But what I simply want to point out, in reply to something the minister said, is that perhaps he does not know the things that affect health. We pointed out earlier that returning traditional land to indigenous people would be one instance of improving the health of a community. Health has a wide definition, Minister.
—Ah!
—Minister, did you not know the factors that improve health? Did you know that unemployment affects health; that people who are unemployed are less healthy—
—I do not know whether the minister knows that, but I know it, and you will address your remarks to the chair.

—I would like the minister to think of the wider context of health, so that, in addressing those issues of returning land to traditional people, he also addresses the health of those people. In that way the focus would not be taken off what the minister said was so important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am simply going to respond to the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) by making absolutely clear the great importance the government places on issues of health, employment, housing, and economic development. I remind the House that in the course of the social justice package discussions the indigenous people of this country are going to put to the government for consideration some very serious propositions as to how those matters can be more adequately addressed. The government's real commitment to these issues is shown by the nature of the programs that we have put in place in all these areas—most of which, might I say, have been opposed by the coalition at every turn.

PARA.TAB: I want to give a very clear commitment on the part of the government: we will not be cutting public expenditure on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander programs. Furthermore, I give a commitment that we will find even better ways to spend the money, and a further commitment that in doing that we will seek to work with indigenous people, because we believe that, when these programs are put in the hands of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people themselves, when they are in the driving seat of change, the programs work. I ask a very direct question of the coalition. Is the shadow minister, the honourable member for Hindmarsh, prepared to give a commitment like the one I have just given that any future coalition government will not cut programs in indigenous affairs across the whole ambit of those programs?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has widened the debate somewhat on amendment No. 4—
—Do not be encouraged by that to do the same.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I hope you will extend to me the same courtesy as has been extended to the minister.
—I will do my best.

—The minister, in his address earlier, talked about consultation and in his second reading speech said that the government had sought the views of peak indigenous, farming, environmental, industry and church groups, had had meetings with Aboriginal representatives and had reached a measure of consensus on the main features of the bill. He also sought the views of premiers and chief ministers, and colleagues on the other side of the House. I am interested in knowing exactly what consultation took place. I do not think there was that sort of consultation at all.

PARA.TAB: The minister again raised the question of accountability. He described it as being tight enough in the original terms of the bill. Yet earlier, when he was debating the provisions of the second amendment, he said that the provisions were more or less similar to those in relation to ATSIC. He argued his case against amendment No. 2 on the basis of not needing to make accountability any tighter than that applicable to ATSIC. Let me say in answer that even a football club with a federal grant would be required to be as accountable as we would like the corporation to be under the amended bill.

In relation to accountability and outcomes in housing, health and education, again I refer back to the Aboriginal Housing Development Association and Palencia Pty Ltd project in Western Australia, which received a total of just under $785,000. They constructed a prefab house in Henley Brook, a prefab house in Laverton and two granny flats in Mulga Queen via Laverton. Let me talk about the actual acquittal of these moneys. For project 0042689C, which is at 92/1273 in their records, they received $56,145. DEET contributed $28,073, of which $25,080 was acquitted. That left a shortfall of $2,993. ATSIC's money was unacquitted, and that was $28,072. For project 0045569J, 92/1303, $29,392 from ATSIC was totally unacquitted. For project 0042692H, 92/1272, the amount was $22,280. DEET contributed $11,140, of which $9,291 was acquitted, leaving a shortfall of $1,849. The $11,140 from ATSIC was unacquitted. The total acquitted was $34,371; unacquitted, $73,446.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the honourable member does have a point he is going to make about accountability.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, what I am trying to show here is that there is clearly a great need for increased accountability, because in the end the community, in supporting the intent of an Aboriginal land fund, would want to see viable, visible and significant outcomes as a result. That is the point of the opposition's amendment No. 4. It is to ensure that, in the granting of land, these particular issues in relation to projects are addressed. I cannot see how any reasonable person could oppose the intent of the amendment. After all, we are talking about $500 million of taxpayers' money. I have said already that there is a considerable amount of goodwill in the community towards this particular concept, but in the end the community wants desperately to see success. People want to see it work, and they have seen over the last 11 years quite considerable failure on the part of the federal government after expending huge amounts of money in the key areas of housing, health, educational needs and economic viability of communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) quite correctly drew attention to the fact that some purchases of land could be of spiritual or cultural significance to Aboriginal people and that the proposed amendment of the opposition made no reference to that, the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) looked very closely at the terms of the amendment to confirm whether or not that was correct. Of course it was. It was interesting then that the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), attempted to squirm out from underneath in connection with this very pertinent point that the minister made, saying that she and the opposition recognise that spiritual sites and cultural factors are important to the health of Aborigines.

PARA.TAB: This proposed amendment says, in part, that the provision of land will have regard at all times:

SPEECH.PARA: to the need to ensure that the health, housing or educational needs or economic viability of aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and communities will be improved as a result of the acquisition . . .

I emphasise the repeated use of the word `or' in that statement. There is no reference there to the point that the minister made about the importance of spiritual sites to Aboriginal people and the fact that some of the money from the Indigenous Land Corporation could be provided for that purpose.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that, given the observations of the honourable member for Moore about the application and acquittal of funds for some projects, the honourable member should now be supporting the proposition that the Indigenous Land Corporation should ensure that the health, housing, educational needs or economic viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will be improved.

I do not know whether that proposed amendment suggests that the ensuring should take place before the approval or as a result of the use of that land. What it seems to suggest is that the Indigenous Land Corporation would need to undertake some type of legally acceptable scientific impact statement which would be acceptable to the members of the opposition before any funds were made available.

While the claim is being made that in some way those concerns are not accommodated within the legislation, proposed section 191B of the legislation states that the Indigenous Land Corporation is established to assist indigenous people to acquire and manage land:

SPEECH.PARA: so as to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders.

It is provided for within the legislation at the present time. That is the whole raison d'etre for this legislation. It is ludicrous to suggest that that type of stupid expression needs to be written in so that the Indigenous Land Corporation will have to prepare some sort of impact statement related to those particular provisions so that not necessarily the members of the opposition but some of their redneck mates in the community will have the opportunity to assess the adequacy of the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, while I do not wish to interrupt the member's speech, I do regard the word `redneck' as offensive and I would ask him to withdraw it.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, if the honourable member believes that I used that word to refer to him, and he feels sensitive about it, I will certainly withdraw it, but I did no such thing.

—On the question of unparliamentary language, Mr Deputy Speaker: the member is trying to be clever, but in fact he was quite clearly referring to friends of members of the opposition in an attempt to smear us all.
—There is no point of order.

—In case there is any question about how the community generally relates to the importance of land to Aboriginal people, I draw attention to a comment that was made by Dr Brendan Nelson the day after the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) introduced this legislation on 30 June. Dr Nelson had criticised the coalition's stand on the previous day. He said that land ownership was central to improving Aboriginal health. Later on I will give some indications of similar comments made by other people as well. (Time expired)

—It is a shame when the debate in this chamber is reduced to the affected reasoning of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). I remind government members about the supposed purpose of their own bill, which is to improve the lot of Aboriginal people. On this side we certainly accept and support that sentiment but totally consistent with that sentiment is this amendment that we are supposed to be debating here today. It simply says that, when pursuing a policy of acquiring interest in land, except where the circumstances make the pursuit of such a policy impractical or inadvisable, there should be regard at all times `to the need to ensure'—having regard is hardly something which the government could surely object to—`that the health, housing or educational needs or economic viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and communities will be improved as a result of the acquisition of land or interests in land to which those persons may have access'.

PARA.TAB: Surely that is the purpose of the bill. If the government were at all accommodating in trying to get some sort of bipartisan support in this, I would have thought it would have regarded it as a fairly innocuous and supportive amendment and would have accepted it. But the government members are jumping to their feet and objecting to it on the most spurious grounds. If you object to that, it really makes you wonder what the bill is all about. It makes me wonder what the government's agenda really is. It seems that it just wants to oppose what we are putting up. We are only trying to assist it in getting a better bill.

We are talking in effect of $24 million extra on top of the $21 million that ATSIC already spends. If any Australian looked at the land situation with Aboriginal people in Australia now, they would see there is ordinary land which Aborigines can buy like anybody else; there is land rights land which the states administer; there is the ATSIC land which already exists; there is Mabo land or native title land; and now we are going to have land acquisition fund land.

In many cases, despite this land which has been acquired for Aboriginal people, Aborigines are still living in the most appalling circumstances, which is regrettable. Members on both sides of the chamber agree that that is the case. In fact, in many places, Aborigines are living in the worst conditions where they own the most land. So before we start rushing in to acquire more land we should put some sensible legislation in place, such as this amendment advocates, to ensure that the best use is made of the land for Aboriginal people. That is all we are asking for: to have regard `to the need to ensure that the health, housing or educational needs or economic viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will be improved'.

Economic viability is something that is being totally overlooked here. It is very important not just for the Aboriginal people and what they will get from the land where it is appropriate but for their credibility and the goodwill that they will engender under the reconciliation that we are supposed to be moving towards with the rest of the Australian people.

In that regard, I would urge the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) to look again at the wording of this amendment and to accept it. If he does not accept it, he should at least come forward with some reasonable arguments as to why not. It just seems to me that the mind of the minister is made up. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was of the mind right from the beginning to reject it outright. I find it a very regrettable situation and I would hope that the minister would reconsider.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some initial comments in relation to comments made in earlier debate by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne). He seemed to criticise me for being in this chamber all morning. I take very seriously my duties in this parliament and my representation of my constituents in the electorate of Leichhardt—
—I criticised you for behaving like a monkey and being in the chamber all the time.
—Order!

—The remarks are in the Hansard. I proudly represent Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Cape York Peninsula, the Torres Strait, Yarrabah and Cairns. This debate is very important to those constituents, and I am very proud to be here to participate in this debate.

PARA.TAB: To get back to the debate, I must admit that the honourable member for Sturt did make a relatively constructive contribution this morning: he did talk about the history of bipartisanship in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. That is perhaps in the past, but he did talk about bipartisanship. That reference was highlighted by the contributions that came afterwards in which the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) talked about this government's failure and then the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) referred to 11 years of failure, presumably of this government.

If there is a failure—and there are problems in health and housing and all those other areas in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities; there is no doubt about that—it is not a failure of a government; it is a failure of 200 years of European settlement in this country to which governments have contributed. If the honourable member for Sturt is right and there has been bipartisanship, it must be a failure on the part of all of us. We cannot both be right. If there has been bipartisanship, we must all share the failure. I accept that.

The minister quite rightly asked the shadow spokesperson, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), whether she would give a guarantee in this House that there would be no more cutbacks to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. That is quite an appropriate question in view of the Fightback policy with its 10 per cent cut. So it is a very appropriate question. I cannot remember whether the honourable member for Hindmarsh has contributed to this debate, but she certainly has not been able to give that undertaking nor, I suspect, could she do so today. I do not think she has the power to do that. Nevertheless, I would suggest that that is the most pertinent question in relation to this amendment because it is obviously important that issues such as health, housing and economic independence are addressed. However, they will not be addressed by this coded amendment.

A lot has been said here today about bipartisanship. I have actually said in another debate—and I know that the honourable minister was present and made some very kind comments in agreement—but I will say it again that, if we want bipartisanship on these issues, this silly coded amendment should be withdrawn and the opposition members should sit down with government members to work out a bipartisan policy on these issues.

This debate is not just about expenditure on the part of the Commonwealth. It is about expenditure by the states, it is about expenditure by local government and it is about access and equity to local government and state and federal programs. It is about the very issues that were addressed by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) when he talked about the states' responsibility for these areas. Under the constitution of Australia, which you all refer to so often in this place, the responsibility for these issues lies with the states. Who controls the states of Australia, if you want to take a snapshot of history in 1994? Five out of six states are run by Liberal and National Party governments.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! I think the honourable member for Leichhardt might take a snapshot of the amendment we are talking to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am talking to the amendment. I am talking about those very things in the amendment, such as health, housing and education needs, which are the responsibility of state governments in Australia. I repeat: if you want to take that snapshot of history, most of the states have Liberal and National Party governments.

PARA.TAB: I said earlier that there is a failure, but it is not a failure of this government. It is much more complex than that. That is just a silly partisan point and, really, when you look at it, it is just absurd. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me first thank the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) for his comic turn, which I am sure added some light relief to this debate. I now turn to some more serious matters. I take up what the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) so aptly mentioned, which has not been mentioned yet in this debate. I refer to the appalling conditions in which Aboriginal people live in many communities. Yes, the members of the government are right; I am new to this shadow portfolio; I have been in it for only two months. But I have been out to these communities where I have seen men living in tin humpies half the size of a car, where the temperature falls to—5 degrees in winter and 50 degrees plus in summer. In some communities, almost all the children have 80 per cent deafness and these kids are suffering from diabetes and rheumatic disease. One woman sat on the floor and, crying, said to me, `How can you let Aboriginal children live like this? How would you like your children to live like this?'
—What is the point? Every one of us could make this speech. What is the point?

—You do not see the point, Minister. Mr Deputy Speaker, may I note that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) said, `What is the point?' We are discussing an amendment that addresses health. It says that when land is purchased let us have a look at what we are going to achieve and, in buying the land, make sure there are things that can be achieved on that land. Obviously, that does not exclude traditional land because I can see—and the coalition acknowledges it—that purchasing traditional land will improve in many cases, perhaps in most cases, the health of those Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: What we have seen in this debate is the absolute desperation of the government in trying to find some reason to reject what is extraordinarily sensible and what was actually referred to me as a motherhood amendment. It was pointed out to me, not by the minister but by somebody in the press gallery who had nothing to do with it and who read it and said, `But this is a motherhood amendment. What do you mean by this? It is simply motherhood. Nobody could object to it.' That is, nobody in their right mind, except the minister who today has revealed once and for all that he is not interested in bipartisanship, and that his calls for bipartisanship have been nothing more than hypocrisy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —More personal attacks and more erroneous statements, but I intend to reply with matters of substance. The last time I rose to my feet I gave an unambiguous undertaking on behalf of the federal Labor government, and that was that we would not cut public expenditure in key areas of social justice that impact on indigenous people. We will not be cutting programs that affect people's health, that affect people's employment, that affect education—

—I rise on the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, with respect to the minister speaking to the amendment. I understand that we have traversed very broad issues on this amendment. However, I would have thought that funding, the Fightback policy which was raised earlier, cuts and so on are really quite irrelevant to the amendments moved by the coalition. I would ask you to bring him to the amendment.
—There is no point of order. The minister is in order.

—I am going to be quite brief about this, but let me repeat that I have given an on-the-record, public commitment about our ongoing stand in relation to addressing those fundamental issues that the shadow minister just spoke about. We will not be cutting programs in this area. The reason I raise that point is that the coalition cannot give that commitment, because the hard men—and they are all men—on the frontbench of the Liberal Party are going to do what they did last time when it comes to proposed expenditure cuts. That is, they are going to target Aboriginal employment, like they did last time; they are going to target Aboriginal housing, like they did last time; and the same thing applies to Aboriginal education. All this phoney, purported caring about these issues is not matched by the substantive policy.
—Order! Regrettably, the minister is not being particularly relevant to the amendment this time.

—The point is that I have given a public commitment on the record; it is matched by the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in an intergovernmental agreement. Let the opposition match that commitment.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask that the minister address the point of order on which you previously ruled.

—I believe that this amendment has been exhaustively canvassed. I spent the first three or four interventions making it clear why this amendment was so offensive to indigenous people, and why it sought to shift the priority and the essential message of the fund away from land and onto other issues. That is why indigenous people have rejected it. It is why the government rejects it and, indeed, the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has done the parliament a service by directing our attention to what is in proposed section 191B. We continue to reject this amendment for all the very good reasons we have given in the course of this debate.

—I do not want to prolong the debate any longer than it has been prolonged already. I would like to bring it to a conclusion. But I noticed that the member for Charlton was getting to his feet when it was the opposition's turn to speak. I would like to deal with some of the comments previously made by the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) and now by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), who demanded that the opposition make clear its policy on cutbacks to funding for the Aboriginal affairs area.

PARA.TAB: How could this possibly be relevant to amendment No. 4, which seeks to ensure that appropriations under the land fund go to the health, welfare, education and wellbeing of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders? It is simply a political stunt on the part of the government, and it should be ashamed of itself that it is reducing what are amendments made in good faith to that sort of level.

I would also like to comment on bipartisanship, which is being traversed constantly in this debate. Bipartisanship was mentioned by the member for Leichhardt, but bipartisanship is not some bullying, one-sided bipartisanship on the part of the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I apologise for the interruption, but I do not think the time clock is working.
—It was, because I was watching it. The honourable member for Sturt's time has expired.
—I did not realise the honourable member for Sturt had spoken for five minutes. I think there was some fault with the clock.
—There was, was there? In that case, I thank the honourable member for Charlton for drawing that to the chair's attention, and the honourable member for Sturt may continue.
—I was in conclusion in any event. I was in conclusion because there are many other amendments to be dealt with.

—Order! Resume your seat. What are we doing with this clock? How much time does the honourable member for Sturt have left? We will start again with two minutes left for the honourable member for Sturt.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. We have sorted out a very technical and important point in the debate! We have had a lot of discussion on this, but I am sure two minutes is not long enough to change the mind of the member for Charlton, although I have changed his mind on issues in the past. I just wanted to comment very briefly on the bipartisanship which has been touted and the bipartisanship that has worked so well in the past, particularly under the Fraser government.

—Order! When you first started talking, you complained bitterly about people not being able to speak on the terms of the amendment and not sticking to the clause. With bipartisanship, you are breaching the strictures that you made yourself. I invite you to continue and pay attention to the content of the amendment.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I understood in this debate that we had been responding to comments being made by the other side and, therefore, I was responding to outrageous allegations being levied against the coalition.
—I will not debate it with you, but I will make the point that if everybody who sat in this chair during this debate had strictly observed the standing orders very little would have been said at all.
—Fortunately, Mr Deputy Speaker, you are one of the better occupants of the chair.
—Flattery will get you nowhere. Please continue.

—If you had been in the chair for the entire debate, I am sure it would have been handled very differently. I conclude by saying that the coalition moves these amendments, particularly amendment No. 4, in good faith. It goes to the heart of the coalition's position as to why we support the bill in principle and seek to amend it. I remind the government of a similar role taken by the opposition over the ATSIC amendments which, when completed, were roundly supported by both sides. I urge the government to reconsider its opposition to our amendments on this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of points that I want to make in response to some of the observations that have been made by members of the opposition on the debate on this particular amendment to the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994. I preface my response with the observation that I believe that their comments were relevant, and for that reason I believe that my comments will be within the spirit of the purposes of this discussion.

PARA.TAB: The member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, when she opened her consideration of the amendments referred to this amendment as one of the key amendments of the opposition. I agree with that. I think it is a key amendment, in that this amendment really has the effect of tearing the substance out of the particular purposes for which this legislation has been introduced. The primary purpose is to make funds available to Aboriginal people who will not and cannot benefit under the provisions of the Native Title Act so that they can get access to land for a whole range of reasons, all of which will be relevant to their general welfare.

When the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) was participating earlier in this debate he said words to this effect: `It is absolutely true that we, the opposition, are concerned about the health, housing and education and other social conditions of Aborigines.' The member for Hindmarsh, in her third contribution to the debate on this amendment, said that she was conscious of and had personally observed the appalling conditions that Aborigines live in. We have to measure the genuineness of the concern of members of the opposition and the possible rhetoric which they have used in this debate against their record.

The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has quite correctly drawn our attention to the fact that a central part of the Fightback package was to tear $90 million a year out of Aboriginal funding. This particular legislation is provided for the purpose of securing additional land for Aboriginal people in Australia, and more suitable land for economic viability purposes as well. In real terms, the amount of money that would be involved in the fund from now until the 10-year cut-off of government injections of public money is about $45 million. At the time of the last election the opposition went to the people of Australia with a package, with a formula, with a blueprint for government which involved ripping $90 million out of Aboriginal funding—for health, for housing, for education, for social conditions, for employment generation and for all of the purposes to which those funds are being applied for Aboriginal people. That $90 million is twice the provision which exists in this legislation for the purchase of Aboriginal land.

Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I say to members of the opposition: how do you expect us to really respond to what we see as a basic insincerity in the position that you adopt? Do you really believe that when you tell us that you are concerned and feel deeply for the health, the education, the housing, the general social conditions of Aboriginals that you are genuine, when last election you said you would rip an extra $90 million out of the Aboriginal funding? How do you expect us to respond?

Other observations have been made by people such as the Reverend Harry Herbert, from the Uniting Church, who very clearly identified the importance of land for the general welfare of Aboriginals. Archbishop Peter Hollingworth said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is an issue of justice in there and I think we all need to recognise that, you know, in the end, you achieve justice and human dignity for Aboriginal people if there's some greater opportunity to achieve land rights.
Archbishop Hollingworth knows, as we know, that that is the purpose of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I relate part of my comments to those made by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). He made the observation, which was noted by numerous people on his side as a demonstration of our economic and social perfidy, that under Fightback we were going to take $90 million out of the budget for Aboriginal affairs. That is correct. It is also correct that we were going to reduce the budget of every single department of state by an equivalent amount of about 10 per cent.

PARA.TAB: I say that because our objective was to make those decisions across the board because we believed then that they were the right decisions for Australia, particularly in view of the national debt, which continues to grow inexorably month by month. At least that point demonstrates that the direction we were aiming to take Australia, had the people chosen us, was basically correct. I do not wish to see any member of the government stand up in here and try to make a virtue out of necessity because of the weaknesses in the government's own legislation that has been brought before this House. To argue that somehow or other we have deliberately selected Aboriginal affairs for a reduction in government expenditure is simply not the fact. I want that clearly on the record.

We were again accused by the honourable member for Charlton of perfidy in our approach and, according to him, our apparent lack of concern for Aboriginal welfare in the wider context, not only regarding land but also housing, education and welfare. I have no doubt—I sincerely hope I am telling the truth when I make this observation—that the honourable member for Charlton has also visited Aboriginal settlements in the Northern Territory, and that he has been to outstations and seen the conditions in which many of those people live. I am sure he would agree with me that, generally, those conditions are appalling. We try to do the right thing by Aboriginal welfare by saying, `You now have access to land and you, of course, have the right to live where you like on that land.' That is the general philosophical position. It is a position chosen by the government and it is a position shared by the opposition.

But let no side of this parliament be so naive as to suggest that, having accepted a principle, it necessarily follows that the application of that principle in terms of the lifestyle of the people who live there is in any sense satisfactory to them or to us. Time and time again, when I was shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, I would go to outstations and the people would say to us, `You have given us the land, but look at the way we have to live.' I would be left speechless. Perhaps my colleagues on the government side, under those circumstances, could have come out with a little fib here and a little fib there. The truth of the matter is that those people were desperate then and, sadly, some years later, many of them are still desperate.

We have been trying to emphasise that, when a decision is made to purchase land, irrespective of where it may be, side by side with that decision consideration must also be given to the conditions which will exist for the people who want to live on that land. If giving them land means that their access to education, their access to health, their access to any possibility of employment or prospects are significantly diminished, then obviously commonsense tells you that funds need to be made available to prop up the purchase of the land with the necessary resources to ensure that, having moved onto that land, that community has something on which it can base its economic and social wellbeing. That is the essence of our approach. It is nothing that we are ashamed of; it is simply commonsense.

For this government to come in here and for the minister to say after a five-minute examination of our legislation that he is dismissing it out of hand simply misses the point that we have been making all along. Why does he dismiss it? Apparently it is because we did not talk to various Aboriginal leaders. That simply suggests that legislation from the government side is not drafted by the government but exclusively by Aboriginal leaders that tell the government what they want. We have been trying to make the point that, in too many cases, individual Aboriginal communities and families in those communities—whether they be small families or extended families—are being left out of the equation because they do not have political strength. Those people who shout the loudest are the ones that the government listens to, and not necessarily to the ordinary Aboriginal people whom we want to help. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two points I want to make. Firstly, I congratulate the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) for again putting the opposition on the spot and for making it very clear that the cuts in Fightback will impact harshly on the education, employment and housing of indigenous people. Secondly, there has been no response from the shadow minister to match the government's commitment to maintain expenditure in these areas. With the greatest of respect, she and the coalition ought to be saying, `Let us have a difference of opinion about how programs are managed and how programs are directed. Let us quarantine expenditure in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs from cuts because it is the pre-eminent issue of social justice in this country.' That is why we differ from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). We do not believe in across-the-board cuts; we believe in social justice. That is our guiding light.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think honourable members opposite liked what I had to say then. To make a further, quite separate and distinct point, the honourable member for Bradfield made a very important point about the need for long-term planning in relation to providing infrastructure and services on land which is purchased by the land fund or which is currently purchased by ATSIC. That is certainly something that has been recognised by the whole parliament in the passage of the ATSIC Act, the preparation of regional plans and the placing of the decision making power in the hands of indigenous people. The point that I wish to make is that the government has reinforced its commitment to doing just that by ensuring that two members of the board of the fund are going to be members of ATSIC. Quite obviously, there will have to be a great deal of cooperative work undertaken between ATSIC and the board of the fund.

PARA.TAB: There is another reason why this amendment is so poorly judged. I have a very easy and simple illustration. It often happens that areas of great importance to Aboriginal people are being held by non-indigenous people in private ownership for a great period of time. It is land that may be of enormous spiritual importance to those people. As members from the more rural areas will know, perhaps once in a decade or once in 50 years that property gets on the market. What on earth would a responsible board of a land fund do in those circumstances? Would it have regard to this amendment? It would be moving with the speed of light to try to get an option on the property to secure it for indigenous people. That is why we are calling it a land fund. Sure, these other issues have to be addressed, but let us not pretend that, with one stroke of the pen, there will immediately be a school, housing and other infrastructure on that land. The land has to be acquired first. It just amazes me and, I am afraid to say, it makes indigenous people very angry that this very simple concept cannot be grasped.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make one further contribution to this question of the cuts proposed in the Aboriginal affairs budget by the coalition prior to the last election. Putting aside the fact that it is ancient history, let me again emphasise that this government has built an Aboriginal industry with a cast of thousands and $90 million could have been taken out of the administration and the bureaucracy of Aboriginal affairs without the slightest impact on services or on the delivery of better facilities and opportunities for Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: It is an area that has been abysmally overwhelmed by expensive bureaucracy. Those sorts of things have been a part of the reason that the government's performance in this area has been so poor. I think it is really hypocritical of the government to be drawing attention to proposed cuts while it squanders so much money on needless administration, setting up corporations and getting in the way of Aboriginals advancing their own cause.

I might add one other line, and that is that the coalition Fightback package was a two-sided document. There were also very substantial cuts in taxation and other areas which would have saved ATSIC and other Aboriginal organisations considerable amounts of money. So to talk in terms of those cuts showing a lack of commitment to Aborigines is an unjust and unwarranted comment.

The government has so far opposed opposition amendments which would have allowed land funds to flow to individuals to buy land, to give genuine land rights to individuals. The government has opposed proposals to make the land council more accountable and to recover funds that had been wrongly applied. Now the government is proposing to oppose a requirement that this fund be used for such worthwhile purposes as assisting health, housing and education needs and the economic viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and communities. It seems to me that this suggests that there is not much left of an Aboriginal affairs policy when you are not prepared to be supportive of those sorts of noble objectives.

That is clearly what the opposition has in mind in ensuring that the land fund is used productively and used wisely, genuinely to benefit Aborigines and not just to accumulate vacant acres that are not used for any purpose. The real intent is that the fund should be used productively so that those acquisitions can really benefit the Aboriginal people. This amendment and others that have preceded it are important in the way in which they propose to deliver responsibility, attachment and ownership to particular individuals so that people have responsibility for the land that is entrusted to them.

I recall vividly the situation in the Cherbourg Aboriginal community in my own electorate where for many years the council, which owns most of the houses, did not really bother too much about collecting rent. Rent payments became optional. So there was never any money then to spend on maintenance of the houses and, naturally, they fell into a state of disrepair. People had no responsibility for the houses because no-one ever bothered following up and collecting the rent. A new council was elected and for the first time it started to evict people who did not pay their rent. It is remarkable what a change of attitude occurred. People started feeling responsible for their homes; they knew they were theirs and that, when they paid their rent, there would be a return on that money through improvements to the housing. There was certainly a new sense of responsibility towards those homes.

How much better that would be if those people could actually buy the houses themselves and that, instead of their being owned by the community council, the corporation, the land council or the other tiers of bureaucracy being established by the government, individuals could acquire those homes, make them their own property and care for them for themselves and for their families. That would certainly aid their health, their education needs and their prospects for the future. This ought to be encouraged. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been sitting in my room watching these proceedings on the television and I must say that I was drawn to come back down here after listening to the last two speakers from the opposition. It was astounding to hear the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) get up here and wear, with a badge of honour, the proposals for Fightback. It was also astounding to hear the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), who has just spoken, say that $90 million could be cut out of Aboriginal administration and it would not be felt.

PARA.TAB: Frankly, what this illustrates is the absolute paucity of understanding in the opposition about these issues. I am surprised particularly by the honourable member for Bradfield—I know he has got a bit of a reputation around the place for what he does in his spare time—that the opposition is actually saying to us that there is room for us to cut $90 million and that this was going to be a cut across the board.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) told us in his speech on the second reading about the absolutely abysmal state of affairs with regard to Aboriginal health, housing and education. He says this on the one hand, but he and his colleagues still defend propositions which would worsen the situation. I cannot quite see that there is any credibility in that argument at all.

Then the opposition members are saying that the responsibility of the commission—the body to administer the funds—ought to be to look after improvements in the standard of Aboriginal health and housing. Can they not see that there is an ultimate contradiction in their argument? The purpose of this exercise is to purchase property—land—and it might well be that the purchase of some land might serve a productive purpose in producing fat cattle, for example. It might have a very useful social purpose.

After all, the guts of this issue is Aboriginal land—the social, psychological, spiritual and cultural importance of land to Aboriginal people. This aspect seems to be totally lost on many members of the opposition. They then try to tie in the proposals in this land fund bill with improvement to the health, education and housing status of Aboriginal people, while at the same time defending propositions which would have cut the amount of money available across all portfolios and within the Aboriginal affairs portfolio to provide those services. You have to wonder about them, do you not? How can you take them seriously?

What they should be doing, as I have said previously in this debate, if they have serious concern about Aboriginal housing status and health and education, is to go to the state and territory governments and ask them what the hell they have been doing. Opposition members should sheet the responsibility home to where it rests and not try to transfer it to an Aboriginal organisation, the function of which is to purchase land.
As a person who has lived and worked in remote communities for many years, I have experienced the results of this lack of service. We must ask why it is that in the Northern

SPEECH.PARA: Territory, for example, the education attainment levels of Aboriginal people, in comparison with non-Aboriginal people, are that if you are a non-Aboriginal person you have an 80 per cent chance of finishing year 12, and if you are an Aboriginal person you have a 10 per cent chance, yet during the last couple of years the Northern Territory government has taken the absurd position of decreasing class sizes in urban schools at the expense of bush schools where it has increased class sizes and withdrawn support staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they've got a beautiful new parliament.

—A great parliament—$110 million. Those are the priorities. The Northern Territory government spends $110 million on a parliament, but there is no increased funding and no additional resources going to Aboriginal health, housing or education. In fact, as demonstrated by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) this week, the Northern Territory government has been pulling back its own resources from those things. As I said this morning, not one cent of its money is being spent on housing. There is no doubt that it supported the proposition which has been put forward this morning—by the last two speakers, at least—that would see additional cuts in expenditure from the budgets referred to in the amendment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am glad you polished your glasses. Desperate times call for desperate remedies, and this debate from the coalition is a pretty desperate remedy for desperate times. I note too that none of us has been jumping up about the necessity for people to stay on the amendments. The comments have ranged far and wide, and I do want to make reference to the comments of the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss).

PARA.TAB: The amendment that we are debating at the moment goes to the very heart of this bill. As Senator Cheryl Kernot said, the position of the opposition amounts to gutting the fund. This is not the government's assessment; this is the view of the Australian Democrats. I would have hoped that the Liberal Party and the National Party would have taken notice because, at the end of the day, the numbers in the Senate will decide this matter. What did the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) say? We are not sure what he is saying at the moment—I think he has run for cover—but he said on 30 August:

SPEECH.PARA: We are determined to fight for our amendments which will broaden the focus of the fund and increase accountability.
If the Government rejects the goals of our amendments we will not support the Bill.

They are carrying on about bipartisanship. They are bleating about it. If they were really taking a bipartisan approach, they would indicate their support for the bill. But, no, as a result of their own difficulties they came out and said, `If you won't do this, we won't play ball.' That is what it is all about.

PARA.TAB: As a typical example, my good colleague the member for Wide Bay, who was excellent in the chair—I must pay him that compliment—talked about Cherbourg. He did not say it was very clear in the history of Queensland that there was a total abrogation of human and civil rights of Aboriginal people. These people have been subjected to appalling conditions of dependency for the last 150 years, and therefore we should not be surprised that it is taking a little time for those people to become empowered. He gave an example that, when you do move to make a difference, you can empower Aboriginal people to make decisions and deal with their problems.

That is what Aboriginal people are saying, and that is what Sol Bellear said in the Great Hall in response to these proposed amendments just after the opposition leader made his speech on the second reading of this bill. He said that Aboriginal medical services, which are particularly concerned and have been critical of the government in relation to the way we deal with health issues, support the government on this land fund bill. Land is essential for their people.

Members of the opposition come in here, beat their breasts and try to take the high moral ground about the appalling health conditions—conditions over which there is no disagreement. This government is committed to addressing that issue, and there are other very difficult social infrastructure issues to deal with. I refer to the comment of the member for Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) in the Northern Territory that state governments have abrogated their responsibilities and have not allocated effective funding for infrastructure in Aboriginal communities for health, education and housing, even though money was provided for those purposes.

Time and again in the access and equity inquiry of the House of Representatives standing committee it has been made very clear that in health, education and housing, to which this amendment refers, the state governments have commented, `Oh, well, it's Aboriginal. Let ATSIC do it.' ATSIC was never put in place to provide full funding for all Aboriginal issues. It provides extra and specific funding. It is quite clear from evidence we have received in previous inquiries that ATSIC's accountability is excellent. It spends a very small proportion of its budget on administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fourteen per cent for the lot.

—Fourteen per cent for all of its administration. I thank the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs for his assistance. But we hear from the opposition, including the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), `Give them land.' This is about setting up a land fund to purchase land that would otherwise not be available for communities under the Native Title Act. This government is committed to all the issues of concern to the opposition, but to refocus this bill would mean to make it a non-land bill. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring up another point with regard to the reasons why the government is opposed to amendment No. 4. My point comes from the experience that I and other members have had in the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. In one of our trips, I am pretty sure it was to Western Australia, we went to a community that had a problem with getting access to a sacred site that was in fact contained within a pastoral property. The Aboriginal people were seeking from our committee some assistance to negotiate access to that site because they had trouble with the leaseholder, who was not allowing people to move onto that sacred site because he was running cattle.

PARA.TAB: Through this land acquisition fund that the government is setting up, that is the type of property about which the local community would say, `We would like you to purchase that for us'—not because they intend to make it an economic operation but because they want that sacred site returned to their community. That is part of the spiritual and cultural needs of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people that we are seeking to address in this land acquisition fund. That part is being ignored by the opposition in its amendment where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . with regard, at all times, to the need to ensure that the health, housing or educational needs or economic viability . . .

The coalition has ignored one of the most fundamental reasons why we are establishing this fund; that is, to also deal with the spiritual and cultural needs of Aboriginal people. This fund will deal with the health, educational and economic needs of Aboriginal people because many of the purchases will be for those purposes. Many of the purchases will enable an improved economic position for a community. That is one of the major motivations of the fund.
