So to consider that we, as a government, are not taking that into account is quite false.

PARA.TAB: We are also taking into account those other elements. If one had a complete understanding of the importance of land to Aboriginal people in a cultural and spiritual sense, one would understand that we cannot restrict the purchases to ones which address economic viability or employment, health and housing needs. The purchases have to extend to examples like I have cited where communities have lost access to their sacred sites, where they would like to have the opportunity to purchase a property for it to be theirs—not so they could make it something that they could earn an income from but so they could deal with their cultural and spiritual needs that have been lost or taken away from them because of our colonisation process.

That is one of the other reasons why we are opposing this amendment. It restricts too much the capacity of the fund to deal with those types of needs, which will be many across Australia. The government is still very much concerned about health, housing and employment opportunities. We will not be denying those as very valid reasons also for purchasing land.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the debate on this amendment, which has gone for quite some time, is coming to an end. I do not disagree with what the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) has said, except where he has misinterpreted what we are doing. I think the spiritual and cultural needs of Aboriginal communities are extremely important. In most situations they would improve health. We would have no problem with an Aboriginal community returning to the land where it has spiritual and cultural ties. I would see it first and foremost as improving the health of that community. If it does not, look at the amendments, which say that, except where the circumstances make the pursuit of such a policy impracticable or inadvisable, health, housing or educational issues should be addressed.

PARA.TAB: First of all, your problem would have been addressed by improving the health of Aboriginal people in the community anyway. If, for some reason, returning to their traditional lands was not going to improve their health, under this amendment the land could still be provided to them if it were considered inadvisable to take on board one of those aspects.

There have been no arguments why this amendment should not be incorporated in the bill. We have heard lots of flustering and blustering from the government, trying to justify what is basically a totally unjustifiable stand, an absolute intransigence, on what are extremely reasonable amendments. The government did not look at any of the amendments. It said outright that it would reject the lot. It now has the very difficult job of trying to explain why it has rejected each individual amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand by every word that I have said in this debate and I do not propose to repeat those words. I would like, however, to finish on the most fundamental point that has been made in this debate. That is the point made by all government speakers about the unacceptability of this amendment, based as it is upon the opposition's total failure to be prepared to acknowledge the very essence of this bill as a land fund bill, its absolute inability to be able to acknowledge the social justice element and the pivotal element of the rights of dispossessed indigenous people to gain a land base. They cannot even grudgingly recognise this most fundamental principle.

PARA.TAB: That is why every indigenous organisation in the country that has spoken on this matter has rejected the coalition's amendment. It was left to me to send details of it to them in the absence of the coalition even having the courtesy to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject the minister's assertion. We have supported the land fund bill. We have passed it at the second reading stage, showing in principle support for the land fund. All we have asked is to have some of our measures of accountability taken into account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever the shadow minister might rise to say in reply, I do not intend to respond to it. To make it absolutely clear: each and every amendment has been considered on its merits. Even if we accepted every one of the coalition's amendments in the House of Representatives, what we are told by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and by the shadow minister is that that will not be enough because then we move to the other place and we have a whole new series of amendments. But, as the Demtel ads would tell us, there is more—because we can possibly have a Senate inquiry to boot, and who knows what agenda of the coalition is going to come out of that? So do not come into this place and pretend as good faith what is obviously very much a political agenda of the Leader of the Opposition, which this government refuses to embrace.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Mrs Gallus's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5)Clause 3, page 4, lines 11-14, omit proposed paragraph (b), substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(b)in a case where the Indigenous Land Corporation acquires an interest in land for the purpose of making a grant of the interest to:
(i)an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(ii)an aboriginal person; or
(iii)a Torres Strait Islander; or
(iv)a trustee of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust;
—that grant being made within a reasonable time after that acquisition.".

SPEECH.PARA: (6)Clause 3, page 4, lines 25 and 26, at the end of proposed paragraph 191E(1)(c) add "under agreements with the holders of the land".
(7)Clause 3, page 5, line 4, omit "have regard to the desirability of", substitute "give priority to".
(8)Clause 3, page 6, lines 15 and 16, omit "have regard to the desirability of", substitute "give priority to".
(9)Clause 3, page 6, line 31, at the beginning of subsection (4) insert "Subject to subsection (5),".
(10)Clause 3, page 6, after proposed subsection 191F(4) add the following subsection:
Report to Minister if sacred matters affect performance etc

PARA.TAB: " `(5) The Indigenous Land Corporation must provide a written report to the Minister in cases where the performance of its functions is affected by matters referred to in subsection (4).' ".

SPEECH.PARA: (11)Clause 3, page 9, lines 28-32, omit proposed paragraph (b), substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(b)the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary as the case requires, considers that it no longer needs to hold the interest for the purpose of making a grant of the interest to:
(i)an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(ii)an aboriginal person; or
(iii)a Torres Strait Islander; or
(iv)a trustee of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust;
within a reasonable time after that acquisition.".

SPEECH.PARA: (12)Clause 3, page 10, lines 29 and 30, omit proposed paragraph (a), substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(a)the acquisition of interests in land for the purpose of making grants of those interests to:
(i)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(ii)aboriginal persons; or
(iii)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(iv)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts.".

SPEECH.PARA: This is a sequence of consequential and incidental amendments to the bill, and I will very briefly address them. Amendment No. 5 is a consequential amendment which depends on an amendment to proposed section 191D (1). Amendment No. 6 proposes an addition to proposed section 191E(1)(c). It ensures that any land management activities in relation to indigenous held land are carried out with the agreement of the holders of the land. I would have thought the minister would be highly in agreement with that, and I simply cannot understand why he is not.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 7 addresses proposed section 191E(3). This ensures that, in the performance of its functions, the ILC does not merely consider the desirability of following the criteria; it must give priority to its functions mentioned in proposed section 191E (3)(a) to (c). Amendment No. 8 addresses proposed section 191F(2). Again, this amendment strengthens the regard that the ILC must have for its functions.

Amendment No. 9, which is tied in with amendment No. 10, addresses proposed section 191F(4). These two amendments ensure that the ILC, in dealing with matters that are sacred or otherwise significant to any particular group of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, must not discuss any material that is sensitive to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. However, when such matters affect the dealing of the corporation, the corporation must provide a written report to the minister.

Amendment No. 11 is a consequential amendment which again depends on our first major amendment today. It widens the scope of the bill to allow not only corporations to have grants but also individuals, trusts and partnerships. Amendment No. 12 addresses proposed section 191N(2)(a). It is consequential, in that it extends preference not only to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations but also to individuals and trusts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has given a technical presentation of these amendments, and I will respond in kind. I intend to go through each and every one of these amendments to explain how each and every one has been given detailed consideration by the government. I will also explain why they are not acceptable to the government.

PARA.TAB: The fifth amendment returns us to the proposition that would include, inter alia, funding of individuals in respect of land purchases. I repeat the fundamental point that this would overturn the policy of every government, both coalition and Labor, since the Commonwealth first attained the power to pass laws with respect to the human rights of indigenous people in the 1967 referendum. It is an amendment, as were the others, which has not been discussed by the coalition with a single indigenous person before they were introduced into this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know? You wouldn't know what we have done.
—The member for Mitchell asks how I know. I know because the shadow minister said on the public record to the press gallery of Parliament House that there had been no consultation.
—On the form of the amendments.

—There has been no consultation, as you acknowledge. Amendment (6), in the government's view, seeks to restrict unduly the activities of the Indigenous Land Corporation. It is our view that the corporation should be able to carry out land management activities that do not necessarily relate to a particular area of land.

PARA.TAB: I will just give some examples of the kinds of activities that it might be very good public policy for the Indigenous Land Corporation to engage in. I think it would be very important for the corporation to instil to the greatest degree it constructively could an understanding in the wider Australian community about the very essence and purpose of the legislation: that it does not threaten the rights of non-indigenous Australians and that it seeks to address a fundamental issue of social justice. I think it would be good public policy if the Indigenous Land Corporation had a capacity to be able to carry out broader educational initiatives concerning good environmental management of land. The amendment that the coalition seeks to move would unduly restrain the corporation from that kind of activity; therefore, the governments does not support it.

Amendments (7) and (8) relate to an attempt by the coalition again to unduly restrict the activities of the Indigenous Land Corporation. I ask honourable members to note that the government recognises that there are certain matters that the corporation ought to have regard to and that the board should properly consider, but we are not prepared to direct them as to these matters being the priorities in the form the coalition wants. We do not think it is an amendment that improves the legislation; we think it would adversely impact on the policy of the bill to entrust those matters of judgment, which often involve individual case judgments, to the members of the board of the corporation.

Amendments (9) and (10), as the shadow minister has told us, relate to matters of reporting of issues that may be sacred to indigenous people. We do not accept this because again we do not think it is good policy. We believe there is a potential element of cultural insensitivity to impose this requirement, especially in view of the fact that it is not included in comparable major legislation, including the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, which was of course legislation of the Fraser Liberal government. That is not to deny Edward Gough Whitlam and his government the credit for the impetus of the social movement and, indeed, the legislation itself, but it was the Fraser government that brought it into existence. This provision is not in that legislation; nor is it, of course, in the Native Title Act. We do not think it should be in this one.
Amendments (11) and (12) again relate to the first amendment of the coalition. My colleagues and I have articulated at great length the reason we oppose that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) re-entered the debate on amendment No. 1—the government obviously lost the argument—and I do not think he added much to the debate at that point. On amendment No. 6, I am at a loss to understand the minister's point. He said he rejects the amendment because it restricts the activities of the Indigenous Land Corporation, yet when I look at the actual bill proposed paragraph 191E(1)(a) states:

SPEECH.PARA: To carry on, or arrange for the carrying on of, land management activities in relation to indigenous-held land under agreements with the holders of the land . . .

They are the very words we have added to 191E(1)(c), yet the minister says we cannot add them because they will restrict the activities of the ILC. I am at a total loss to know what is going on. Let me reiterate this. In the present bill, as it stands, proposed paragraph 191E(1)(a) states:
To carry on, or arrange for the carrying on of, land management activities in relation to indigenous-held land under agreements with the holders of the land . . .
When we get to proposed paragraph (c), we see that it says almost the same thing:
to carry on other land management activities in relation to indigenous-held land—

other than what was mentioned in proposed paragraph (a). But it does not add that clause. So we have simply added the clause that was in the corresponding part of the bill in proposed paragraph (a)—mirroring exactly what the government intended. I would be delighted for the minister to tell me the difference. Regarding amendments Nos 7 and 8, if the minister is so unsure of the instructions given to the Indigenous Land Corporation that he is not prepared to replace the words `desirability of' with `priority to', I would suggest that the minister has very little faith in his bill.

PARA.TAB: In amendments Nos 9 and 10 we have in no way violated the cultural sensitivity of Aboriginal people. We have acknowledged that there are times when there are sacred matters that should not be disclosed. All we have asked is that when those times occur the board go to the minister and say, `There was a situation where we could not disclose information because it was of a secret or sacred nature.' I am at a total loss to understand the minister's reaction to those amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reply immediately to the point the shadow minister made—or, rather, to explain to her that the comments she made had no point at all. If you look at proposed section 191E(1)(a), you will see that she is undoubtedly correct to say that in that clause the government believes that there should be a reference to agreements with the holders of the land. But proposed paragraph (c), which she has referred to, is deliberately intended to be broader.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Gallus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We will take it really slowly. I said in my earlier remarks that there may be a very good public policy reason why the Indigenous Land Corporation may wish to have some broader activities that do not necessarily relate to any particular area of land. Those activities may include more general forms of activities to raise Aboriginal awareness, and perhaps even broader community awareness, about some key aspects of the work of the corporation—a perfectly normal clause. For that reason, it would be absurd to suggest that that ought to be on the basis of agreements with holders—
—Give us an example of what you are talking about.

—I have just given you two examples. If you are going to interject on me, I am more than happy to let my existing comments on the record stand. You can read the Hansard if you want another example to illustrate the point. I would have thought that all members of this House would believe that it is very important for there to be a developing and more developed awareness by indigenous people—and, importantly, by the wider community as well—about the questions of protecting land, land management and land enhancement.

PARA.TAB: The corporation may seek to work with indigenous organisations which own land as a part of that broader campaign and the broader awareness initiative of the corporation. In that particular case there would not need to be an agreement with any individual land holder. It is a very simple point. We are not prepared to further restrict the scope of the board to undertake such a broader initiative. For example, it may be very important for the board members to bring in the holders and owners of various pastoral properties for some form of educational or other initiative. In those circumstances, they would not—and nor should they—have to have agreement with the holders of any land.

I want to turn to another point, because it is far more substantive. I mentioned that there were no requirements in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act or the Native Title Act for any report to the minister as envisaged by amendment No. 10. A more fundamental point ought to be made. The legislation which creates the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is unanimously supported by the Australian parliament. It is very important to emphasise that there is no clause in the ATSIC legislation comparable to the one that the coalition now intends to insert in relation to its amendment No. 10.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that we can't have anything in a bill that wasn't in previous bills?
—No. But you have to advance a good public policy reason why it ought to be supported. You have not done that. Therefore, the government rejects the amendment.

—We need to go through these amendments, because it needs to be understood by our fellow Australians that the coalition is proposing to strengthen the role of indigenous land owners against what could be an overpowering bureaucracy operated by the Indigenous Land Corporation. There are three small paragraphs. The first one says that the corporation will not do anything until it talks to the landowner. You will give this land away—you are spending over $1 billion giving land to Aboriginal communities—and then you will leave this outfit in charge of it. In one instance you say that it shall consult, yet two paragraphs later you say that it need not consult. The wording is identical.

PARA.TAB: I will give the minister an example of what could occur because it only relates to indigenously held land; it does not relate to any wide land pattern of management, any examination of what lands might be eligible for indigenous land-holders to take up or anything like that. The land must be held by indigenous people. Under this proposal, you are giving the Indigenous Land Corporation the power to make any management decisions it chooses about that land. It can put roads through it or build fences or open a tourist station on it. It could do anything there. It does not have to consult.

I will run through the three paragraphs in sequence. They appear to be almost identical and somewhat confused. The first one says that the Indigenous Land Council can carry out land management functions or arrange to carry out those functions after consultation and agreement with the holders of the land. The second one says that it can carry on, or arrange to carry on, land management activities in relation to land held by the Indigenous Land Corporation. That is its own land. But then there is a paragraph which says that it can carry on other land management activities in relation to indigenously held land. There is no consultation or concern for the Aboriginal people or the ones for whom this bill is supposed to be in place.

The government is putting forward an incredible proposition. It is expecting us to believe that it is not paternalism or centralised control and that it is not a group of five or six people sending their servants into Queensland, the Northern Territory, Western Australia, New South Wales or even the ACT to tell the landowners what is good for them. It could put a road through the land, start a tourist place on it or do whatever it likes. The bill is clear: the power rests centrally. The Indigenous Land Corporation has a veto over the holders of land. It is clear that it can do what it likes without consultation with the indigenous landowners who hold the land.

We will go through the rest of these four or five amendments. We are asking the government to do some fairly simple things. For instance, we are asking the government to change simple words. Instead of having regard to the desirability of a certain series of objectives, this Indigenous Land Corporation must give priority to its objectives. You reject that. You do not believe it should give priority to its objectives.

I do not know where you have been but Australia has changed in the last 10 years. People are now starting to set priorities and objectives in the workplace and for corporations. Why should this land outfit not do the same thing? All we are asking is for it to give priority to pursuing sound land and environmental practices; we are asking for it to give priority to pursuing a policy of granting money or making loans only where corporations consider that alternative approaches are not satisfactory; and we are asking for it to give priority to cases where the Indigenous Land Corporation arranges for the carry-on of land management activities under agreement with the holders of indigenous land, directly involving the holders of the land.You are not even prepared to say that that should be a priority.

The title of this outfit includes the words `indigenous land corporation', and you are not even prepared to make consulting the indigenous landowners one of its priorities. Well, well, well, there we have the government. You say `must consider it', but you give no priority to consulting or dealing with the indigenous landowners. Do not make it a priority, do not make it an objective; just waffle on and say that it is a desirable result. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether members of the opposition naturally have a problem with understanding the language or whether they are being deliberately obtuse, but the two different clauses under consideration are quite simple and straightforward. I am referring to amendment No. 6, which wishes to insert the words, `under agreements with the holders of the land' in proposed section 191E(1)(c).

PARA.TAB: Proposed section 191E(1)(a) talks about land management activities that the corporation will undertake on specific sites of land. So, if it is going to do something to a particular site of land—and you have used all these examples of putting a road through, building a tourist development and all of that—it must negotiate with the holders of that land. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has explained that paragraph (c) refers to carrying on other land management activities in relation to indigenous-held land. It talks about general educational or promotional activities. It talks about where the ILC may want to talk to all indigenous-held land corporations and say, `Well, you should be doing this as far as your land management activities are concerned,' so it can run educational programs. It is a lunacy to suggest that, in the performance of its duties in relation to land management, the ILC has to refer every decision it makes about running an education program to every holder of the land. If it is doing something on one specifically held piece of land, it is required to negotiate with the holders of that land.

But proposed section 191E(1)(c) relates to other activities. It relates to general activities that the corporation will be undertaking in advancing land management activities. It is designed to ensure that the board has the capacity under the act to do those things. It will not be possible to run general educational activities if this clause does not exist. You well know that acts often have sections of a similar nature which are designed to give, firstly, a specific duty and, secondly, a more broader responsibility. It is ludicrous for the opposition to suggest that those words should be inserted in that third paragraph when it will defeat the very purpose it is meant to achieve, and that is to ensure that the corporation can undertake general educational activities to promote good land management practices by all indigenous land-holders throughout.

All the other amendments are consistent with the opposition's desire to try to restrict the flexibility of the board to make the appropriate decisions in relation to its activities as a corporation in purchasing land, and are consistent with the opposition's total lack of understanding about what the corporation is about or what this bill is about. That is why the opposition's amendments are rejected by the government and will not be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment briefly on amendment No. 10, which refers to the question of secrecy. It is really a nonsense type of accountability if, at any time a question arises about whether or not funds have been wisely spent, all the Indigenous Land Corporation has to say is, `This is some kind of Aboriginal secret so therefore we won't tell anybody about it.' I acknowledge also that there are Aboriginal secrets which are important to them and which they want to preserve, but this can far too readily be used as a defence if there is not some degree of guarantee that someone is able to scrutinise the validity of the excuse.

—Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister agree with the member for Kalgoorlie—who normally sits behind him—who today described the League of Rights as `just an ordinary little organisation'? Does the Prime Minister share the member for Kalgoorlie's concerns about `the power and influence of Zionists'? If he does not agree, what action has the Prime Minister taken today to discipline his own party member or, when it comes to McCarthyist smears, is this another case of his double standards?

—The strike against the Leader of the Opposition yesterday was that he would not own up to the fact that he had been to this meeting. He was trying to say that it was some Christian gathering. This was after he said on television a couple of weeks ago, `I am the most honest person you will ever meet.'

PARA.TAB: I think Mr Campbell's appearances at these sorts of gatherings are extremely ill-advised and, in my view, he would do himself a great service by not attending them. But he is not the leader of the Labor Party. For the Leader of the Opposition to come in here and ask me questions about Graeme Campbell as some sort of apologia for the fact that he turned up to a League of Rights meeting I think shows where he is.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister inform the House about the progress of reforms to Australia's labour market and the vocational training system introduced in the white paper?

—The white paper, or Working Nation, was a landmark in Australian social policy. No other country has produced such a comprehensive, integrated, detailed response to the challenge of long-term unemployment. The same may be said about the challenge of training and skills—perhaps the most important challenge of the era. We have set out to build a vocational training system to rank with the best in the world. I am pleased to say that the Working Nation programs are now under way. Let me give a couple of examples.

PARA.TAB: As at the beginning of this month, 2,000 case managers are on the job; they have been appointed and have taken up their positions. Sixty-five thousand people have already entered case management: that is, 65,000 unemployed people are already being case managed. In July, 16,000 clients eligible for the job compact were managed. In July we also raised the subsidy rates for the long-term unemployed—by up to $230 for the first 13 weeks and $115 for the next 26 weeks.

This is a start on the way to our aim to fund 50,000 new entry level positions by 1995-96 and to find jobs under the job compact for more than 160,000 long-term unemployed people a year. We are getting these people ready for work, matching their skills to the needs of employers. We have established a new Employment Services Regulatory Agency, ESRA, which will add to the competition of the system. ESRA's job is basically to develop a competitive market for job placement and for the job compact.

This morning I launched NETTFORCE, the National Employment and Training Taskforce, which follows from the work done by Lindsay Fox and Bill Kelty in establishing traineeships throughout 1992 and 1993. NETTFORCE consists of people who have experience in business, such as Mr Evans from the Metal Trades Industry Association, Mr Wright from the hotel industry, Mr Deveson and others. They all share a common ambition, and that is to give confidence to young Australians and to help them actively enter into training.

The government is seeking to add 50,000 entry level training places to the system, and NETTFORCE will now establish training companies, that is, companies which are related to a particular industry. For instance, we will have a training company in the hospitality industry, the metal industry, the engineering industry and in various other sectors of the economy. That will mean that employers in that sector of the economy can go to the training company which has been established by their organisation with the trade unions to take on trainees for traineeships. It will be a one-stop shop for the appointment of trainees in the country. Combined with the training wage, this will simplify the appointment of trainees.

This morning I had the chance to speak to a few trainees who are now three or four months into their year of training, and they said how valuable the training was to them. We will see how the Liberal Party addresses these issues on Monday. When the Leader of the Opposition was shadow Treasurer, he said the white paper `was a spending spree'. He said the white paper `requires heroic assumptions'. He said that it was irresponsible and that it would discourage investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is unbelievable. Where is the money coming from?
—Unbelievable! Here is your press release, which refers to `the government's decision to go on a spending spree'.
—So? It is unbelievable.
—Why would you say it is unbelievable? You have said it—`requires heroic assumptions' and `so irresponsible are the assumptions'.
—I am glad you read the press release.

—Don't try to pretend you didn't say it. We will see what the Leader of the Opposition has to say on Monday about traineeships, the long-term unemployed, social equity and decency in the labour market, to see that all Australians have the benefit of enjoying the recovery, not just those who have jobs or are taking up new jobs. We want those long-term unemployed people trained to have a place back in the labour market.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. In bringing McCarthyist smears to Australia yesterday, the Prime Minister suggested that members of parliament should not knowingly or unknowingly address an organisation known as the League of Rights. In answer to a question I asked just a moment ago relating to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, the Prime Minister made the point:

QUESTION.PARA: But he is not the leader of the Labor Party.

Is the Prime Minister aware that Mr Ian Taylor, the Leader of the Labor Party in Western Australia, issued an invitation to members of the Australian Heritage Society to meet him and his shadow cabinet this week? Is he aware that the society's letterhead says that it was formed in 1971 and is a division of the Australian League of Rights? Will the Prime Minister now call on the Leader of the Labor Party in Western Australia to resign, or is this another case of the Prime Minister's double standards? I seek leave to table the invitation from Mr Taylor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—No.
—Order! Leave is not granted.
—Stung, isn't he? He is really stung.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say clearly and unambiguously—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want the answer?

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I never said you were an anti-Semite.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister will resume his seat. I remind those on my left that the collective types of interjections that are being used are not permitted and should cease. The Leader of the Opposition has asked his question and the Prime Minister will answer it.

—If the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia meets the League of Rights, he would be as foolish as the Leader of the Opposition was when he met with them. He would be as utterly foolish as you were when you met them.
—I didn't invite them.

—This is the person who says, `I was always in politics. I grew up in politics. I was at my father's knee in politics. I understood politics. It was always in my blood.' But at 36 years of age he did not know he was addressing the League of Rights. It is reported in Mr Oakes's column that the explanation to his friends was that he was very young at the time—just like his explanation two weeks ago, `I had something else on my mind at the time; I was emotional about the corroboree at the time.' Of course, as the Age points out, the corroboree took place an hour after his comments.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting.
—I do not say that the Leader of the Opposition is an anti-Semite but I do believe that he knowingly went to a meeting run by notorious anti-Semites.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Under standing orders there should not be one rule for the Prime Minister and one for everyone else. The question was specifically about an invitation from Mr Taylor to the League of Rights to go to a morning meeting with his shadow cabinet. I asked the Prime Minister about it and I would have expected an answer to that question.
—Order! The Prime Minister will answer the question.
—Let me give you an explicit answer to the question. He would be as foolish to extend that invitation as you were to accept the invitation to address the League of Rights, and which you attended.
—Order! Order!

—The Leader of the Opposition's offence was basically committed yesterday when he compounded his folly by hiding and pretending he did not know, by trying to say he had attended a Christian rally and that he had no recollection of the League of Rights being there. He said he would never share a platform with the League of Rights and he only accepted an invitation from a nice, pleasant, elderly couple. Does he expect us to accept that pathetically childish, deceitful nonsense? Who does he think he is fooling—at 36 years of age? The honourable member for Dickson is 32 years of age and is the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth. I would not have thought that a 36-year-old could claim to be a child.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition should have come clean yesterday, said he made an error and said he went to the League of Rights. Instead, he slinked out the door of some venue yesterday, and hid from the media all afternoon. He would not have been brought to account at all but for the fact that he tried to stymie debate in the House. He hid behind the member for O'Connor and the Leader of the National Party, and when I heard this it was at about that stage I decided to go and say something at a doorstop. Only then did he finally admit to the fact that, yes, he had been to this meeting, that it was the League of Rights. He then attempted a public square off. If he had done that earlier in the day, he would have been well and truly better off.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

TALKER.NAME: Mr DOWNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Mayo from moving forthwith that this House censures the Prime Minister for discrediting the high office of Prime Minister by making unfounded, divisive and racist allegations for his own base political ends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the suspension.
—You might like to have a chat with Ian Taylor before you make your speech to find out what your mate is up to. You and Ian are together. You are the two who go and visit Brian Burke.
—Order! Is it the intention of the Leader of the House to allow this motion to continue?
—Absolutely.
—Is the motion seconded by the Leader of the National Party?
—The Leader of the House seconded it.
—I second the motion.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party has indicated that he seconds the motion. Is that the case?
—I seconded the suspension of standing orders. I think if this guy is silly enough to put up a proposition to suspend standing orders to discuss his peccadilloes he should be given every chance.
—It gives me a bit of time to talk about the Labor Party in Western Australia.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative, with an absolute majority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DOWNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House censures the Prime Minister for discrediting the high office of Prime Minister by making unfounded, divisive and racist allegations for his own base political ends.

SPEECH.PARA: I must start off by saying that it is amusing to hear that today the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has started to shift his argument away from the ugly implication that somehow I am racist—it is only an implication, but an ugly implication to get the headlines—to saying that it was something about the way I and my office handled the media in relation to this exercise. The Prime Minister should read the headlines today. He should have watched the television news last night. He wanted the headlines that said, for example in the Australian, `Racist row: PM and Downer clash'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you did.

—Yes, you are right. You wanted those headlines. You wanted the word `race' struck across the Brisbane Courier-Mail yesterday. That is what you are trying to incite. That is what you are trying to encourage and you are using a different argument now because you are embarrassed about that one. The fact is that the Prime Minister of Australia is one of the people in this country who sets the standards, not just for his government but for Australia.
—You set a great standard—going to talk to racists!
—Order! The honourable member for Calwell!

—The way the Prime Minister behaves, the way he speaks, the way he looks on national television and the way he goes about his business affects the way all Australians perceive government and the institution of parliament and it affects the way we, as a nation, see ourselves.

PARA.TAB: The behaviour of the Prime Minister and other ministers in the course of this week began at the level of shabby and has ended in the gutter. Earlier this week, in all good faith, the federal opposition put forward some proposals to amend the Aboriginal land fund bill. If those amendments were supported by the government, we would be prepared to support the bill. That is what we said. Before the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), who is walking out and who has himself been party to the shame of the Labor Party this week, had ever seen the amendments, they rejected them saying, `We are not interested in your amendments, but we don't know what they are.'

That is not professional government and that is not a way to bring Australians together in reconciliation in order to achieve a better outcome for Aboriginal people and a country more at home with itself. This side of the House represents very nearly half of Australians. Your attitude to that half of Australia is that it is illegitimate. You do not want any part of it. You believe that reconciliation is your side—reconciliation amongst the Labor Party factions—but you forget about our side of politics and those millions of people who support us.

So that was the beginning of the week; that was Monday's and Tuesday's exercise. By Wednesday we had the descent on Australian politics of ugly McCarthyism. Can you imagine someone like Ben Chifley or John Curtin or even Gough Whitlam or Arthur Calwell or, should I mention his name, Bob Hawke—remember Bob Hawke?—those heroes of the Labor Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I take a point of order. Ben Chifley would never have gone to a League of Rights meeting.
—Order! The honourable member for Chifley will resume his seat.

—But would Jack Lang have gone to a League of Rights meeting? I will tell you in a minute about Jack Lang—this guy's hero—because a lot of you do not know much about the history of the Labor Party and you certainly do not know about the decency of some of the people who went before him as the leader of the Labor Party. I am not casting aspersions on all of you because not all of you are as bad as him, and you know of it, of course.

PARA.TAB: But let us have a look at the way the Prime Minister tries to get the racial line up. He never comes out and says that I am a racist or that members of the coalition are racists—never anything as unsubtle as that. It is always the underlying theme. So when I made that speech in Western Australia about the Native Title Act, what was the Prime Minister's reaction to that? It was that I am run by the `worst elements of conservatism', which he described as `unrestrained bigotry'. This was, you might say, clever politics because he does not say that I am a bigot. What he does is get them to write that I am a bigot. So on the front page of the Melbourne Age we ended up with the headline, "`Downer is a bigot', says PM". That is what you wanted, and you got it. That is part of the subliminal campaign to cast aspersions on everybody over here as being racist. That is what your campaign is all about. And this, the first of the racist smears in my time as the Leader of the Opposition, which is only three months.

Then we came to the notorious so-called League of Rights affair. This relates to assertions about what I did seven years ago. What was the Prime Minister doing seven years ago? Do you remember what you were doing seven years ago? Do you remember what you were doing seven days ago? Seven years ago this was a headline from the Sydney Morning Herald, `Keating predicts lower loan rates'. What happened then? They went up to 17 per cent, business loans went above 20 per cent and you created the worst recession in 60 years. So that is what you were saying seven years ago but what you did was put a million people out of work. Nice.

How about this, the same week: `Keating move for PM denied'. I just thought I would mention it. I think you would like to be reminded of that, wouldn't you? This affair over the last few days is one of the more despicable events in Australian federal political history. In many respects it is a watershed moment in Australian political history because we as a country have to ask ourselves: are we going to continue to tolerate the underlying, underhand racial slur from the man who is supposed to be the political leader of this country or is resistance going to be put up to this type of political tactic and are all Australians eventually going to say that enough is enough? I tell you, they are going to say that enough is enough.

Yesterday in the Senate we had Senator Bolkus. First of all, we had somebody called David Epstein. He is not well-known to members on this side of the House but he is the man who runs the National Media Liaison Service. He was wandering around the press gallery shamefacedly distributing a lot of material always designed to give the impression that I was some sort of vile, far right wing racist—never saying it, but always designed to give that impression. Then we had Senate question time. In Senate question time we had Senator Bolkus. Senator Bolkus was using all the quotes of Eric Butler and these other characters from the League of Rights, anti-Semitic quotes that I think everyone here would be appalled with, and then associating me with those remarks. That is part of the standard of debate used by the Labor Party.

We had the effort of the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), who is at the table, which was perhaps a little more harmless. I do not think the minister would ever quite sink to the standards of the Prime Minister or, in this case, Senator Bolkus. After all, the minister at the table is a colleague of Ian Taylor. When it comes to guilt by association, mate, you might like to think about that.

Then we had the most shameful event of the day, one of the more shameful events of Australian political history, one of the ugliest moments that we have seen in Australian politics for a very long time: the Keating press conference. He rushed out there to the press conference and was asked several questions. He was asked one very specific question: was Alexander Downer anti-Semitic? He was asked that question quite specifically.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who knows.

—One of your backbenchers says `Who knows'. One of the women said that. Let us just hear who it was. You gave the same answer as the honourable member for Bass. You did not answer; you left it in the air. You would not want anyone to come to the conclusion that I am not anti-Semitic, would you? The President of the Council of Australian Jewry came out quite clearly and said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am quite satisfied that as far as anti-Semitism and racism is concerned, Alexander Downer is not a racist.

He is the President of the Council of Australian Jewry, somebody I know. You are also, as it turns out, somebody who has been in this parliament with me for the last 10 or so years. You, as the Prime Minister, know only too well that I am not anti-Semitic or racist. But when that question was put to you by a journalist, you refused to answer it. That is the level of your standards. What a coward you are! If ever you needed proof that this Prime Minister was running a subliminal campaign to have people write that I am a racist, that is the proof we are looking for. It is the old Keating line: smear by innuendo. Do not ever say somebody is a racist, let others draw that conclusion. That is one of the ugliest facets of politics that I have seen. The Prime Minister deserves to be very strongly censured for behaving in that way.

PARA.TAB: Let me make one final point about the Prime Minister: that is, the point on double standards. The double standards of the Prime Minister on this issue are simply incredible. I have made the point in relation to Ian Taylor, the Western Australian Leader of the Opposition. The invitation states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ian Taylor MLA
Leader of the State Parliamentary Labor Party
Invites—
in nice writing—
Mrs M.E. Burton and members
Australian Heritage Society (WA Branch)
To a morning meeting with his Shadow Cabinet team
the irony of this is that it was this week—
Time: 10:00 am
Date: Monday 29th August 1994.
In order to assist with catering for tea and coffee, please RSVP to Ian Taylor's office on 222 7233.

Kim would know the number; Carmen would not. She turned her back, did she not? What is the Australian Heritage Society? Here is its letterhead. At the top of the letterhead is the name of the secretary and the address: Midland in Western Australia. At the bottom, it states:
The Australian Heritage Society was formed in 1971 and is a division of the Australian League of Rights.

You can make the charge that I went to this meeting to talk about the constitution, that some people from the League of Rights were there, and that it was a front for the League of Rights. That is fair enough. I can tell the House that I have never invited the League of Rights for morning tea.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Invite all of them as well? What is the Labor Party about? Where is the sincerity of the Labor Party? This Mr Taylor was on Radio 6PR in Perth this morning. He was criticising the Prime Minister, saying that he should not go on in the way he does. People out there in the community are embarrassed by the way the Prime Minister goes on. More importantly, this Mr Taylor said, `Backbenchers can go around and talk to groups like that but, as the Leader of the Opposition, I wouldn't do it.' Is that not strange? He is the Leader of the Opposition and he invited them. It will be very interesting to see what the Labor Party does about Mr Taylor. That is one example of double standards. I would have thought it was, on the whole, just a trifle embarrassing.

PARA.TAB: In question time, I referred to the remarks made by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) this morning. He referred to the League of Rights as just an ordinary little organisation. He expressed concern about the power and influence of Zionists.

TALK.START.PARA: —He had you lot pegged.

—Apparently, this is all right; this does not matter to the Prime Minister. But when somebody on our side of the House has anything to do with any organisation of that kind in any shape or form, it is time for the subliminal racist campaign. Australians are not impressed with those double standards.

PARA.TAB: I thought the House may be interested in my third example of double standards. It is interesting to know what the Prime Minister said about his great hero in politics, Jack Lang. Do you remember Jack Lang, the man whom the Prime Minister campaigned to get brought back into the Labor Party? Jack Lang was expelled from the Labor Party. Years passed and the Prime Minister was one of those who tried to get him back into the Labor Party.

The Prime Minister once said of Jack Lang, `Lang taught me a lot about the feeling and the spirit of the Labor Party.' Jack Lang! What a hero! What did Jack Lang say? Jack Lang could only be described as anti-Semitic. If you read the biography of Jack Lang, you would learn that he was a man who attacked Jewish migration from what was then called Palestine. He thought they were people who would dabble in black market commerce when they arrived and would create Australian ghettos.

The first thing we know about the Prime Minister's hero is that he was anti-Semitic. The second thing we know about the Prime Minister's hero is that he thought the white Australia policy was a wonderful thing. He told the House of Representatives that `white Australia is the most vital plank of our national policy'.

I make these points for a good reason. It is not to suggest that the Prime Minister is anti-Semitic or that the Prime Minister would like a return to the white Australia policy. Obviously, no-one in this House wants that. I make the simple point that the man whom he describes as his great hero in politics is a man who held those views. It would be pretty crass to draw the conclusion that the Prime Minister was therefore associated with someone who was anti-Semitic and who believed in white supremacy. Yet that is the sort of standard that the Prime Minister applies to public debate in this country.

This House should censure the Prime Minister. In the office of Prime Minister, he has lowered the standards of public respectability. The Prime Minister has brought into disrepute the House of Representatives. He has brought into disrepute the institution of the parliament. He is a man who does not uphold the standards that Australians expect from a Prime Minister of this country. He uses any political opportunity he can to smear his opponents.

In this particular case, he has descended to the ugliest of all smears. This time the Prime Minister really has gone too far. I think the House should understand that. Even members on the other side, biased as they may be, are embarrassed by the depths to which the Prime Minister has sunk this week.

He started the week on the Aboriginal land fund, rejecting the coalition's amendments before he had seen them—at best a man who is insincere. He ended the week by sinking into the political gutter. Playing around in the gutter, suddenly he found Ian Taylor there. Not only is it embarrassing for the Prime Minister, it is worse than that. The Prime Minister has reduced the standards of public office in this country and it is about time the House censured him and we did something about resuming better standards in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: THE PRIME MINISTER

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING
TALKER.ROLE: Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: I move:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be deleted and be replaced with

"This House censures the Leader of the Opposition for his deception and dishonesty in failing to tell the truth about his attendance and participation in a League of Rights meeting in Adelaide in 1987."

SPEECH.PARA: By the way, I had that typed before lunch just in case you got up to these schoolboy tactics, which I thought you would. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) is up here today because of paragraphs like this in the newspaper—

TALK.START.PARA: —He has caught you out.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland!
—It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, Downer did in 1987 address a meeting of one of these organisations, but that is not really the point. The point is that Downer lacks the brains, the judgment, the strength and the honesty ever to lead his party effectively, let alone the country.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—That is why you are on your feet. That is a Sydney Morning Herald article, and similar comments were made in the Age. That is why you are on your feet. That is why he is up on his feet today; that is what stung him. He had a chance yesterday when this matter came out.

PARA.TAB: Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Ballarat!

—I am told reliably that the material was leaked by the Liberal Party in the first place. When it came out the Leader of the Opposition should have got up and said, `Yes, I did attend this meeting and I shouldn't have. It was a mistake. It was a foolish mistake, and I admit it,' and that would have been the end of it.
—Rise above this level. Get above it.
—You have had your go; just wait. What did he do? He told journalists at the function that he would give them a comment afterwards and then slunk out the back door.
—I didn't talk to journalists. That is not true.
—No, your press secretary told them. And they waited for you when you slid out the back door. Then when the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) raised this issue in the House you immediately—
—That is not true. It is absolutely not true.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. Order!

—You immediately then hid behind the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer); then you hid behind the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). You did anything but own up to the fact that you actually attended this meeting. How could you attend such a meeting and not know you had attended it?

PARA.TAB: In the event that you did, at least come out and say, `I did attend it and it was a mistake.' Everybody would have said fine. No, you want to gag the Minister for Finance; you want to stop him speaking. You had already played your little game with the journalists. When I went out and said that which I did, I did not call you a racist, as you know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no! But you did not answer the question of anti-Semitism.

—Then you are back in here today with this little thing. We have got all this mock indignation about McCarthyism and the rest. You did not mind it when Senator Chapman was hopping into Graham Richardson in the Senate, did you? You did not mind it when his family was being subject to this sort of material, when you were saying that he had been associating with prostitutes. You did not mind that. You flew over on a VIP aircraft with Senator Chapman on the night before he raised these matters in the Senate. You knew of it and you condoned it.
—And Senator Schacht was on the flight too. Was he involved in it too?
—Order!

—You knew all about it. You were quite happy for that scam to run; you were quite happy for these unprincipled, unsubstantiated allegations to run. Now you are up crying for yourself about McCarthyist tactics and attacks on you. You attacked me for saying in Western Australia that you were pandering to unrestrained bigotry when for a few cheers you stood up and said you would repeal the native title legislation. That is exactly what you are doing: pandering to unrestrained bigotry—cheer chasing with the Western Australian rednecks. Now one of the charges against me is that I did not defend you yesterday and say, `No, he is not a racist; this person attended this meeting not knowing,' when you would not defend yourself. You would not even get up and defend yourself!
—Look. What does this say? Read it.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition!

—Then he attempts to censure me, but he is the one who attended an organisation he knew, and must have known—could not help knowing—was a notoriously racist and anti-Semitic organisation. I do not believe that the Leader of the Opposition is an anti-Semite.
—Now you say it, 24 hours after you refused to answer the question.
—Order!
—But I do believe he is the most foolish political leader of this country since Billy McMahon.

PARA.TAB: Government members—Hear, hear!
Nr ACTING SPEAKER—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —What a wimp.
—Order! The honourable member for Berowra!

—I do not believe he is an anti-Semite, but I do believe he knowingly went to a meeting run by notorious anti-Semites at a time when anti-Semites were at their most active; at a time when they were escorting David Irving around the country and giving him standing ovations for denying the Holocaust; and at a time when his own colleagues were publicly denouncing the League of Rights. It was the very same time! I do not believe he is an anti-Semite, but I believe he lacks judgment and substance. Addressing the League of Rights in 1987 was stupid, but it was not a hanging offence. The hanging offence was the way he behaved yesterday when he compounded his folly by hiding and pretending he did not know, pretending he was at a Christian rally. In Mr Oakes's column, where this first appeared, he had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that Downer is not very discriminating—

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to listen? You have had your go. Mr Oakes said:

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that Downer is not very discriminating—the downside of being a total political pragmatist. A related factor is his lack of a philosophical centre. If you are not sure of what you stand for, it is not easy to pick your company wisely. Downer does not know who his friends should be.
Dead right—and dead right in 1987! Mr Oakes then goes on to talk about the debate in respect of the Tasmanian legislation. He says:
So one day Downer is with the godly; the next day the ungodly. Will the real Alexander Downer please stand up? No, he won't. He can't because he doesn't have a position.

That is the problem. And then, of course, compounding all this, the Leader of the Opposition came in the other day with the nerve—the gall—to say of the government that it was putting at risk reconciliation with Aboriginal people in this country, when he had stood up in front of rednecks and said he would repeal the native title legislation. Then he came in, disingenuously, with a set of amendments, and said, `Unless they are agreed to, we will oppose the bill.' In other words, he had no intention of supporting the land fund legislation—none whatsoever. It took until 3.30 the following day—that is, yesterday—for the government to even see the amendments. These important philosophically based amendments took 1 1/2 days to turn up!

PARA.TAB: What did we find in the amendments? That unless Aboriginal people can show subjectively that they are improved in health, education and other things, they do not get access to their land. What we are seeing by the Leader of the Opposition is simply the same mean-spirited, reactionary, right wing policies we have always seen from him and the opposition. They have basically denied Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders their land.

The Leader of the Opposition came in and said, `I am supporting the land fund.' But it is really a sham to oppose it and he was exposed in that sham. The next day, he was exposed as talking to a League of Rights meeting in 1987. However, he has the gall to say that if I do not defend him in a press conference I am to be censured. But he would not defend himself.

The Leader of the Opposition was going to make a personal explanation after question time yesterday, but when he got through question time, he thought better of it. I am told that he came here and made a space for himself for a personal explanation but then did not make it. He then hid, monkey cunning, in his office until I said something at the doorstop interview. He then came out belching, raging, fuming and going on.

The problem with the Liberal Party is that all the moderates have been expunged from it—Fred Chaney, Peter Baume, Chris Puplick, Ian Macphee—and the Steele Halls, the Michael Wooldridges and the Chris Galluses are simply paying lip-service to this hardline, reactionary bunch who will now try to strike down the land fund and the native title legislation. The Liberal Party has gone to the right and stayed at the right. I can only say to the likes of the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) and the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), `Don't besmirch your political reputations by dealing with them. Don't mess around with sham amendments when you know that the end product is a vote against the native title legislation.'

Yesterday, after 100 days of the Leader of the Opposition being in office, the Leader of the National Party sent out a press release entitled `Fischer salutes Downer's first 10 weeks'. It states that the Leader of the Opposition:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . has set a scorching pace . . . with his professionalism and determined approach.
The forthcoming statement of direction . . . will point the way in a positive but relatively low-key fashion.

The Leader of the Opposition did not know Liberal Party policy when the frontbenchers could not privately sponsor staff. He did not know Liberal Party policy on the Northern Territory land rights act. He did not know what he was doing when he signed a letter supporting the principles of citizen initiated referenda. He did not know what he was signing at the time. He now does not agree with it. He did not know about the League of Rights when he addressed it. Everyone else knew about the League of Rights, but he did not.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition has set a scorching pace of retreat. He opposes the interests of Aboriginal Australians with the native title legislation. He opposes the land fund. He runs away from the Queen, whose place in the constitution he champions by saying that she is quite irrelevant.

The truth of the matter about this Leader of the Opposition is that he has run backwards for 100 days. He has dragged the Liberal Party back to the mad right by seeking to line up with every redneck issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Boring! Boring!
—The honourable member for Kooyong!

—Instead of coming out and defending himself when he is exposed as talking to a League of Rights meeting, he wants to hide. If I point out the fact that he has done so and that he should account for himself, he then goes on to seek to censure me.

PARA.TAB: Every other person in the Liberal Party knew at the time that the League of Rights was the organisation that it is. The Leader of the Opposition should be ashamed that he appeared before it. He still has not told us why he appeared before this notoriously racist, anti-Semitic organisation, yet he went and moved this sham motion. The Leader of the Opposition is in trouble politically.

The Leader of the Opposition is in trouble politically and, as a consequence, he relies upon an invitation from the Western Australian Leader of the Opposition, which invitation, I have been given a note to say, was one of 980 pro forma invitations to community groups in the state electorate of Helena. The list of groups came from the infolink database of the State Library of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who sent out the invitation?

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members will come to order.

—One thing that the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia has not done is accept an invitation from a notorious racist and anti-Semitic body, as did this Leader of the Opposition. He should own up to his foolishness but, in owning up to it, again demonstrate the fact that, frankly, he is too stupid to lead a major political party and that he is taking the Liberal Party backwards in a reactionary fashion. As I said the other day, you cannot afford a leadership battle but you cannot afford to keep him. That is your dilemma and I am afraid for you that you are stuck with it. I commend the amendment to the House.
—Order! The members of the National Party holding up signs will not do so. The honourable member for Parkes!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The arrogance of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) committed him to an awful mistake yesterday—a mistake which, in terms of partisan politics, might give us some passing joy but, in terms of nation building and rebuilding the unity of this nation, can give no-one any joy about the governance of Australia. He provided a double standard. He debased the standard of office of Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Not only has the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) totally exposed the Prime Minister today and shown what a complete and arrogant Prime Minister he is with his double standards; we now find that this is not the first occasion the Prime Minister has sought to bring racism of the worst kind into national political debate. I find myself duty bound to quote back to the Prime Minister, in response to the press release of mine he was kind enough to read out, a quote of his which might cause him some heartburn—as it should. I refer to 22 January 1992, when the Prime Minister was doing that favourite radio program of his, John Laws, on 2UE in Sydney. I quote exactly the words of Prime Minister Keating at that time.
Government members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask people to listen, in fairness to the Prime Minister. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I think from (the Opposition) we will see a repeat of what we saw in 1988 which was basically about how we shouldn't have more Asians here. We shouldn't have Asians in this country. I mean if you scratch most of these characters what you get is a little bit of that sort of talk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly.
—What shame. What absolute disgrace. So it is not once but twice as Prime Minister that you have made major interventions, bringing racism onto the national agenda in a disgraceful way.

PARA.TAB: In terms of Asia, the truth has come out in recent weeks. I have not spent much time reading Mr Hawke's memoirs but I have spent a little bit of time reading them. On top of page 434—

TALK.START.PARA: —Table it.
—No, I cannot table it. I have checked standing orders. I would like to do so. I would like to table page 434 if the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) would let me. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Paul Keating, my successor as Prime Minister, was a late convert to the significance of Asia.

In fact, Mr Hawke has said very clearly that, whilst he was Prime Minister, he had to drag screaming the then Treasurer to go to Tokyo, Japan. He had to get him off the European jumbos to do a fair dinkum visit to Japan; divert him from the French clock visits; divert him from the grand tour of glorious mother Russia, where he vanished for several weeks. He had to be directed to go to Asia.

PARA.TAB: Let us have no nonsense from this man as to who is fair dinkum about Asia. The Leader of the Opposition has been to many Asian countries—Malaysia and so many others I cannot name them all. I have made working visits to some 19 Asian countries. This man only got around to going to Asia with any degree of application when he became Prime Minister. This man, in his work as Prime Minister, has not once but twice injected racism into the national forum, the national agenda, in a disgraceful way. We have caught him out today.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Gerry Hand say?

—As Gerry Hand walked away from Keating on that occasion—Hand rejects Keating's comments—Hand said, `I will not have a bar of this.' He took a principled stand. Gerry Hand did that in 1992. Deep down in your hearts so many of you want to walk far away from the comments and the intervention of Keating yesterday. You will regret those words, and the lady members of the government will also regret those words because they are guilty of the same offence.

PARA.TAB: Interestingly enough, it is the same Ian Taylor—state leader of the Labor Party, if you have forgotten what his role is, in Western Australia; leader of the opposition; quite a nice chap in terms of the personal side of politics, but there is no room for that—who this morning in Perth dumped on his own federal leader, dumped on the Prime Minister, and said that he did not like his style at all and criticised his intervention yesterday.

The one thing about the intervention and comment of the Prime Minister this day is that he denied and deferred—in fact bypassed completely—the accusation in relation to Ian Taylor. We gave you an opportunity to disassociate yourself fully from the actions of Ian Taylor in inviting the League of Rights and members to associate with the shadow cabinet, and you chose not to. In fact, the Prime Minister makes a bit of a habit of this.

We all remember Lateline, for various reasons. We remember the last time you did Lateline. You were asked very directly in relation to this book—not once but twice—`Did you describe Australia as the X end of the world?' Kerry O'Brien was so kind to you that he gave you not one but two opportunities to give a correction. You failed to do so. Why did you fail to do so? Because, sadly, you were guilty of the application of the comment made.

I come to the dispatch box with some sadness. It is no joy to me that the racism banter is around again. I have had my fair share of people from various groupings directing those accusations at me. I must say that, whatever might be the past of decades ago, the National Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you attended any meetings of the League of Rights, Tim?

—I am not going to dignify that interjection with a reply. I have not even extended an invitation to them to come and have morning tea. It is with sadness that we are debating this matter today. But debate it we must, because it is high time the people of Australia realised the real colours of this Prime Minister we have leading this country. It is not just all the words that he chooses to use at the dispatch box from time to time—words that I will not delay the House with—and it is not just his arrogance; it is his double standards. So it was that yesterday at 4.40 p.m. he decided to enter that room where Bob Hawke gave his final press conference as Prime Minister after Keating had knocked him off. Bob Hawke effectively took leave of the prime ministership in that press conference room. Yesterday Keating took leave of his senses in raising this whole question of McCarthyism of the worst kind.

PARA.TAB: Some of us come to politics with the aim of improving the lot of Australians. Some of us come to our deliberations in a parliamentary sitting week with a view to seeing what we can do for our electors as they face drought and a very patchy economic recovery, and as they battle with real life far from the cocoon of Canberra. When we go back to our electorates and see the further deterioration facing so many families in this, the International Year of the Family, people ask us, `Why is the Prime Minister of this country carrying on in his arrogant way, not even defending what he believes about Australia?' They ask, `Why is he bringing racist interventions into the public debate of this country?' They also ask, `Why doesn't he get on with the job of providing some decent parliamentary activity and governance of this country?' This Prime Minister is a man who has failed the responsibilities of his office. But he has done something worse.

If we are going down this track, I think it is time to turn back to some of the exact words written about Jack Lang. I know the Leader of the Opposition made passing reference to this. Either you knew exactly what Jack Lang thought about the migration program and policies of this country or you are a fool. Either you knew what he had written about the Jewish communities of the world and the world banking interests or you are a complete fool. I want to quote from the book The Big Fella by Bede Nairn. Of Lang's policy speech during a state election in New South Wales, Nairn wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: It was also self-revelatory. He shared, with Anstey and other socialists, as well as the members of the boards of the Royal Sydney Golf Club and of the Melbourne Club, in the uneven but widespread anti-Semitism in Australia.

So his references to Niemeyer, whom he regarded, incorrectly, as a Jew, were always accompanied by a special twist to his snarl, an extra rapidity to his swinging hands and stabbing fingers, and a conspiratorial tone to his staccato delivery.

Presumably the Prime Minister has heard of Otto Niemeyer. He has probably heard of the statements named after him by the treasury department. Presumably, the Prime Minister knew, when he sat at the feet of Jack Lang, that these were the views of Jack Lang. Presumably the Prime Minister felt absolutely comfortable in associating with Jack Lang, notwithstanding Jack Lang's deeply held anti-Semitic views.

PARA.TAB: If you are going to go down this path, would you care to explain to the House why it was all right for you to support Jack Lang at every occasion but not for the Leader of the Opposition? You have been caught out as one of the most arrogant prime ministers ever to come to the dispatch box. You have been caught bringing racism into the political agenda of this nation when it is the last thing that you should do. You have been caught out in your substandard attitude to building a proper relationship with Asia in the early days of your political career. You have been exposed time and time again. In these circumstances, there is no doubt in my mind that you should pay the price. You should allow your members to vote the way that they would vote on this motion if given half a chance. You know that you got it wrong yesterday. We know that you got it wrong yesterday.

Even at this 11th hour, we invite the Prime Minister to be man enough to stand up at the dispatch box and apologise to the Leader of the Opposition, apologise for his abuse of his high political office and regret fully the comments that he made not only yesterday but in January 1992.
An opposition member interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He did indeed make them. I have to say that some members of the government might treat this as a laughing matter, but others believe that the Prime Minister has made a truly awful mistake, one which will do damage to the fabric of politics and to community relations right across Australia. It is for this reason that the Prime Minister deserves the total condemnation of this House. He failed to fully dissociate himself from Ian Taylor; he failed to carry high standards into the office of the prime ministership. It is for those reasons that this motion should be carried by this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said, in answer to a question in question time on the subject of Ian Taylor, totally dissociated him from Mr Taylor. I do not quite know what point the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) was trying to make. As it happens, the Prime Minister need not have said that about Ian Taylor. If he had had the information at the beginning of his speech he would have been able to point out several things. He did so very briefly.

PARA.TAB: This censure motion is based on a suggestion that the Leader of the Labor Party in Western Australia knowingly, off his own bat, invited members of the Australian Heritage Society to meet with him.
