We have from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) a conjured up image of the serried ranks of the frontbench of the opposition in Western Australia seeking a personal meeting with the League of Rights front organisation in Western Australia so they could exchange vows and views. An invitation was sent out by the secretary of the associated campaign organisations to 980 organisations in the Helena region.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —In addition, it was augmented. Apparently the Australian Heritage Society was included with 103 names provided from Infolink in the Alexander library as an organisation that had associations in the Helena region. This invitation went out to 1,000 organisations. That is the first point I make. We now know how the invitation ended up in the hands of the League of Rights. What we do not know is how the League of Rights invitation ended up in the hands of the Liberal Party. Is that not an interesting thing to think about?

PARA.TAB: The second point is that the invitation that went out to the Heritage Society was not on the letterhead of the Western Australian branch of the Heritage Society. So ask yourselves: how did the letterhead of the Western Australian branch of the Heritage Society end up in the hands of the Liberal tacticians? These are very interesting questions to think about because it says that for somebody in the Western Australian Liberal Party there is a lock-step relationship with the League of Rights.

Just as the Leader of the Opposition—unknowingly he says and unfortunately for him—has been earning money for the League of Rights for the last seven years as it has retailed his video, and just as people have benefited from that particular link in South Australia there is clearly somebody in the Western Australian Liberal Party who feels as though he or she would benefit from this particular relationship with the League of Rights in Western Australia.

The third point is that the Leader of the Opposition has liked to portray his troubles this week, and they have been many and varied, as a product of the devilishness of the Australian Prime Minister—the Prime Minister's sleeping and waking thought is, `How can I invent yet something else that will slip a torpedo into Alexander?' It is a feature of Alexander's self-obsession that he arrives at this conclusion but, again, his self-obsession does not relate exactly to the truth.

It is pretty well-known about the place that the material that ended up in Laurie Oakes's hands came at some point from the Liberal Party. Quite clearly, he has been subject to destabilisation from that section of the Liberal Party that clearly has no truck with the League of Rights as opposed to the other section of the Liberal Party that receives correspondence from the League of Rights and passes it across to the Liberal Party frontbench team here. That is the second interesting feature of this proposition.

It is not surprising that the Leader of the Opposition should be destabilised in this way, because what has happened to him is a reflection of the way in which he conducts himself in public life and the way in which he treats his colleagues. The most effective cartoon of him this week was not a cartoon about the Leader of the Opposition as a racist—an accusation that has never been levelled at him by people in Australian politics—it was a cartoon of the Leader of the Opposition as a cushion, representing the last backside that sat upon him that might advance his interests. That is the most effective cartoon of the Leader of the Opposition as far as the presentations this week are concerned.

The next thing I would point out about the Leader of the Opposition's habits is this: the Leader of the Opposition is a terrific perpetrator in his party of how he gets some of the most rotten people in his show running for him without directly associating with him. How do you do that? It is your version of statesmanship. You get every ratbag element in your show, use them to destroy your opponents, get close to them, have little chats with them and occasionally rap them over the knuckles and in no circumstances repudiate them.

We have also received other transcripts from Western Australia. Were you not nicely picked up by Howard Sattler this morning when he asked you a question or two about your treatment by the media over the last little while? This is what you had to say in defence of yourself and your little performance with the League of Rights:

SPEECH.PARA: If I had known that years and years later instead of being a backbencher I was going to be the leader of the opposition and the Labor Party was going to run a smear campaign aided and abetted by some of your colleagues in the media, run a smear campaign like this then of course I would have looked at things differently.

In other words, he was saying, `If I thought I was going to be in high office, I would never have attended the League of Rights meeting. Of course, if I had not assumed that, I would have done exactly what I did at that point in time.' Eric Butler has been spending a considerable amount of time, if you have not noticed, over the last couple of days pointing out that he is an honoured, frequent converser with your family—

TALK.START.PARA: —He certainly was not.
—and that you knew exactly what it was that you were attending. You had a chat with him at that meeting.
—That is not true.
—Order!
—It may not be true, but it is what he says.
—Order!
—That is a smear on my whole family.
—Order!
—So sue him. He did not say it in this place; he said it out there—sue him.
—That is a smear; that is hypocrisy.

—You have an opportunity to get out there and sue him; do it. Do not muck around in here arguing with us whether or not Eric Butler is telling the truth about his relationship with you and his attendance at that meeting. Go out there and deal with him yourself. That is what he says and it is not repudiated by you.

PARA.TAB: Another feature of your particular performance in this regard is your double standards in relation to the way in which you treat people in your organisation. Howard Sattler was on to you again on that subject. In relation to your sacking of your predecessor from the frontbench, for what most people would regard as mild peccadilloes, Sattler said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yeah but some people look at him being kicked off the front bench and Chris Miles being left on it and say hang on this is an indication that Alexander Downer perhaps is an extreme right-wing with extremely conservative views.
You replied:
You know that that is wrong, you know that is totally wrong.
Sattler said:
Well why didn't you kick Chris Miles out then?
You replied:

In fact it's an absolutely disgusting thing to say that I am somebody with extreme right-wing views. Anybody who knows me knows that I am the most reasonable and decent sort of person. You can read all of my record Howard, you can read all of my record and no where on my record will you find that I am a purveyor of extremist far right-wing views and I can tell you, I can tell you I won't sit idly by without putting up a fight for that sort of smear and innuendo—
Stamp! `I will not put up with it.' Stamp! That is the performance of a Leader of the Opposition as he sits down and has a chat with his people on the other side. Sattler goes on:
And I mean you have extremists in your party, people who are on your front bench like Chris Miles who runs around the place drumming up anti-sodomist rallies and I mean you support him don't you?
This is what Alexander says to an invitation to support the front bencher who survived:
I don't support everything—everybody in the Liberal Party.
Watch out Chris, you are next on the list for a chop. Sattler goes on:
Well he is on your front bench. I mean you didn't kick him off the front bench like you kicked John Hewson off the front bench.

I do not necessarily have a great deal of time for Howard Sattler, but I suppose that was the obvious question to ask when that was presented. Having just said that he did not support everything that members of the Liberal Party said, he says:

I make the judgments about those sorts of things but as far as the Liberal Party is concerned there is obviously a breadth of views in the Liberal Party and it is not everybody in the Liberal Party agrees with you. That doesn't mean that they are subject to pillory.
Only if they are John Hewson. If they are John Hewson they are subject to pillory but if they are Chris Miles they are put up with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to members by their titles.

—This has been your record in the South Australian Liberal Party over the last decade. You get up there with the moderates and you kick them to death in all the party functions that you get to. But then you say, `It wasn't me who did it. It was really all those right wing uglies, like Minchin and the others. They are the ones who are really after you. I am a softening influence on their behaviour. I am merely the greasy bottom fish who hangs around waiting for the crumbs to fall off the savaging of the sharks or the poor minnows in the Liberal Party left in South Australia. I feed on the bottom, and feeding on the bottom has put me on the top as far as the Liberal Party is concerned in dealing with the moderates.' That is why you find yourself in the trouble in which you find yourself.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately in national politics, there are very good sonar mechanisms and we pick up the greedy little bottom fish that hang around waiting for the skerricks that fall out of the savaging of the sharks, and we know who benefits. There are a few people in the media who know who benefits, too. Those people in the media from time to time are inclined to draw that to public attention and say one or two things about it. And when they say one or two things about it what they get from you is a stamped foot and a little peroration on how it wasn't you. Well, I know something of the college that you were educated in and I know why you are like that. It is the classic mechanism of a bully defending against a superior bully.

When you have an inferior bully, an inferior person, before you, somebody weak like your former leader, you know exactly what you do. When you have a superior bully like the right wing uglies in your organisation you know what to do too. `Oh no, Ponsonby, I didn't say that. That was Bernard Hassett-Smythe. I couldn't possibly have said that.' `Oh, no Bernard Hassett-Smythe, I didn't say that. Ponsonby may tell you that I told Ponsonby that, but it wasn't him; it was Wellesley. Wellesley was the person who told you that, not Ponsonby.' `Don't beat me, please Wellesley. It had nothing to do with me at all. It was Bernard Hassett-Smythe or perhaps it was even Ponsonby, but it wasn't me.'

You can never find the origins of Alexander. That is one of the real problems with Alexander's views—they are not there. Black is white as far as Alexander is concerned in his public presentation. `I say one thing and somebody else says another thing but I didn't say that. But when I am caught out, I am put upon.' `I was put upon to have pot, not because I enjoyed it.' `I was put upon to support foreign investment because I was employed by the Chamber of Manufactures.' `I was put upon by the Liberal Party to oppose foreign investment because our public opinion survey said that I ought to evade that.' `I was put upon by the Western Australian Liberals to say that I opposed the Mabo legislation and would repeal it when I got back into office and when I come over here I had nothing to do with that at all. I want to isolate myself in little pockets as to where I appear around the country.'

It is no accident that, when confronted by somebody like yourself, there are occasions when your views might be misunderstood. Right thinking people in the public who see contrary reviews are likely to interpret them in contrary ways. As far as this place is concerned, you must be the first Leader of the Opposition that has had a major Western Australian daily newspaper say in its editorial, after you have led the opposition for 100 days, that you preside over a party which is disintegrating. A great political force under your care has fallen apart.

That was the verdict of the Telegraph Mirror about your leadership before this week began. It ought not to be in a position where it is obliged to revise its judgment at the end of it. What a stupid tactic to get up a round robin letter sent out by the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia and expose the fact that you receive information from the League of Rights. As a result of it, you are worthy of the censure motion that has been put upon you. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COSTELLO
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had one of the usual buffoonish performances from Billy Bunter who masquerades as the Leader of the House. If I were you, my friend, I would not come into this place and start talking about other people's fathers. Your father has a lot of respect around this place. One of the things I have always respected about him is his famous statement that when he joined the Labor Party it comprised the cream of the working class and that when he left it it had the dregs of the middle class.

PARA.TAB: I have always thought to myself: how could a father have so unintentionally described his son? He comes into this place as the dregs of the middle class, with all the privileges that he had, and he carries on with absolute buffoonery. He stands here, stamps his feet and goes on with imagined names and fictional examples. He is no foot stamper; he is the foot sloucher. He stands here with his foot on the seat and goes into fantasies about what may or may not have happened. But he can never deal with the facts; he can never answer the charges; he can never make a reasonable, coherent case.

The reasonable, coherent case on this occasion is that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) stands absolutely condemned through his behaviour yesterday. The Prime Minister does not own that office. He should have no truck in demeaning that great office as he did yesterday in the way that he carried on.

TALK.START.PARA: —A position Alexander will never hold.

—Don't you start intervening. You demean the office of Attorney-General the way you were carrying on before. You ought to think sometimes when you make these accusations and let them fly across the table that you are the first law officer of the Crown and you ought to have some respect for the position that you hold.

PARA.TAB: In our society the strongest condemnation is reserved for racism. Racism is a hateful thing; racism degrades human dignity. Racism demeans people on the basis of their birth and things over which they have no control. We have seen in this century racism that ends in murder and genocide. There is a natural revulsion in our society for racism, and there should always be.

I give the government this warning: if you want to throw this label around, if you want to start applying it as a term of politic abuse, you will demean yourselves and you will demean the cause of tolerance in Australia. If you want to start throwing around this label of abuse and start calling decent, tolerant people racists, the people out there are going to think there is nothing wrong with that label.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not. Who has? Who has? Who has done that? Who has called anyone a racist? Fraud!
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory.

—If you start running around and using it as a term of political abuse, you will run out of language to identify and condemn despicable behaviour when you see it. Nothing could be more damaging to the cause of anti-racism than to go slinking around and using this as a term of political abuse. At the end of the day, if you cry wolf too many times, you will run out of the ability to warn the Australian public when it does see a wolf coming along. You will run out of the ability to condemn despicable behaviour. You will run out of the ability to adequately condemn that kind of behaviour.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday the Prime Minister let himself down; he let the great office of Prime Minister down; he let the nation of Australia down; and he let the people of Australia down with the grubby politics of smear and innuendo. Yesterday he was too clever to be caught saying that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) was a racist, but he was clever enough to slide around, trying to make sure that the newspapers ran it and trying to put that heavy implication on somebody who is decent and tolerant and does not deserve that kind of opprobrium, regardless of what his political views might be in opposition to the Labor Party. If you start trying to run the politics of racism and abuse on that person, you will not help the cause of tolerance in Australia. You will turn this into a political football. You will excite passions and the very things that responsible leaders would not intend to do.

There was a subliminal text yesterday, and everybody knew it. The Prime Minister could not get out there quickly enough to try to run a subliminal agenda. If you want to know what a decent politician would have done yesterday, you need only look at what the Treasurer (Mr Willis) did. The Treasurer was given the opportunity to run the subliminal text in a press conference at 1.15 p.m. A journalist asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Would you be seen dead on the same platform as Eric Butler?
That was a nice lollipop; it could have run the agenda. The Treasurer said:
How does he come into the conversation? It's a very bizarre question you're asking.

The Treasurer is a decent man who sticks to the issues. He may be wrong on some of these issues, but he sticks to the issues. But the Prime Minister could not control himself, could he? He had the tongue of a viper and the morals of a snake as he sat there and watched question time yesterday. He knew that it was time to run out the subliminal text in relation to the Leader of the Opposition. When he was asked whether he believed that the Leader of the Opposition had anti-Semitic views, the Prime Minister said, `It's hard to explain that he addressed the League of Rights meeting.' Do you know what a decent person would have done? A decent person would have said, `Of course not.'

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say it.

—He came into the parliament and said it today, you fool. Why could he not have said it at the press conference yesterday? That was the absolute proof. He did not believe it. He said it in the parliament today, but he wanted to run it for 24 hours. You absolute dolt; can you not understand that? You are 24 hours off the pace. He could have said that at the press conference yesterday. He had the opportunity to say it. He could have stuck to the issues, but he wanted to let the newspapers run that story for 24 hours. Anybody who knows anything about politics knew that would happen, complete with Channel 7 showing goosesteppers in its report. Talk about inflaming the press!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Shame! Shame!

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute shame on Channel 7 for doing it. Anybody who had been around would have known how the cartoonists would deal with this. Anybody with political instinct would have known that you had to light only a little bit of a match to get a flame going out there. You do it over and over again.

PARA.TAB: The end point of this is that you are not advancing tolerant and open debate in this country. You are trying to throw around labels of political abuse that ought to be reserved for heinous conduct. Today the Prime Minister said, `Oh, I don't think the Leader of the Opposition is an anti-Semite.' What qualifies the Prime Minister to be a judge of this? If we go back through people's records, we can see that the Prime Minister's criteria and qualifications are not suitable for him to be a judge on this particular issue.

This is the man who was boasting about the way in which Lang had given him political tutelage. He was boasting about how he used to have these sessions two days a week. He was boasting about how he used to read the Century, the magazine that Lang used to put out. The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: I like politics, I always have.

The masthead on Jack Lang's old newspaper, the Century, used to say that politics governs your life from cradle to grave. He used to read the Century; he knew what Jack Lang was on about, as the Leader of the Opposition read out to the parliament. Let us have a look at the kinds of things that used to be in the magazine that the mentor of the Prime Minister used to publish—how he used to complain about people coming into Australia, under headlines like, `Palestinian problem reaches Australia'. That article said:

Instead of making a contribution to the productive effort of the country, many of them prefer a parasitic life. So they dabble in black market commerce. When they arrive they immediately create Australian ghettoes.

Have we heard a condemnation of Jack Lang from the Prime Minister? Have you ever heard it? Did he stand up today and say he condemned it? Did he condemn the Century newspaper? Did he walk away from the fact that all of his political instincts and training came from this man? Did you hear anything like that from this man who is now parading himself as the great judge? Of course you didn't.

PARA.TAB: Did you hear anything in relation to Graeme Campbell? Let me tell you, in the last 24 hours there has only been one person out there spruiking for the League of Rights, and he sits on that side of the parliament. He sits on that side of the parliament, trying to tell Australians that there is nothing wrong with the League of Rights, trying to tell them that it is raising legitimate issues. He is sitting on that side of the parliament. There was even a piece in the Good Weekend by Gerard Henderson entitled `The lunar right rising', and who do they the pull out as an authority on the League of Rights? They pull out Mr Graeme Campbell. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Campbell told the Canberra Times's David Sibley that while he had been critical of the League in the past, it was now `moving to become a mainstream conservative organisation'.

Let me tell you who is out there defending them, who is out there appearing on platforms with them—it is somebody who the Prime Minister is quite happy to rely on for a vote to make him Prime Minister; he is not prepared to condemn him, not prepared to discipline him, not prepared to expel him. He is quite prepared to rely on his vote when it helps make him Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Yet, we had this absolute charade yesterday—`unfit to be the Leader of the Opposition'; subliminal racism attacks being run against the Leader of the Opposition as the Prime Minister tries to run this illegitimate agenda, as he tries to engage in the politics of political abuse. We can all do it. I can do it against you. Tomorrow you can do it against me. But if it is done, at the end of the day no Australian politician is going to be sticking to the issues and no informed debate is going to be happening and, when you do find real racists, you are going to run out of language to describe them. You are going to run out of the language of condemnation that you need.

If the Prime Minister was really upset, you would have thought he would have been out there on that; you would have thought he would have been out there on Ian Taylor. Now we are told Mr Taylor did not know what he was doing. He knew enough to find out the name of Mrs Burton, the person who was in the Australian Heritage Society. He knew enough to let it go out on a flier that was printed and authorised by Ian Taylor MLA, Parliament House, Perth. He knew enough to make sure that the place and the time was there for the whole of his shadow cabinet.

The Prime Minister is over here in Canberra ripping up Australia as if there is some great heinous act being done when he has got a Leader of the Opposition out the same week. Where do you people get off? In relation to Ian Taylor, we had the Prime Minister on 9 March 1994 saying `the Leader of the Opposition, Ian Taylor, is a very able fellow'. He referred to our having to run this country cooperatively between the Commonwealth and state governments `and with local government, I might say, the idea that certain things of the states and certain things of the Commonwealth . . .' . Did you know he said that, Attorney-General—certain things of the states and certain things of the Commonwealth?

Where would he be preaching that message? Oh, Western Australia. I wonder why he would be preaching that sort of message in Western Australia. He would not be the kind of person who went to Western Australia and talked about states rights and came back to Canberra and talked about the need to centralise power in the Commonwealth, would he? He would not be a person who tailored his message, would he? He would not be the kind of person who got over there in Western Australia and talked about states rights in a way he would never do here, would he? Of course he would be, because he is one of the great masters of changing his language, one of the great masters of narrowcasting his messages, one of the great masters of sending out the subliminal text, one of the great masters of smear and innuendo and abuse.

There is no person that has single-handedly demeaned Australian politics more in the last 10 years than the Prime Minister. He is the person who has changed all of the rules. When people come into this parliament and ask, `What has happened to the standards?' I say to them one thing—Keating. That is what has pulled the standards down in Australia. That is what has changed the rules. That is what has led to the language we hear. That is what has opened the gate to this subliminal text. That is what has got Australia into these sorts of discussions. This is the man that does not deal in the facts. This is the one that will not be scrupulous. He will not be scrupulous and he will not give the opportunity to deny these stories before they start. This is the one that wanted to do entirely the different thing. This is the one that ought to be censured in this House today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) finished by talking about the rules of this place. Any experienced member of this place knows that if he has been subject to an allegation that is not true or has been misled in a press report he has a very simple process available to him. Under the standing orders he can rise in his place and indicate that he has been misrepresented. I honestly thought yesterday that the Leader of the Opposition would refer to the press reports concerning his speaking at a League of Rights conference and say, quite frankly, as was suggested from his office right from the outset, that he had been misrepresented. At that stage, if there was any misrepresentation, it was not coming out of the office of the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition could have stood in his place and said, `It has been suggested that I spoke to the League of Rights conference. I want the House to know that when that conference took place I believed I was responding to an invitation from a religious group. I want the House to know that I deplore the League of Rights. I condemn its anti-semitism. I condemn its racism.' Then he could have sat down. I, for one, and every member of this House, would have been pleased to accept that statement.

We must ask ourselves why that statement was not made. If it had been made, the matter would have ended there. It was simple and it was appropriate. But the real problem is that if you make that sort of statement to this House and it turns out not to be true and accurate, you are in deep trouble. We, as members, are bound to accept a statement along those lines on the basis that the member making that explanation is telling the truth.

Why did it not happen? I spent some time looking at the material in respect of this matter. Quite frankly, I represent an electorate where many people have suffered as a result of racism and the terms `racism' and `anti-semitism' are not to be used lightly. Too many people have suffered. So there was, as one would expect, a press briefing. What was said on the first occasion of that press briefing to a bevy of journalists? He confirmed he had spoken to a seminar in 1987 but believed it was organised by a Christian group to discuss the constitution and was unaware of any connection with the League of Rights. If Mr Butler was there, he was unaware of it. He was unaware of his presence, and would not have recognised him anyway.

That was not a statement confected in the office of the Prime Minister; that was a statement made for and on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition by his relevant press officer. The difficulty with that—

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't know about the video.

—You have taken the words out of my mouth. The problem for him was that that was only version one. So I went and looked at some of the videoed questions to see what version two was. When asked on a Channel 9 program whether he had ever been on a League of Rights platform, he started to say, `If I have been'—the implication, of course, being that he might have been—but then he paused, stopped, changed tack and said, `Sure I've been on platforms where there have been people from the League of Rights around. I have never given any support to the league.' What is the reasonable inference from that? That he was an honest, decent fellow who had gone along to a meeting and there could have been some League of Rights people there? I do not know how he would have known. They do not actually walk around with big badges which say `I am in the League of Rights'—but it could have been the case. That was version two.

PARA.TAB: Now we have version three. At this stage, who enters the debate? Eric Butler. Let me say quite candidly and openly that, having regard to Eric Butler's record, I was hoping desperately that the Leader of the Opposition was telling the truth. Let me read out what Eric Butler said in a press interview. At this stage nothing had been said by the office of the Leader of the Opposition. He started off almost in a fatherly way:
He was very young. He would have known about the League when asked to participate in a seminar on the Constitution.
I was there and took the opportunity of saying I was pleased to see him there.

SPEECH.PARA: This hardly fits the description of people from the League of Rights. As the videos show, Eric Butler was not just acting like a father figure, saying `nice of you to come'; he was sharing the platform with the Leader of the Opposition. Who else was on the platform with him? Jeremy Lee. Let me remind the honourable gentleman opposite—and for the benefit of those who may be uninformed—that Mr Jeremy Lee is a full-time officer of the League of Rights, and he was the sponsor of notorious revisionist historian David Irving, who would have us believe that the Holocaust did not happen. That was the person who was prevented by a minister of this government from coming to Australia.

PARA.TAB: Young Alexander had been a political adviser to a prime minister, had been in the parliament since 1984 and had actually been picked to lead a delegation to the United States. The League of Rights had been established in South Australia since 1940. I suppose you could not really expect a young politician—who had been bred for the job—

TALK.START.PARA: —Born to rule.

—You could not expect him—born to rule—to know, for example, that the League of Rights had been there for many years. Let me read the interview given by Mr Butler on AM this morning. He was asked whether the invitation came from the League of Rights, and he answered `Yes'. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was arranged by the late Mr Frank Bawden, who was the State Director in South Australia at the time.
But you could not expect a young politician to know that! He continued:

And he arranged it and he informed me—I was National Director—that that was what we were going to do. And I said: That's fine with me. So I wasn't surprised at all because we've had, as I've said, a wide variety of people that have appeared on League platforms over the years. And sometimes there's pressure put on them.
This question was asked:
So how was Mr Downer approached—normally, I guess, a letter, then a follow-up telephone call?
Eric Butler responded:
Relying on my memory, I would say that he was probably rung up and approached in that way.
Then this question:
I mean, obviously when you're approaching people to speak that you would have to say where you're coming from. You have no reason to doubt . . .
Mr Butler interceded:

. . . seen tonights showing of the video which one of the stations obtained somehow. There's no argument that Mr Frank Bawden, State Director of the League, was on the platform and opened the proceedings. And Mr Downer did refer to him.
The next question:
So he would have known who he was and where he came from?
Mr Butler said:
I can't speak, but I'd be amazed if he didn't. In fact, I'd be staggered.
To round it off, he was asked:
So, for an invitation to be put to Mr Downer, it would be a matter of it coming under the name of the League of Rights, wouldn't it?
This was his answer:
Oh yes, definitely, I would have thought so, yes. Mr Bawden wouldn't misrepresent himself. He'd represent himself as the State Director of the League of Rights.
Question:
So you are under the impression that there's no way that Mr Downer could have not known where he was going to speak and who he was addressing?
Answer:

Well, I can only say that, without getting involved in the controversy, I can only say that I would be surprised if he didn't. But it's conceivable that, well I'd find it hard to believe that he didn't know. I don't know.
Question:
You were there on the occasion . . .
Answer:
That's right, I was the second speaker.
Question:
And also Jeremy Lee . . .
Answer:
I can't say whether he would or whether he wouldn't, but I presume he knew who I was.
Question:
Had you met him before that?
Answer:
I had not met him before that, but if you'll look at the video . . .

They took a video, and it was so impressive—this young politician with these two full-time officials of the League of Rights—that they sold it for a profit to make funds for the League of Rights. With the sensitivity that is now operating, of course, it has been taken off the market. I would think this discussion would cause the price to go up, but we will all be able to buy it in due course. Mr Butler, referring to the Leader of the Opposition, said:

I had not met him before that, but if you'll look at the video and get the recording there you'll find that I followed Mr Downer's address and took the opportunity, on a personal note, referring to the fact that I had known his late father for some time, both before he went to the United Kingdom as the High Commissioner, met him on several occasions in Adelaide, primarily to discuss one of my books with him which he read, `The red pattern of world conquest'. And then, of course, when he went to the UK, after 1962 I was in the UK every year for the next 10 years lecturing on the common market issue, and Mr Downer, as anyone who checks the records will find, he was strongly opposed to the British entry. And so naturally I had something to do with him.

Isn't that nice? I am not going to blame the Leader of the Opposition for his father's friends. Young Alexander was probably away at boarding school and did not know. But when you look at this record, what you learn is why the Leader of the Opposition was not prepared to come in here and address this House—and he still has not—and say, `I made a mistake. I did not know that.' The record shows that he met Butler; Butler referred to him in the most generous of terms; and on the video Mr Downer is referring to `Eric'. It was not Eric the Viking, and it certainly was not Eric the Red; it might have been Eric Butler.

PARA.TAB: So they were on first name terms. I do not deduce from that that the Leader of the Opposition is an anti-Semite or a racist. I believe that the problem is the way in which he has handled this House, knowing the problems he would have if he misled the parliament. The real allegation is not that he is a racist or an anti-Semite but that he is a political dill. This performance shows the same merit he showed when he went to the Northern Territory without getting briefed on the land rights act. He made a mess of it and said that he was emotionally upset because he saw a corroboree. The only problem is that he made his statement before he saw the corroboree.

The Leader of the Opposition confected this argument today whereby he said, `It's all the fault of the Prime Minister and the media. I'm just misunderstood. I want to be the brave, great, true and glorious leader of this pack.' Let me say for the benefit of that pack that members, particularly of the National Party, have stood up in this House and condemned the League of Rights for what it is—a racist organisation. We are still waiting to hear from the Leader of the Opposition. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a pathetic performance by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding). I want to explain to the House why it was so pathetic. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware that before the House today is a letter from the honourable member for Melbourne Ports which proposes that we debate a matter of public importance. We will not have the debate; we have had the censure motion instead. The letter says that we ought to be debating today:

PARA.TAB: The urgent need for the Government to promote racial harmony by strengthening the Racial Discrimination Act to confront racial and other hatreds and the need for Members to reject the insidious influence of the League of Rights on Australian public life as demonstrated by the current controversy surrounding the League.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Melbourne Ports proposed that we debate that subject. The speech he just gave was a speech to support his matter of public importance. It was not a speech to either support the government's amendment or oppose the coalition's censure motion. I say to the honourable member for Melbourne Ports that his speech is positive proof of the basis upon which we have moved our censure motion.

PARA.TAB: For the interest of those listening, I will recite the censure motion, which is what we are actually debating, not the MPI that was submitted earlier at the instruction of the tacticians within the Labor Party. We are debating this motion of censure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating):
That this House censures the Prime Minister for discrediting the high office of Prime Minister by making unfounded, divisive and racist allegations for his own base political ends.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has moved an amendment to it which is basically a bucket on the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer).

PARA.TAB: The nub of what we are saying in the censure motion, and the reason why objective and reasonable members on both sides of the House, including members of the Labor Party, ought to support our censure motion is that this government, with the leadership of the Prime Minister, has set out deliberately to make an unfounded racist slur and allegation against the Leader of the Opposition and, by implication, all members of the coalition.

The honourable member for Melbourne Ports said at the conclusion of his remarks—talk about being a dolt, as one of my colleagues described another member on the other side—`We're not saying that the Leader of the Opposition is racist. Our attack is on his credibility.' We did not come down in the last shower. Of course he was attacking his credibility. Governments attack our credibility every day of the week, as we attack your credibility. Do not give us a lot of ammunition for attacking your credibility.

This is not about the conduct of the Leader of the Opposition. What you have set out deliberately to do in the last few days is manufacture a nasty little racist slur. That is the basis of our motion to censure the Prime Minister. The reason we find that so despicable and the reason we are prepared to stand here and take it to the government and to fight on this issue is that we believe it is against the national interest for a Prime Minister, for the most blatantly political motives, to take a sensitive issue such as race and harmony within our Australian society and use it for his own political ends.

As Prime Minister, his job is to build good policy in the interests of all Australians. Under our political process, he was not finally installed in the Lodge to pursue his own political benefits and discard the national interest. We are all well and truly aware that in politics a lot of argy-bargy and trivia goes out through the media. We all know that a lot of silly things are said. I suppose that, in politics, you take it most days and you give as good as you get.

The public is pretty sensible about most of these things. The public can see that politics is often just a stage and that the players come and deliver their lines. Some players are more permanently on the stage than the others. Many Australians have a certain commonsense understanding about politics.

But yesterday the Prime Minister went beyond the standards which we believe ought to be set by the Prime Minister. Again, most Australians appreciate that, whatever you think of the Prime Minister, from time to time he has been known to reach to the almighty depths of public debate. Yesterday was one of those occasions.

I suppose that if we say anything to him, we say, `When you so demean the office of the Prime Minister, we are going to deliver it back to you, because we have an obligation, as a coalition and an opposition in this parliament, to do all that is within our power to maintain proper standards.' We do that because, ultimately, we believe that the Australian people are entitled to good government. Good government has to be based on proper standards and reasonable principles. When you descend to the depths as you did yesterday, you deserve a censure motion, which we have moved. We did not win the last election. We do not have the numbers, so we will lose the censure motion. But we will win the point morally. Ultimately, I believe that that is what really counts.

The government is running a campaign. It is the usual argy-bargy of politics. The Prime Minister's remarks yesterday were classic Keating. He was advised not to turn up to question time, because every now and then he goes completely over the top. He treats question time with absolute contempt, which is just treating the public with contempt because it is their chance to hold the government to account. Yesterday he was not in question time. He was seething about this issue. He was stung by some comments by the Leader of the Opposition, so he barged into his office and said, `I'm going to do a doorstop and get that Downer.' I have seen it so many times in his political career. He went too far.

Let me just briefly recount the facts. So often, the facts are just completely dismissed. You would never know what this was all about unless you were an aficionado of politics. But it really is quite simple: let us not let the facts get in the way of a good story. It might be the government's line, but it is not ours.

In 1987, there was quite a debate about constitutional reform. As a general rule, I think debate is healthy and ought to be encouraged. Citizens ought to be encouraged to be informed about their constitution and to think about it. In 1987, at a time of growing constitutional discussion, which led ultimately to a full referendum being placed before the people in 1988, the Leader of the Opposition, who was then a backbencher—in fact, he had just been dumped from the front bench—had an invitation to attend some function in Adelaide or somewhere. It was not an invitation by the League of Rights but by some other crowd whose name is irrelevant for our purposes. It was at a Christian hall somewhere. He was asked, `Would you come along and speak about the constitution?' As many of us have done on many occasions—as politicians, we are paid to go out and debate and put a point of view—he fronted up to a meeting.

He was introduced by a bloke called Eric. I might just pause here. Eric Butler is, as people apparently know, a leading member of the League of Rights. He founded it and he is an activist within that organisation. On television last night we saw film clips of a video taken at the time and, on the front page of the Age, we saw a photo with the caption, `Mr Downer meets Mr Eric Butler'. The fact is that apparently it was not Eric Butler at all. The film clip which says `Thanks, Eric' was not referring to Eric Butler. It was Eric somebody else. It could have been Eric the butler for all we know, but it was not Eric Butler, although he might have been there.

Talk about a gross exaggeration. It shows you how these things snowball completely out of proportion. The Leader of the Opposition fronted up to some meeting organised by some crowd not known as the League of Rights. To my knowledge, he was not told that it was the League of Rights. He has always denounced that group in his political career. No-one in his right mind would suggest that Alexander Downer was anything other than a mainstream Australian politician with some strongly held views, with a sense of compassion and with a sense of public service. He spoke for 20 minutes, finished his speech, had a cup of coffee or something to be polite—he probably wanted to get back to his family—and then he shot through.

This is supposed to be a matter of appalling judgment, a matter of national controversy. In fact, the Prime Minister yesterday said that it was a crime. Talk about going over the top! This bloke has really got a screw loose, and yesterday was one of those days when he went completely over the top. But the crunch came when the Prime Minster was asked by a journalist, `Do you really think that Alexander Downer has anti-Semitic views?' The Prime Minister said, `Well, it is hard to explain why he has addressed a League of Rights meeting.' That is just outrageous. The journalist continued, `Is the crime that he addressed the meeting or that he won't own up to it?' `Both,' said the Prime Minister.

In fact, we are told that the Leader of the Opposition went to the meeting, had his 20-minute burst, left and a few weeks later somebody from an Australian-Jewish organisation rang up and said, `Look, that crowd was actually a front for the League of Rights,' and the Leader of the Opposition immediately denounced it. For heaven's sake, we politicians are on platforms day in and day out. I do not mind saying that I believe I have been at functions to which the public has been invited and there have been members of the League of Rights there. I denounce them and, furthermore, I denounce all that they stand for. That is the standard.

As the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) so succinctly pointed out, the Prime Minister yesterday was not prepared to say that the Leader of the Opposition was anti-Semitic but today he came in here with a different tactic. I would say that the backroom tactic discussion this morning was, `This has got a bit out of hand. Let's back-pedal a bit.' So the Prime Minister back-pedalled and said, `I am not saying he is anti-Semitic.' We said, `But, Prime Minister, you said that yesterday and what you said yesterday is the reason we are censuring you today.' Even the honourable member for Melbourne Ports, who spoke on his matter of public importance—which was irrelevant—ought to be voting with us today.

I want to say one other thing: this whole question of guilt by association is a common tactic. This is not the first time that the Labor Party has run it and it is not the last time it will run it. It is a favourite tactic of the Labor Party, as the matter of public importance itself demonstrates. In 1992 when Keating tried to run this against Dr Hewson, Gerry Hand—and you have to give him this—a member of the Labor Party and a minister at the time, publicly rejected the Prime Minister's attempts to run a racist slur. If you are a Labor voter and you try to judge this, you do not have to take what I say. Take what Gerry Hand said back in 1982 because he knew a racist slur campaign from the Labor Party. For heaven's sake, he has been part of the Labor Party and knows the tactics of the Labor Party.

It is particularly sinister and nasty to try to attack somebody on the basis that, because they may be associated with somebody or a concept, they ought to be condemned. I will tell you why it is sinister. As members of parliament, we actually have an obligation to consider issues on their merits. Australia is a great country and, even with the disappointments of recent years under Labor, this country has a good future. But it really has a good future only if, when we sit down to make decisions about our future, we do so on the merits of those decisions. Let us take the Evatt Foundation as an example. The Evatt Foundation comprises a left wing crowd. If the Evatt Foundation puts up an idea and I dismiss it because it comes from a left winger, and if I abrogate my responsibility to consider issues on their merits, we all fail in our duty.

I am not prepared to put up with a charge of guilt by association. That is an invitation to walk away from our responsibilities as members of parliament. We have a pretty good parliamentary democracy in this country because, by and large, most people are bona fide. But, if we allow guilt by association to be a tactic that can be successfully employed against us, we walk away from our responsibility. I say this to the Labor Party: we will take you on every time. If you want five, six or 10 speakers today, we are going to stand here and fight you because we will not put up with racist slurs. We will not put up with unfounded, divisive, racist slurs from the Labor Party. Our censure motion ought to be supported. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor Mr G.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed timely for the House to be debating this motion today, given the public controversy which has erupted in the last couple of days over a speaking appearance by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) at a public meeting in South Australia in 1987, organised apparently by the League of Rights or an association closely aligned with it.

PARA.TAB: Let us strip the rhetoric away and look at this issue for what it is. We have had the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) in this House blaming the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for putting this particular issue on the agenda today. Let me remind the House and honourable members opposite that it was the member for Mayo who appeared on the same platform as the League of Rights; it was the member for Mayo who told the Australian people that he thought it was an invitation he accepted from an elderly couple; and it was the member for Mayo who failed to stand up in this parliament yesterday and defend him himself, as was outlined by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding). He had the opportunity and he backed away from it. Because he backed away from it, we have had the spectacle here today of a ragged opposition fighting a rearguard action for a leader it wants to remove but cannot for political reasons.

There are very compelling reasons why the member for Mayo ought to immediately—and I mean immediately—resign as Leader of the Opposition. The central issue in this debate is not the issue of free speech, and it never has been, and it is not the issue of McCarthyism or a member's right to attend a public meeting organised by the league, one of its front organisations or any other organisation in the Australian community. The central issue in this debate is whether the Leader of the Opposition knew that the meeting he so effusively spoke at in 1987 in South Australia was organised by the league or should have been aware by the personnel present at that particular meeting that the League of Rights was heavily involved.

The member for Mayo has told the Australian people that he thought the meeting he attended was organised by a Christian group. If anybody really believes that explanation, they really do believe that leprechauns and fairies are at the end of the garden. The member for Mayo might try to pull the hood down over the eyes of the Australian people but they know—and the people on this side of the House know—that it is inconceivable that the member for Mayo did not know who was involved in the meeting he chose to address. He must be the only parliamentarian in this place in 1987 who was able to get up on the same platform as Eric Butler and Jeremy Lee and then later say to the Australian people that he really did not believe, he really did not understand or he really was not aware that this was a front for the League of Rights or indeed a function organised by the League of Rights.

He has betrayed his fellow members in the coalition. It is not very often that I hand out bouquets to my political opponents in this House, but I take my hat off to those members of the National Party who, throughout the 1980s, waged an incessant battle against the League of Rights. How disappointing it must have been for them in 1987 to see the member for Mayo stab them in the back and turn the knife by appearing at a function that was organised by the league or by one of its front organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend to members opposite the speech Senator Boswell made to alert the Australian community to this political organisation. As members of this parliament, we may not always have the liberty of choosing the issues upon which we are called to speak. But we can choose the forum in which we debate the issues. On the occasion in 1987, the member for Mayo chose the issue and he chose the venue. In doing so he bestowed a political legitimacy on an organisation which has been roundly condemned by his coalition partners, roundly condemned by members of his own party and members of his backbench and, indeed, roundly condemned by community groups.

PARA.TAB: What do his coalition partners in the National Party have to say about the League of Rights? You would not get the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) appearing at a League of Rights function. In an article in a Sunday edition of the Age in 1990, the member for Gippsland was reported as saying:
My major objection is they are subverting the political system, deliberately working to wreck it.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the attitude expressed on the public record by the member for Gippsland, a coalition partner of the member for Mayo. How disappointing it must have been for him to be stabbed in the back by the member for Mayo as he cavorted about the community speaking at these sorts of functions organised by one of the most racist organisations that this community has ever seen.

PARA.TAB: Let me give the honourable member for Mayo a few lessons and a few tips on how the league operates in rural and urban communities. The league selects an issue of concern to the local community—whether it be the issue of fluoridation, council amalgamations, or the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. The league then organises a public meeting for the forum to discuss the selected issue. It invites prominent members of the community to speak at these gatherings. That gives the league and its front organisations the political legitimacy to operate.

SPEECH.PARA: The unsuspecting people in this equation are the public. They come along to hear a sensible debate on an issue and they leave with a kit bag of the league's most putrid racist propaganda. The Leader of the Opposition invoked Isi Leibler in his defence here this afternoon. Mr Isi Leibler, the President of the Executive Council of Australian Jewry, put out a publication in 1985. Under the heading `The League of Rights and You', it states:

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this booklet has been to inform the public, and especially anyone who may be invited to address the League, of its history and true nature.

SPEECH.PARA: To summarise . . .
—For thirty-eight years the League has propagated and spread hatred of the Jewish people in the manner of the Nazis.

—The League has always been an extremist group, denouncing at various times ethnic minorities, Aborigines, European and non-European migrants, and nearly all mainstream politicians in the A.L.P., the Liberal, and the National Parties.

PARA.TAB: The conclusion is inescapable that the League of Rights is a menace to Australian democracy. By taking part in the activities of the League of Rights, by addressing it, by sharing a platform with any of its members, concerned Australians who may otherwise oppose the League and what it stands for, run the risk of granting it the legitimacy it so desperately seeks, diminishing Australian democracy and increasing the strength of political extremism.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Mayo's propensity for making chummy appearances with the leading lights of the league is really not shared by the Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett. In 1985, as Leader of the Opposition, he banned state Liberal politicians from being on the same platform as the league. That was over an issue of Aboriginal land rights at Lake Condah in the western district of Victoria. Obviously, that exhortation by the leader of the Liberal Party in 1985 was not an exhortation that was understood or accepted by the current Leader of the Opposition, the member for Mayo, in 1987.

PARA.TAB: I have some experience in this matter with the League of Rights. I was a councillor with the city of Colac in 1990. There was extreme public controversy over the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. People attended a public rally; they were disturbed with what they were told and with the literature they were given at the rally. On further investigation, I found that the operatives of the league in the western district of Victoria were involved in organising the meeting. I felt it was my public duty to inform the people of the western district exactly what was going on in their area. I did it not to say to them, `You should not attend this particular meeting.' I wanted to let them know the type of people who were behind the organisation of the meeting. People went to the meeting genuinely over one issue and came away with a lot of racist propaganda about another.

After I had made public statements on this matter, I was threatened with a defamation suit by an operative of a front organisation of the League of Rights. A Sydney barrister named George Turner rang my home to inform me that he was prepared to sue me for defamation. He did not get me on the phone; he got my teenage son. He proceeded to intimidate my family with statements such as, `We will sue your father for every penny he has. You will not have a house to live in.' He did not do that only to me. He did it to a friend of mine who was also engaged in this debate. When he rang my friend's house, my friend's 14-year-old daughter answered the phone, and he did the same thing.

Let me tell honourable members a little about the Constitutional Heritage Protection Society, which this particular operative belongs to. This organisation is a particularly peculiar one. I will refer to the sort of literature that comes out of the fronts of the league—the front organisations that attend the sorts of meetings that the Leader of the Opposition so easily got sucked into. The Constitutional Heritage Protection Society produced a document called the `First and Last Discussion Papers'. The organisation that is involved in defending the great Australian constitution had this to say in that document:

In any event you should be more alert from now on. The slime at the bottom of the barrel is gaining power to threaten individual life and liberty. From now on always assume that my telephone is bugged and do not ask if I will be attending any particular event.

SPEECH.PARA: The members of the society are really whackos. The document further stated:

PARA.TAB: I can still say to you that it is not too late if we all work together. The trouble is that we all want to be Field Marshals and no one wants to be a soldier. We have a lot of talent. Peter Sawyer and Brian Wilshire both do great recruitment promotions; Wake-Up and LOGOS can distribute news on a wide front; The League is a mine of historic information; the CEC movement—

SPEECH.PARA: of which the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) would have an intimate understanding—
has potential to enlist a huge army; CHPS is an armaments factory.

Yes, and one of its chief foot soldiers and one of the big cannon firers is the current Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Mayo. I will tell the House exactly how this organisation organises itself by outlining some of its aims and objectives.

PARA.TAB: In 1988 the Constitutional Heritage Protection Society formed the Anti-Treason Coordinate. What a whacko bunch! The aim of the coordinate is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . simply to provide a support base for the co-operation and co-ordination of those different groups and individuals who have the desire, and the courage, to expose the treason and treachery that is destroying our culture. We propose that this Aim be directed to the Objective of regaining the full rights of self government provided for by our legitimate Australian Constitution.
This organisation was a front for the League of Rights. The coordinate's proposed activities and ideas were:
.That other groups be contacted and invited to a meeting to discuss unity and co-operation . . .
.That we make every effort to remove the present Federal Government.
The list goes on and on. This is a manual of how the League of Rights operates on the ground in manipulating these issues.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition comes into this House masquerading as a moderate, a man of great moderation, but deep at the heart of the Liberal Party is a hard cancer. That cancer is represented in this place by the Leader of the Opposition coming to the dispatch box to defend the allegations made against him. That hard cancer is now eating the Liberal Party to pieces. (Time expired)
