TALK.START.PARA: —We are not sitting next week and because next week is National Alzheimer's Week I want to take this opportunity to say a few words. Alzheimer's is a tragic disease that most people in this House would have had some personal experience with.

PARA.TAB: Dementia is generally something of a taboo subject in our society. We tend to ignore it until it happens to someone we know or love, yet about one in eight adult Australians will eventually experience some form of dementia. The number of people with dementia can be expected to increase rapidly as more Australians survive into their 70s, 80s and 90s.

Dementia is not just a disease of the elderly. Alzheimer's disease, for example, affects about 10,000 people under 65 years of age. It is a tragic fact that a type of dementia is a common feature of the latter stages of HIV-AIDS. I understand that some unpublished studies indicate that between 20 and 30 per cent of people with HIV-AIDS can expect to be affected by dementia.

I am sure that honourable members can relate to their own personal experiences of the effects of that dementia, whatever the clinical causes of that dementia, and those experiences that are also shared with them by their constituents. However, Alzheimer's is the most common form of dementia, and is a disease which attacks and destroys brain cells. While research is giving us a better understanding of how the disease process works, we as yet have no cure.

Yesterday, in the Main Committee of this House, I commented on the challenges faced by personal carers—spouses, partners, sons, daughters and friends—in caring for loved ones with the frailties of age, physical or mental disabilities. Those who care for people with dementia have perhaps the most difficult challenge of all—the frustration and heartbreak of watching someone who might be physically well but who is declining mentally.

When we mark National Alzheimer's Week, we should remember that carers are as much sufferers of Alzheimer's and other forms of dementia as the people for whom they care. I think it is also appropriate to give full due to the professionals, volunteers and organisations such as the Alzheimer's Association of Australia which assists and supports people with dementia and those who care for them.

One way of easing the burden of Alzheimer's is to promote dementia specific care facilities. Brian Burdekin and his committee on mental health looked at the great work being done by the small number of such dementia specific facilities in Australia. He spoke very highly of the Lefroy Hostel in Western Australia, which houses 36 residents with dementia. It not only provides primary care to residents but also offers respite and carer support services. I am visiting this facility next week.

While Brian Burdekin encourages the expansion of such dementia specific facilities, the sad fact is that, in my own electorate, one of only eight dementia specific facilities in Australia is just about to close. I think it is an enormous tragedy that a facility that gives dignity and appropriate care to some of the most frail people in the community should not be able to continue. I think it is a great pity that funding is so rigid as not to allow consideration of this sort of facility.

I commend the Alzheimer's Association of Australia for its work. I hope next week is a success for the association. I hope it helps raise the issue of Alzheimer's disease in a positive way throughout the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haviland Mr C.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak this evening on behalf of a constituent in my electorate of Macarthur, Mr Aristeo Fernando. Mr Fernando has a dream, an inspiration, for reform which he believes would be the beginning of the unification of the world in peace—a common bond between all nations. Mr Fernando proposes the introduction of a bill changing our official calendar from the Gregorian calendar to a perpetual calendar.

PARA.TAB: The proposed perpetual calendar is similar to the present calendar. It has 12 months in the year, the year is divided into four quarters each of three months, and the first month in each quarter would have 31 days and the second and third months of each quarter would have 30 days, that is, January, April, July and October would have 31 days and all other months would have 30 days. This gives a total of 364 days. The 365th day would fall between December and January and not be identified as a particular day of a week or a month, but would be called world peace day. There would also be a leap year day at the end of June every four years.

The most important feature of this proposed calendar is that the names of days and dates are the same year after year. For example, 1 January would always be a Monday and special occasions like Christmas and various anniversaries or, for that matter, individuals' birthdays would always fall on the same day of the week. Activities regularly held every year would become easier to plan for and remember.

Mr Fernando also points out that there are environmental benefits to be achieved from this proposal. Because the names of the days and dates would not change from year to year, there would be less demand for new calendars, thus the usage of paper for the printing of calendars would be dramatically reduced. This could see a reduction in the amount of emissions from paper production plants and a decrease in the number of trees which need to be logged.

Mr Fernando understands that Australia alone cannot introduce and use a calendar which is completely different to that used by the rest of the world. However, Mr Fernando, a Filipino migrant, has immense pride in being an Australian citizen and believes that Australia has the courage to initiate and spearhead such a reform and that it can persuade the rest of the world to follow.

Mr Fernando would like to see the Australian parliament agree, in principle, to his proposed perpetual calendar, with a view to proclaiming the calendar at the opening ceremony of the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney. In the meantime, Australia could raise this proposal in United Nations forums and other appropriate forums in order to achieve international agreement to the perpetual calendar. The calendar would operate from 1 January 2001, which appropriately is a Monday.

Mr Fernando believes that this could be Australia's lasting gift to the world and an appropriate celebration of its centenary of Federation. I must admit that when Mr Fernando approached me on this issue I was rather pessimistic about his chances of success; that is, until he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If we don't speak up, who will speak up? If we don't move, who will move? If not now, when will it ever be?

A statement like that is pretty hard to argue with. Mr Fernando is a person who had the desire and courage to speak up and share his inspiration with other Australians. He has already received some publicity for his proposal in local newspapers.

PARA.TAB: As his representative in this place, I am happy to bring his proposal to the attention of the House so that it can be considered and debated by anyone who sees merit in the idea of a perpetual calendar. Those of us in public life who commit ourselves to reform and change know only too well that the road towards change can be a rocky one. I hope that by raising this issue today I can play a small part in promoting, at least for consideration in the community and amongst honourable members, something which does appear, on the surface, to be a proposal of some merit.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, during the adjournment debate, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) levelled against me a series of allegations which, I am glad to say, do not add up. He gave me the courtesy of letting me know that he would be raising these matters. I have done the same for him today.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Calare drew to the attention of the House a survey I have distributed to Landcare groups throughout Australia. I thank him for highlighting this because it does underline the importance assigned to landcare by the coalition. It was alleged that this survey was sent out to every Landcare group in Australia—some 2,200 in all. Whilst that was my intention, this was not possible because the mailing lists available comprised nowhere near that number.

My office distributed 1,520 surveys in total. Landcare groups in Queensland, Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia—some 986 in all—received their surveys in envelopes supplied to me under my Parliament House stationery entitlement. Postage for the distribution of these surveys was covered by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) as a survey was prepared and jointly distributed by the leader and me.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the CALM ones?

—Good grief! I am in the process of explaining what happened. Distribution of the survey in New South Wales was handled differently. The honourable member for Calare will be disappointed to learn that this was because the New South Wales Department of Conservation and Land Management would not supply a list of Landcare groups. So its attitude reflected somewhat differently from those who took the more bipartisan attitude in other states. The total number of surveys distributed in New South Wales was 535.

PARA.TAB: When my office was unable to obtain a list for New South Wales, I decided to try to distribute the survey through the 29 catchment management coordinators in New South Wales, a list of whom is publicly available. I wrote to each of them individually, enclosing 10 copies of the survey complete with stamped, self-addressed envelopes, and asked them whether they would be prepared to distribute them. I am unaware of how many eventually reached Landcare groups and, if they did, how this was achieved, although it appears from the copy of the survey the honourable member for Calare brandished in this place yesterday that some apparently may have gone out in state department envelopes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surprise, surprise!

—Bring the earth down, for goodness sake! Shattering stuff! As a result of this mail-out to catchment coordinators, my office subsequently received a call from one Landcare specialist with CALM who wanted a further 20 copies for Landcare groups in that particular region. Subsequently, my office attempted to contact all Landcare specialists in New South Wales and asked whether they would circulate the survey to Landcare groups in their region.

PARA.TAB: Three of those contacted requested another 225 copies in total—all of which were again sent with stamped, self-addressed envelopes. I am unaware of the means by which these surveys were distributed. Plainly, many people have found them of value and of interest. They were issued with the best intent in the world. Landcare enjoys strong bipartisan support and I have always acknowledged that and will continue to do so, especially in relation to the underlying principles involved.

I have never sought to claim anything other than that there is strong bipartisan support for landcare, but I maintain that it is entirely appropriate for me to try to ascertain how well it is going, given that landcare specialists right across the nation—including, I notice, Professor Brian Roberts in Queensland, the latest—are warning that the movement is in danger of falling away under a spirit of demoralisation and a concern that due to the economic viability problems of the rural sector and so forth different approaches may be needed in future. Under those circumstances I do not resile from my position that it is entirely appropriate and entirely reasonable for me to attempt to ascertain how Landcare groups feel about the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knott Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not appropriate for state government resources to be used for the circulation of party political propaganda. That issue will not go away here. It will end up in ICAC. I would like to talk about another slanderous situation in New South Wales. In New South Wales I and my family and my fellow residents of Kiama have been slugged with an $80 a year environmental levy by Mr Fahey and his government. This is relevant to the last comments that were made because I happen to have been appointed by Mr Armstrong, a former National Party member, as the chairman of a Landcare group in my area. When we asked Mr Fahey through his government, through the water board, for some money to distribute some of the water, the effluent, they are pumping into the ocean and out onto the trees that we are putting on that headland, what was our answer? No.

PARA.TAB: It goes further, though. I have made representations on behalf of the Kiama Golf Club, which has made an approach to the water board in New South Wales. It currently uses a rather large amount of water for which it is charged the full rate. The club asked whether it would be able to borrow the money—$268,000, I believe—to put the pipes in to take the water which is currently being pumped out into the ocean. They were told that they could borrow the money and pay for all the works to do it but that the water board, under Mr Fahey, would charge them the same rate they would get for drinking water. In other words, the New South Wales Liberal government is saying through its water board, `We do not really care about cleaning up the oceans.' An organisation like a golf club cannot get cheaper water. The water that they are throwing into the ocean for nothing now cannot pay for the pipes and provide the water at a cheaper rate. I find that absolutely amazing, when these same people are telling us that they are concerned with the environment. I will read to members an open letter to Mr John Fahey on behalf of the people of the Kiama, which I intend publishing:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Fahey
Mr Fahey your government is charging us $80 per year `Environmental Levy' on our water & sewerage charges but you don't spend the money here. We want results for our money.
We don't see any environmental improvement here and we don't see practical water saving in the middle of a crippling drought.
Mr Fahey, when a local Landcare group wanted wastewater for their restoration work adjacent to the treatment work it was denied by your government.

Now Kiamma golf club is poised to reuse treated waste water. We would like your government to provide financial help for our Golf Club to conserve `good' water and reuse `old' water and to put less wastewater into our fishing and surfing environment.

Mr Fahey, if carefully targeted and intelligent investments were made by the Water Conservation Ministry then our water resources would be more efficiently used. Less drinking quality water would be wasted, and less waste effluent would be dumped at sea.

Golf courses are a case in point where it makes economic sense to help modify their usage—especially in drought conditions where water restrictions are imminent. Right now water is being pumped at great expense from the Shoalhaven to Sydney, while the golf courses in Water Board territory pour drinking quality water onto grass.

Kiama Golf Club would be typical of most courses which use around $50,000 of drinking quality a year (at 65c a kilolitre) which will no doubt cost them a lot more when newer filtering equipment comes on line soon.

The Club is happy to pay 15c to 20c a kilolitre for pre-treated sewerage effluent that would otherwise be poured into the sea—and no doubt provide the water board with a tidy profit and save the Golf Club $30,000 a year. The problem Mr Fahey is the club has to find $280,000 for the piping and pumps—not a huge figure given that there is a ten year payback cycle, but this is a sporting club, not big business. They need grant and loan assistance.
They need some of the environmental levy that we are paying. The letter continues:
I am sure that the people of Kiamma have paid enough `Environmental Levy' by now to expect some return to our community!
Come on, Mr Fahey, where are you? Or do you not want to win the next election? If you do not act, you will be thrown out, as you so properly should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to pay tribute to a fine Western Australian, a great ambassador for our nation and a sporting hero for many young Australians, Geoff Marsh, who this week announced his retirement from first-class cricket. Geoff Marsh made his first-class debut for Western Australia in 1978, at 19 years of age. His record since is a very proud and impressive one. Geoff played 184 first-class matches in which he captained the Western Australian team on 31 occasions. He played one of the greatest innings by an Australian when he scored 355 not out against South Australia in 1989, the 10th highest first-class score by an Australian. That was one of his 33 first-class centuries for his state and nation.

PARA.TAB: Geoff rose to the highest level in cricket, playing for Australia in 50 test matches, 37 of them as vice-captain to Allan Border, and was instrumental in the Ashes victory of 1989. I recall many of Geoff's superb performances but one that will be remembered for a long time is his record partnership with Mark Taylor, the new Australian captain, in which the pair shared an opening stand which lasted for well over one day's play.

Geoff also excelled at the one-day level, playing 117 one-day internationals, and was one of the leading players in helping Australia win the World Cup in India and Pakistan in 1987. He also held an Australian record for the most centuries scored in one-day internationals and was often the backbone of our one-day victories after playing the sheet anchor role in magnificent style. Indeed, it is not surprising that much of Australia's success both in tests and one-day matches came with Allan Border and Geoff Marsh at the helm of our team.

In cricket partnerships Allan Border and Geoff Marsh combined brilliantly to lead our national team to many triumphs. He was often the backbone of both the Western Australian and Australian sides and his commitment, his gritty determination and his perseverance made him a great role model for youngsters. As captain of Western Australia, he showed true sportsmanship as a fair, competitive and honest leader of the Western Australian team and as vice-captain of the national team Geoff was a brilliant lieutenant to one of Australia's greatest cricketers, Allan Border. It was typical Geoff Marsh style to apply himself with such dedication to his state and nation, a characteristic that has been a fine example for many up and coming youngsters who look to the likes of Geoff as a role model.

Geoff will be sorely missed from the Western Australian team as captain and player. I commend him on his career with our state and national teams. I particularly commend him on the dedication, gritty determination and commitment with which he applied himself to the game of cricket. He was a wonderful ambassador for our state and our nation. I applaud him for a wonderful career in which he represented Western Australia and Australia with impressive aplomb, something every young person can aspire to.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 8 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth funding for the vocational education and training sector for the years 1994 and 1995 has already been appropriated under the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992. The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill provides for supplementation to these amounts in line with price movements. The bill also appropriates funding for 1996, in accordance with the Commonwealth's undertaking in the heads of government agreement to establish the Australian National Training Authority to provide triennial funding for the vocational education and training sector.

PARA.TAB: The year 1996 also sees further evidence of the government's commitment to expansion of the vocational education and training sector through the provision of a further $70 million in growth funds. This brings total growth funding since 1993 to $1.1 billion. The Commonwealth, in turn, expects states and territories to honour their undertakings in the ANTA agreement, including maintaining their own effort in vocational education and training.

This bill also provides funding—$25.9 million from 1994, including $2.4 million for monitoring purposes—to ANTA for support for off-the-job training provider assistance under the Australian traineeship system and career start traineeships, including assistance for both public and private training providers.

As the government announced in the white paper, we are committed to the task of achieving 50,000 additional entry level training places by 1995-96. An integral part of this is achieving an additional 16,000 trainees in that time. In 1995 and 1996, an additional $12.8 million and $22.7 million respectively is available for this purpose. When this is combined with the $70 million growth funds that the government is providing in each of 1995 and 1996, as well as the transitional funding of $20.4 million in 1994 and $10 million in 1995 provided in the budget, the government expects these costs to be more than adequately met.

The government expects ANTA to report separately each year on progress towards achieving a target of 35,000 trainees by 1995-96, under the $2.4 million being provided to monitor these grants. The bill provides that these additional funds will only go to those states and territories that are able to demonstrate to ANTA that they have achieved additional trainees.

This bill also adjusts funding to ANTA from July 1994 to allow the ACT to enter the national infrastructure program for vocational education and training. This places the ACT on the same footing as all other states and territories in terms of national planning for vocational education and training facilities.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the House.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I need to seek your guidance. The government also intends to move one amendment which, if it is possible, I would not mind moving at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be done at the consideration in detail stage.

—I foreshadow a minor amendment to align the government's white paper initiatives on the national training wage and the initiative to increase funding for off-the-job training under the Australian traineeship scheme and career start traineeships. The government amendment relates to the proposed new section 9A, which deals with the Australian traineeship scheme and career start traineeships. Clause 4 of the bill proposes to insert a new section 9A to empower the minister to increase funding to a state where participation in traineeships in that state increases as a result of initiatives in the government's white paper and, as a result, the demand for off-the-job training in that state increases. The clause refers only to the Australian traineeship scheme and the career start traineeship.

PARA.TAB: It is necessary to amend the proposed subsection 9A(1) because the proposed national training wage award will generally subsume the Australian traineeship scheme and career start traineeships and provide for future traineeships to be under that award. Therefore, the proposed subsection 9A(1) will extend eligibility for funding for eligible off-the-job training to a state. A new subsection would be added to define eligible off-the-job training. Eligible off-the-job training would now include the national training wage traineeships as well as the Australian traineeship system and career start traineeships schemes, which the minister considers should be taken into account for the purposes of determining that there has been an increase in the number of people receiving off-the-job training in a state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1994. The background to this bill is that the Commonwealth provides grants to the states and territories for the provision and support of the vocational education and training, primary and technical and further education system. Prior to 1 January 1994, grants to the states and territories were provided in accordance with the provisions of the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act 1989. These grants contributed to general operating costs and recurrent expenditure grants and capital expenditure grants.

PARA.TAB: From 1 January 1994, the funding arrangements under the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act 1989 were replaced by funding arrangements under the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992. Under the new arrangements, a single pool of funds comprising the previously separate recurrent expenditure grants and capital expenditure grants is passed to ANTA for allocation amongst the states and territories. The Australian National Training Authority Act 1992 gave effect to an agreement announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 21 July 1992. That is over 27 months ago. This was an agreement between the Commonwealth, states and territories for the establishment of ANTA.

I would like to remind the committee of the objectives of the agreement. They included the following: the establishment of a national vocational education and training system; closer interaction between industry, vocational education and training providers; an effective training market; and, improved cross-sectoral links. That is the background to this debate which I think is very important at this stage when trying to meet those objectives. I will be drawing this debate back to those objectives which have been set out and which have been agreed to, particularly the objectives of an effective training market and a national system.

Within this bill, the main provisions are in clause 4. It will insert new sections 9 and 9A and, I think, 9A(1)—it is the latest one which has come in—into the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992. Section 9 currently provides for payments to ANTA for allocation under the Australian National Training Authority Act 1992 of $638.96 million in 1994 and $719.741 million in 1995. The effect of the new section will be to amend the amounts payable to ANTA in the following manner: it will increase the amount payable in 1994 from $638.96 million to $673.612 million and the amount for 1995 from $719.741 million to $755.71 million. It will set out the amount payable for 1996. It is a very substantial amount which we are putting into this part of education in Australia. That figure which we are dealing with in this discussion is $835.52 million. So we are not talking about a small amount of money; it is a substantial part of the appropriations for 1996. There is a lot of money involved. Australia is going through a tremendous amount of change in this sector of the educational area.

In this area of administration a lot of difficulties are surfacing. The real issues that we need to face are: what are the intentions of the federal government; and what are its strategies as outlined in the white paper? Is the government really focused on increasing and improving the skills of Australians or is it more interested in trying to pull down the unemployment figures just for a gloss effect out there for public perception purposes? I raise that as a very important point: what are we about? It would appear to me, from my reading and from talking to the state ministers who are in negotiations on various aspects of training and skilling in Australia, that there are some deep concerns. I come to a report which the government at the moment does not want to provide to the public. It is a report by Vince Fitzgerald. A copy has been provided to me. One of the chapters is entitled, `Successful reform'; the heading is `Inadequate performance planning and reporting.' It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Continued reliance on Frameworks, Guidelines, Policies, Procedures, Protocols, Memorandums and the other paraphernalia of government avoids the central question of what is the performance target, what is the work and business plan and where are the annual reports against reform targets for each of those agencies or organisations actually responsible for the reforms.

We are dealing with millions and millions of dollars here. As I said, in 1996 it was over $800 million. These funding proposals are in place at the moment and we support them. We could really label this debate `funding for failure' or `funding without focus'. I am not sure which one we should adopt. It certainly can be described as `funding without focus' at the moment. We are not going to skill this country and we are not going to develop a more competent work force unless this money is effectively used and unless there are administrative arrangements in place which set up clear measurable targets that are identifiable publicly and that are achieved.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, all the evidence indicates that money is being allocated by the parliament, but the progress is not very great. There is deep concern out there by a whole range of people, organisations and industry who are involved in this area. This report says that there are `confused accountabilities and responsibilities'. We are at the very early stages of trying to re-skill and up-skill Australia. We have an in-depth report which says that it is two years since the Prime Minister announced changes in this area and that there is total confusion in regard to accountabilities. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Below the level of the Ministerial Council, it is difficult to draw clear lines of accountability for the implementation of training reforms.

If we are going to make progress and if there is not to be so much red tape and bureaucracy in this field, the government has got to give some clear direction to this whole field. The report says in conclusion to this particular chapter:
Our assessment . . . relates to both the substance of the national training reforms themselves and to their strategic management. In both areas they have been found wanting.

So the very nature, the essence, of what the government says the reforms are about is found wanting in a report that the minister is too concerned to make public because the providers, business and industry are deeply concerned about the way in which this whole thing is operating, because the very nature of the program which is being envisaged is, some people would say, a sham.

PARA.TAB: The report finds the reforms wanting with regard to strategic management. The whole direction for ANTA really comes back to the federal government. I know the state minister is also involved in the set-up of the council, but it is this government that is driving the agenda and has responsibility to make it work and, clearly, there is lack of direction from the government. It does not know which way to go now. It wants to go in a certain way. It wants a top-down approach to government. It wants to have centralised control over so many things in this country.

Again we see a dynamic tension among the goals I mentioned earlier about the establishment of ANTA. Let us consider the goal of a `closer interaction between industry and vocational education training and training providers'. The fact is that industry out there is saying that there is not this genuine interaction. There might be in a few cases, but it is not substantial and it is not right across the board. There are literally thousands of people out there in businesses who are ignored, one could say, if not locked out of the training procedures. The act also sets out the goals of an effective training market and other objectives which the government and the council have agreed to but they are simply not being realised.

I move on just to make two more key points. One is a concern that these proposed funding levels as set out are unrealistically low, and that the government is really trying to force an agenda onto the states which is going to cause problems. The agreements between the states and the federal government have not yet been made, and I suspect that at the end of the day we may be back here having to allocate more money, because what the federal government has done over the years in other areas it is now doing in this area: it is palming off certain responsibilities to the states, giving them a certain amount of money, but expecting them to do far more than that money will ever achieve.

I can relate that to education and to lots of other fields, such as health and law and order. They are state areas of responsibility that the government keeps cutting the real funding for, while still expecting the states to do something about them. It is about to do the same, I suspect, in regard to vocational education and training.

The third thing which I want to highlight is that this bill is also notable for giving the Commonwealth minister power to determine whether states are meeting targets for new trainees rather than leaving that task to the ANTA board. Why does it have to be the federal minister who has the power to determine whether the targets have been met? Why can it not be left to the ANTA board? Of course, this parallels the eleventh-hour amendment to the ANTA act in December 1993 which allowed the Commonwealth minister to overrule the ANTA board and the ministerial council in determining whether states have succeeded in meeting maintenance of effort requirements. It is a pure set-up—nothing more and nothing less. There is a centralising of power and control by the federal minister in this area which is totally unsatisfactory.

It is interesting to look at a few figures in this area. The white paper talks about a target of 46,000 apprentices in 1994. In 1990 there were 162,600 apprentices. People might say that we have got traineeship schemes, that we are going to have apprentices and a whole host of other schemes brought in, and that that means people are going to become diversified, they are just not going to be in apprenticeships. But when we look at that target it is still about 20,000 less than the 162,600 apprenticeships we had in 1990 in this country. What is going on in this area of training?

This is an area where those opposite feel extremely vulnerable and guilty because, over the decade they have been in government, they have done little in regard to TAFE education. These figures indicate their paucity of action and total lack of administrative focus.

They may talk about the Australian traineeship scheme—a great brainwave, a great idea. Did it work? Were the targets reached? What was the outcome? The outcome was that from 1985 to 1993 there were 80,291 students who commenced traineeship schemes, but fewer than 70 per cent finished. This government says it is about action but at the end of the day, when we have a look at whether it is meeting its targets, we will find it is usually failing. I want to go into more detail about what is in this report because it goes to the heart of where TAFE education and training is. I move:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Main Committee is of the view that the Government should be condemned for the lack of direction in its approach to training reform and its mismanagement of this vitally important area".

SPEECH.PARA: I want to go through some of the comments which are being made about this reform process. There are eight key elements to training reform and where this money, about $800 million for 1996, which we are allocating here today, will go. These areas cover competency based training, about which we have heard in the past, competency standards, national recognition of training, curriculum delivery and assessment, entry level training, training market, access and equity, and funding for training. Some of those words sound pretty highfalutin and that is about where they have been left.

PARA.TAB: To give you a few ideas of the problems we see arising in this area, the report which was done for the government by a highly professional group of people says, in regard to competency based training, that there is conceptual confusion, a lack of understanding, poor marketing and promotion, high costs, failure to integrate, failure to convert and inadequate strategy. It is interesting that, in some of these areas, even the results are very hard to identify—for example, in regard to competency based training.

Let me refer to the report and give you a few ideas as to the problems that are likely to arise in this area. It says that there is conceptual confusion, lack of understanding, poor marketing and promotion, high costs, failure to integrate, failure to convert and an inadequate strategy. It is interesting that in some of these areas even the results are hard to identify. For example, with regard to competency based training, the report says that the `results are difficult to define with any degree of precision.' Therefore, not only are there no results, but all of these weaknesses have been found in the processes involved in developing a new training system here in Australia. It is totally unsatisfactory.

I will now move onto the second area of competency standards. It is pretty important in this area to have certain standards of competence for the people involved in training. What are the weaknesses in this area? ANTA says that the weaknesses are far more complicated and resource intensive than initially thought and that they will take up a lot more money and effort than ever we expected. Will this money achieve good competence levels and standards? Industry standards are being developed by bodies which are unrepresentative of the key enterprises in those industries. We are finding that some standards are being developed out there, but they are being developed on the fringe and certainly not in the heartland of the very important industries of Australia. Where are we going to end up if the standards are being set by people who are not in the mainstream of the industry?

The report goes on to say that the eight-level ASF discourages labour flexibility. The practical relationship between the NTB endorsed standards and the Mayer competencies is unclear. And this is a report commissioned by the government. The report further says that as competency standards in their current form are conceived as a series of tasks, their translation into a flexible curriculum is difficult, if not impossible. Are we getting a more flexible training market or are we getting a more rigid market? In other words, are the users of this system going to have great difficulty in getting the types of courses that they want?

What does the report say about the national recognition of training? Are we making good progress in the national recognition of a nationwide system? The report says that there has been a failure to convince enterprises of a value adding capability and that there has been inadequate involvement of industry. I thought that one of the key goals of setting up ANTA was to get interaction between industry, business, training and TAFE colleges and that it would be a cooperative, collaborative partnership. It is not happening. Two years after the Prime Minister announced this, it is not happening. It is said to be inadequate: in accreditation, certification and in the recognition of processes.

Fundamental problems are arising with the government's strategy in this. It really opens up the question of whether the working paper strategy on training in Australia is about training or whether it is about trying to reduce the numbers of the unemployment figures. The report also says that one of the weaknesses in this area is a bias towards inputs rather than outputs. But what about the curriculum? What is the nature of the curriculum for the people who are going to be involved in this area—the delivery and the assessment? With respect to this area, the report says that `national curriculum initiatives take too long to become operational', that they get bogged down, and that they do not get out and have an effect in the areas where thousands of Australians, mainly young Australians, want to increase their skills.

The national curriculum effort is too institutionally oriented. It fails to deal adequately with the needs of enterprises. In other words, it is a top-down approach, with centralised control by the government, and the government does not listen to Australians to find out what sort of training they want. The government does not listen to industry or enterprise. It says, `We know what to do. We are going to impose our approach on them, and they can just take what they get.' That is the approach that the government is taking.

The government has got to make a decision in regard to training in Australia as to whether it is going to continue to have a top-down approach, or whether it will have a bottom-up approach, where the users have some say about what they want to be trained in, rather than being told by bureaucrats and getting caught up in red tape. To give clarity to our administrators in this area, real responsibility must come from the government. The government is sitting on its hands. In a couple of years time, I suspect that we are going to be looking at a disaster in this area. The government is on notice to get it right.

The report to the government on curriculum delivery and assessment says that no-one is clear about how far a national course can be varied in content to meet the specific needs of an enterprise, while retaining integrity as a course leading to a qualification. This leads to rigidities in training. In other words, in regard to flexibility, there is no-one at this stage who knows how to slightly modify a course and still have it accredited. That is absolutely disgraceful. Here we are today talking about hundreds of millions of dollars, and yet no-one can tell us how there can be flexibility in these courses.

The report says that the take-up rates of the national curriculum are apparently poor. The government has been saying that there are lots of people out there taking it up. That is not true. The report says that they are not really taking it up. The coverage might be good, but nobody is taking it up.

Another point of weakness, according to the report, is the lack of responsiveness by TAFE providers to the needs of enterprises. Again, the problem in this area is that it is a top-down approach by the government. I could go on. There are distinct weaknesses in the area of entry level training, but time does not permit me to go into detail. There are enormous problems in the training market. With access and equity it is the same, as it is for funding for training. There is a list of areas with problems and weaknesses in managing the reform process.

The government has a total lack of direction and focus in regard to training. We are debating the allocation of millions of dollars worth of extra funding, but the government has not put in place the due structures and processes to ensure that Australians are adequately trained and skilled. There are tens of thousands of Australians out there who want to go into vocational education and training. They do not want to go on to university. This is a very important area, and yet we are throwing money at it without putting in place the due processes.

This report indicates that the government has to act, otherwise businesses will not have trained people, and enterprises will not be able to compete in world markets because they will not have the skills in their work force. I urge everybody here to accept my proposed amendment to this bill.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—I understand that the honourable member for Bendigo has seconded the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill replaces the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act 1989, and will set the level of Commonwealth vocational funding for the period 1994-96.

PARA.TAB: Nothing that I have seen or heard in the House or in this place can convince me that the opposition has any serious thoughts about vocational education and training in this nation. The opposition, it appears, has yet to grasp the fact that a well-trained and skilled work force can more ably compete in the international trading community. Individual members of the opposition and, of course, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), referred to a number of reports. I intend to refer to a number of reports as well, so I hope that he stays and pays attention to what I am about to say.

There are a number of people who contribute regularly to education debate, but the number of people on the opposition side who contribute can be counted on the fingers of one hand. If you count those who contribute in a constructive manner, the number is far less. It is a exception this morning, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we have 11 speakers on this particular bill. Perhaps that shows some progress in terms of the coalition, but unfortunately—and sadly—the coalition position on education is one of indifference. The policy position of the coalition can only be described as irrelevant and out of touch with the needs of our schools and our institutions. Why do those at the cutting edge of the delivery of education and training services in this country believe that the coalition is totally extraneous and that it has lost the plot when it comes to policy matters?

One could argue that the level of informed debate in the House has actually dropped over the last three or four years. People would not have to look past the number of questions without notice that the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), the then shadow minister, put to the government about employment, education and training in the last term of government. The answer: four—a miserable number—plus two questions that he asked a few days ago. To put it in perspective, that means that the former shadow minister asked a total of four questions about education and training over a three-year period. Not a bad average for a party which claims to be serious about employment, education and training in this country! It is no wonder that we on this side consider members of the opposition beneath contempt when they come into the House or this place ranting and raving about something that they really do not understand. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) time and time again becomes confused about the policies of the coalition, so what chances do his backbenchers have?

The coalition's policy is even more unrealistic in vocational education, in meeting the current and future expectations of business and the community. The effect of the coalition policies that are spelt out in the policy document Fightback, in comparison to our own stance on TAFE funding, would result in an overall reduction in funding of $27 million. In fact, the minister pointed out that it would actually add up to about $30 million in resources made available to the national TAFE system.

Just remember that that $27 million hole was on expenditure prior to the commitments that we made to this year's Working Nation document. Over the last few years this government has put TAFE and vocational education high on its priorities within the employment, education and training portfolio. Over a four-year period we have seen three major reports produced by the government on this subject. We did not produce the reports so that they would sit idly on a desk somewhere accumulating dust; indeed, we have adopted many of the principles espoused in the reports.

The first, of course, is the report of the Deveson Training Costs Review Committee, which was released in 1990. This is a very important document because it sets the agenda for future reforms and it also makes the states acutely aware that they could not go it alone. The major recommendations are wide-ranging in terms of the way in which the whole approach to training needs to be reformed. Importantly, it stresses the need to provide a greater consistency across the state systems in respect of the development of curriculum and accreditation and in recognition of the skills already obtained.
Further recommendations are set out in the Finn report, which was released in 1991. I do not know how many members have read the report—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's all history.

—It is not history for you, because you do not know about it. The report could be described as the benchmark for reform for post-compulsory education in Australia, and it sets targets for the government to achieve in secondary, tertiary and vocational education for young people. The targets recommended in the Finn report are, admittedly, ambitious, but they are certainly highly desirable for the creation of a highly skilled and competitive work force. The final targets which it set are that, by the year 2001, there should be: a level 2 traineeship or progress towards a higher level vocational or academic qualification for almost all 20-year-olds; and at least a vocational or academic qualification above level 3, or a diploma or a degree, for at least 50 per cent of 20-year-olds. The principles of these reports have been adopted by the government. With the cooperation of the states, many of the recommendations are already in place and many more are well on the way to being achieved.

PARA.TAB: Then came the report by the Employment and Skills Foundation Council headed by Laurie Carmichael. The Carmichael report recognised that education and training should be a lifetime process, rather than a one-off process at the beginning of or before a person's working life. The principles of the Carmichael report are based on competency rather than time or process. The recommendations have, importantly, set the groundwork for the introduction of the training wage as outlined in the white paper. As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) recently pointed out, the importance of the training wage cannot be underestimated.

It will introduce for the first time an adult wage, in line with the Carmichael principle, based on competency rather than time or process. Once the relevant skills have been acquired, a person then moves on from a training wage. The training wage will also simplify the complexity of rates which apply to youth. This would not have been possible without the involvement and agreement between the ACTU and the peak bodies of employers. Those peak bodies of employers include: the Metal Trades Industry Association, which, I might add, recognised the importance of what we are trying to achieve at a very early stage of the negotiations; the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry; the Business Council of Australia; the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry; the Retail Traders Association—and, of course, we would not forget the National Farmers Federation.

If, according to the Liberal-National parties, our position on vocational education and training and the general thrust of the white paper on employment and growth are fundamentally wrong, why is it that they are the only odd ones out? Persons receiving training on the job will also qualify for the training wage, which, in turn, will add force to the process of enterprise bargaining. Enterprise agreements are now very much a part of everyday industrial relations, although it did take employers quite a while initially to be comfortable with the ideas of these agreements.

Both employers and employees now see a benefit in enterprise agreements. More than one million workers under federal awards are now covered by workplace agreements. All of them have been finalised by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission since October 1991. Half of those 2,000 agreements have been registered in the past 12 months. Almost 50 per cent of workers under federal awards are now covered by agreements, and 90 per cent of businesses with 500 or more employees in the federal system have workplace agreements. In the next 12 to 24 months, I expect there will be a steady increase in the number of enterprise agreements signed, particularly from the small and medium enterprise sector.

What the members of the opposition do not realise is that there is a revolution going on out there in the workplace. They are still arguing about the merits of the Stone Age industrial relations document of the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), Jobsback, not realising that time has already passed them by. The policy hole left by the out-of-date and out-of-touch Jobsback policy document is yet to be addressed by the opposition, with many still adhering to the teaching of Jobsback like lemmings over the cliff. The training wage is a watershed achievement in the skills formation agenda of this county and is essential to avoid skill blockages which, in the past, have dogged Australian industry in every economic recovery. It is competency based. It will overwhelmingly provide greater assistance for the long-term unemployed to obtain gainful employment.

The government has recognised that economic growth alone will not reduce the overall number of people enduring long periods of unemployment. An active policy was needed to intervene and reduce the wasteful nature of long-term unemployment. Now the training wage is aimed directly at that very problem. In previous recoveries, six out of every seven jobs went to new entrants to the labour market and not to the long-term unemployed. The long-term unemployed are not normally jobs ready, so the training wage goes a long way to help solve this problem, along with other active employment programs administered by the government.

TAFE in Australia has undergone a major refocusing and expansion in real terms to meet the changing needs of employers. To reach the achievement levels set by the Commonwealth, states and territories, the Australian National Training Authority was created. The objectives of the agreement included: the establishment of a national vocational education and training system; closer interaction between industry and vocational education and training providers; an effective training market; and improved cross-sectoral links. These changes were prompted in particular by the recommendations of those government reports which I have already mentioned, and the government has firmly resolved to bring excellence into the training area.

As TAFE is now more relevant in providing the skills for a person to become more employable, it is a real alternative to other forms of post-secondary education. Although TAFE has expanded the number of places available, the heavy increase in demand from students is outstripping the ability to meet those needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right!

—Yes, I admit that. That is why this government is pouring large sums of money into the construction and upgrading of TAFE facilities. The Commonwealth realised that the states would not be in any position to deal with the expected increase. While some states, early in the piece, believed the Commonwealth was attempting to take over their traditional role in TAFE services, they now realise that the TAFE system which existed at the time would have buckled under the strain. As a result, the states are now quite happy to cooperate and take the money from Canberra.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth is, and has always been, happy for states to have major control over TAFE, on the understanding that they act in cooperation with the Commonwealth and the other states. By 1996, the Commonwealth contribution to the states in respect of TAFE funding will have reached $858 million, which is double the funding of the early 1990s—and a considerable outlay, in anybody's language. The fact that applications to universities have fallen in recent times can be directly attributed to the increase in the number of placements offered and the number of students now applying to TAFE colleges, and to the realisation of young people themselves that the needs of the future are in fact for technical and operative skills.

Unfortunately, I suspect the number of unsuccessful applicants will increase until the Commonwealth, together with the states, is able to increase the physical capacity of our TAFE colleges. The problem is that, whilst the Commonwealth is providing the funds for expansion, there is a considerable inert period after the funding is made available: that is, from the time a state government approves an individual project—with reference to all the relevant parliamentary committees—until the completion of the construction.

In the first six months of this year, in my own state of South Australia, about 6,000 people were unsuccessful in their attempt to access TAFE education and training. Although that lack of 6,000 places is unacceptable, South Australia is in fact better placed in TAFE than are most of the other states. Of course, South Australia has always been considered a leader in the provision of vocational and TAFE courses and, although we currently have an odd collection of members who make up the Liberal state government, the current state Minister for Employment and TAFE, Bob Such, has so far shown credible leadership in this area—despite the state Liberals' ambivalence in all matters educational.

Under the new arrangements, a single pool of funds—comprising the previous separate recurrent expenditure grants and capital expenditure grants—will be passed to the Australian National Training Authority and will provide for greater flexibility in the funding of the TAFE system. The functions of ANTA include allocation and remission of funds to state and territory training agencies, and the administration of any programs requiring national delivery, on the basis of guidelines determined from time to time by the ministerial council.

The bill also provides for the creation of an additional 50,000 places, comprising the following: 14,000 new apprenticeship places; 15,000 ATS/CST traineeships; 1,000 Commonwealth trainees; 5,000 off-the-job training places; and 10,000 new places within the current labour market. These places are a direct result of the government's white paper process, and are part of the government's strategy for a fall to an unemployment rate of five per cent by the turn of the century.

The coalition is arguing that we will not get the economic growth needed to meet those targets, but economic commentators now not only believe that our forecast is achievable but are also confident that we will exceed this anticipated growth. The Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force figures, released for the month of July, reinforce our belief that our targets are very much obtainable; and, of course, that good news was reinforced in the Australian Financial Review this morning.

Employment in July grew to a record 7.97 million jobs, with growth in employment for the month of July standing at 90,000, which, I stress, is the third largest monthly increase on record. The unemployment rate for July fell to 9.5 per cent, down half a percentage point in just one month—
Mrs Crosio interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —And that is on the back of the continuing strong employment growth of recent times. I thank the member for Prospect for her interjection.
—They can't stand it!

—They cannot stand it. Not only did the unemployment rate drop by a considerable amount, but the participation rate also increased by 0.3 per cent to 63.2 per cent. These are very good signs, which suggest sustainable employment growth. Without the presence of inflationary pressure to impede Australia's economic prosperity, the outlook is indeed promising.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's response in relation to the unemployment problem is that our proposals will do nothing but hide the number of unemployed in training places. When year 12 retention rates in 1983 went from 36 per cent to over 80 per cent, as they are now under this government, one would have thought this was also a good thing, but the coalition's response was much the same. The only response was that they would hide the unemployed. It is a pretty shallow argument, without much thought attached to it. Members of the opposition forget about all the barriers which stop the long-term unemployed from getting a job. They forget that without the assistance of the measures contained in the white paper, the long-term unemployed would have Buckley's chance of landing a job.

It is clear this government is on target to meet its commitment to vocational education and to the unemployed in this country, contrary to anything that members opposite may claim. In concluding, it is appropriate to reflect on comments made by Mr Ivan Deveson. Responding to the white paper on behalf of the Business Council of Australia, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a wide spread belief in the community that Australia should not be prepared to live with high unemployment. The white paper responds to this belief. It is welcomed by the Business Council.

His rationale addressing the problem of long-term unemployment from a business point of view is quite simple, and could not be disputed by any member of this parliament. There are sound economic reasons why long-term unemployment needs to be tackled. Unemployment wastes talent and skills. I think it is time the opposition realised this. We understand that this week members of the opposition have not have a good week. Many issues that were raised in the House were confused, and strategies were confused. But this particular bill, the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1994, has received the support of the parliament, and it needs the support of this Main Committee. I commend the bill to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to comment on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1994 and to support the amendment moved so ably by my colleague, the member for Braddon (Mr Miles). I am pleased that the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) is present in this chamber, because the member for Port Adelaide sees himself as perhaps one of the leading education people in the government ranks, and I have a particular matter which I wish to draw to his attention so that he can raise it with the minister.

PARA.TAB: It is quite obvious that people in education in my area recognise the inadequate attention that is being given by the government to linking vocational training with academic studies. I refer, Mr Deputy Speaker, to a program which was forwarded to me which is called the Bendigo EDGE project: E for education, D for diversity, G for gains and E for employment. The Bendigo EDGE project is intended to give Bendigo students the edge in future employment. It has been recognised by the schools in my area that there is a huge gap between vocational training and academic studies, and they have put forward an excellent submission. The schools that are involved in the Bendigo EDGE project are the Catholic College Bendigo, Bendigo Senior Secondary College and Girton Grammar School, and the training providers involved are the Central Victorian Group Training Company and the Loddon Campaspe College of TAFE.

They have had several meetings, which were facilitated through the Central Victorian Group Training Company Ltd with the Bendigo Senior Secondary College and the Catholic College Bendigo Senior Campus, and they have confirmed a joint desire and a joint will to institute two pilot programs in 1995. It is intended to enable the establishment of a three-year VCE course that will incorporate a retail training scheme and career start traineeship through the Catholic College Bendigo, and a hospitality or similar training program through the Bendigo Senior Secondary College.

What it has planned to combine with the introduction of these two pilot programs is the linking of vocational training with academic studies. The current thinking from the schools that are promoting this course is that each program would involve up to 20 students in the initial intake. Those schools have recognised that there is a huge gap which the government is giving insufficient and inadequate attention to and they have also enlisted the support of a number of regional organisations. Amongst those organisations supporting this vocational training are: the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Affirmative Action in Training, the Bendigo Regional Development Board, the Small Business Association, the Bendigo Tourism Board, Bendigo Central Traders, the Bendigo Chamber of Commerce, Eaglehawk Traders, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures and the Australian Hotels Association.

The object is to include the students in this vocational training and to link it with their VCE studies. The project objective is to implement integrated courses of study and training models across the three VCE providers in Bendigo. This will test a combination of school and work based pathways across a range of different industries including retail, hospitality and office clerical traineeships over an extended three-year period. In other words, it is extending the VCE course to three years and it is including vocational training in this VCE course.

Included in this objective is the opportunity to cross-match students from one VCE institution to another and also to bring back students who have left the VCE course and are at risk of receiving no formal education and training. I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon, you have young people in your community who have drifted away from VCE studies because they do not think that the government is giving adequate attention to vocational training and really equipping them for employment after they have completed their studies. That has been recognised by the educational authorities in my region and it has widespread support.

They are looking for funding from the government because the administrative bodies who will be involved in this with the schools include the following: the Directorate of School Education, which is a Victorian state department; the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which is the federal office; the Office of Training and Further Education, which is a state body; the AVC Joint Task Force, which is a federal and state responsibility; and the Catholic Education Office. The project conveners, Central Victorian Group Training Co. Ltd, have approached me and also the government to have a pilot program which will involve a minimum of 50 students. These students will be selected from Catholic College, Bendigo Senior Secondary College and Girton Grammar.

I do not believe the funding they are seeking for this is unreasonable; I think it is quite reasonable. They are seeking $60,000 to implement this pilot program in 1995 over those three secondary colleges in Bendigo to enable those students to take up these traineeships and get vocational training as well as including their academic studies. I think that what we have seen here is a first-class initiative by a group of education authorities which have recognised the difficulties the government is experiencing in giving adequate attention to linking the two programs—linking vocational study with their academic studies. Too often the focus on training is restricted to one area; it is restricted either to academic studies or to vocational studies. The linkage between the two is often inferior and is not subject to a government directive and a government influence that would give adequate attention to linking vocational training with academic studies.

The submission objectives on which this program is based are important. Some of the objectives are: the ability to show how students and trainees can be interrelated; to confirm the sources of ongoing funding; to clearly show how competencies are to be addressed in general key competencies and to demonstrate the development of key competencies and how they will be assessed; application of the program across the many curriculum areas; clearly showing that the funding will be required for only this first year of the three-year pilot program; consideration about designing a training record book for each student participating in the pilot program; and the appointment of a project officer to manage the program, responsible to a management committee. The aim is to clearly state the guidelines for the pilot project: where we are starting from, what the pilot program will do and the changes within the objectives of the AVCTS. It must also clearly show that this project is a progression from the THRIVE feasibility study. General equality must be present.

I think that the organisation has done a thorough job of research of the local needs of the students. It has stressed the objectives which it hopes to achieve for this training program, bearing in mind what the requirements are of the participants and what the requirements are of the prospective future employers. I mentioned some of the organisations earlier. Most of those organisations, such as the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Bendigo Chamber of Commerce and the Australian Hotels Association, are major potential employers of these young people who would receive this blend of vocational training and academic studies. It is important that the support of those groups be maintained. They have given their support to the organisation and to the pilot program.

I know that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), would be interested in this project to extend the VCE course to three years and include vocational training interlinked with academic studies. That has not been undertaken by the government at the moment and I wish that the member for Prospect would take this on board, because I know she is interested in education. I think this has a lot of merit. A lot of young people drop out of the VCE course because it is too narrowly focused on academic achievements rather than vocational training which will equip them for a job. I am pleased that the member for Prospect has taken note of that and obviously will be referring it to the minister.

There is not a great deal of money involved in this course, $60,000 as a pilot program. Those leading schools in Bendigo, Bendigo Senior Secondary College, Catholic College Bendigo and Girton Grammar School, have been leaders in Victoria in educational training for a number of years. In fact, Bendigo Senior Secondary College was the first college in Australia that had a senior level, just years 11 and 12, and that was started by my former colleague, the Honourable Lindsay Thompson, when he was Minister for Education in Victoria. It was really a pilot program for the development of senior secondary colleges throughout Australia. What I am putting to the chamber is that here is an innovative program put forward with the joint cooperation of Catholic College Bendigo, Bendigo Senior Secondary College and Girton Grammar School, with the backing of a whole range of employer organisations, to link vocational training and academic studies over three years in the VCE course.

I cannot see any reason that that project could not be eminently satisfactory and give many students the opportunity to broaden their base of understanding of what happens in the real world of work and employment. They can link that understanding in with their academic studies, gain the practical experience out in the work force and therefore equip themselves to deal with a whole range of situations.

The institutional based pilots that they are seeking approval of have tested one of the following features: firstly, a combination of time spent at work and study, including continuing education in key competencies for school leavers who have completed year 10 or year 11; secondly, vocational training and work experience provided within upper secondary schools; and, thirdly, a vocational year consisting of vocational training and work experience provided within institutions such as schools or TAFE colleges up to year 13.

The comment from the group is that it is breaking new ground, but it believes the concept of the three colleges working together in different industry groups with the group training company has captured the imagination and support of people who are involved in future employment opportunities for these people. What we need to do now is have the support of the government to fund this pilot program and ensure that it sees this as an exciting new pilot program for young people and as an opportunity to provide them with employment opportunities and a broader based educational program linked in with different vocations.

I have principally mentioned two areas. One is the hospitality industry, which is obviously one industry that is growing quite rapidly and, with the advent of the Olympic Games in the year 2000, an industry which we need to train young people in so that they gain the professional skills. The second area I have mentioned is the retail trade. There is always a constant demand for people with retail skills to participate in that work force as well.

I ask the member for Prospect to take up that issue with the minister and ensure that he looks at that submission favourably. I believe that it is an opportunity for young people to gain a very broad based educational experience, an opportunity for them to participate in vocational training at the same time as they pursue their academic studies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am particularly pleased to speak on this Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill. While acknowledging what the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) has said, I am particularly concerned at a motion before this committee from the previous speaker for the opposition, the member for Braddon (Mr Miles).

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, this bill before the House is really all about improving the skills of our Australian work force and, by doing that, it is also about training. While the bill itself contains amendments, it really is complementing what we have brought down as a government with a white paper. It is a decision that was not taken lightly; it followed extensive consultation. I really believe that such an inane type of amendment before a bill such as this coming before this Main Committee needs a lot of investigation.

The bill that we have here now delivers on the commitments and particularly on the promises made by our government following that Working Nation white paper. The honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) had already referred to the Finn report. Certainly, the Finn report's recommendations are what really this bill is all about, and I also would like to touch on some of that.

There have been many words written on training during this decade. The Finn report and the Carmichael report have provided a framework for our government's actions. Indeed, this bill provides growth funding to help achieve the participation in training targets for our young people following that Finn report. By increasing the number of career style traineeships available, this bill also takes us that one step closer to the introduction of the Australian vocational certificate training system.

One third of the residents of the City of Fairfield, which makes up most of my electorate of Prospect, are younger than 18 years of age. I have seen at first hand the obstacles faced by our young people in a world economy which is rapidly changing. I have also seen the benefits to my electorate of our government's training and education policies. On many occasions in the past I have enthused to the House about the massive increases in the number of young people within my electorate who are undergoing education and training.

We are making our society fairer and our economy more efficient by encouraging our young people, particularly those from low income families, to attend university and to further their education. But it certainly would not be desirable, and it would certainly would not be sustainable, for all or even most of the improvements to education to be funnelled through our university process.

The traineeship system has played a major role in re-skilling our Australian work force. This bill expands on the traineeship system by providing 16,000 extra places, and it helps achieve the Finn participation targets for young people. The Finn report set several targets for the participation of our young people in post-school training. That report, which was released in 1991, noted that Australia's record in training was certainly a sorry one. I cannot help wondering whether perhaps that came about because of the 40 years we were seen to have been riding on the sheep's back; and we seem to have had a lack of policy and direction from successive governments. It was undoubtedly a major structural problem.

In 1987 Australia ranked 14th out of the nations of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in the number of 17-year-olds in post-compulsory education. It was easy to see then that the more economically successful nations knew the importance of training. It is interesting to note that in that survey, the nations with the most 17-year-olds in training were, in order: Japan, West Germany, the United States, the Netherlands, Austria and Switzerland.

To rectify this, the Finn report recommended that by 1995 all 18-year-olds should have attained sufficient vocational skills to achieve at least a base level traineeship or year 12. It further recommended that by 2001 almost all people should have obtained at least a higher level traineeship or progress towards a higher level vocational qualification by the age of 20.

I am certainly pleased to note that we have come some way towards meeting those targets; but we have still got a long way to go. The Australian Bureau of Statistics report Australian social trends found that in 1983, 27 per cent of our 15- to 24-year-olds undertook full-time education. By 1993, fortunately, this had risen to 39 per cent. The committee on employment opportunities noted that in February 1993 almost half of the work force had a post-school qualification, an increase of some eight percentage points from February 1985.

As they relate to suburbs within my electorate, the figures are particularly satisfying. A comparison of the 1986 and 1991 censuses for the City of Fairfield found a 61 per cent increase in the number of students attending a TAFE college, and a 110 per cent increase in the number of people engaged in some other educational activity. In coming up with the reasons for this increase I cannot go past the explanation given in Fairfield City Council's excellent publication called Fairfield City: community profile, which, talking about the wonderful 61 per cent increase in students attending TAFE and the 110 per cent increase in the number of people engaged in some other educational activity, says:
