SPEECH.PARA: This increase could be explained by a number of factors including the growing national trend for all those wishing to stay in the workforce to continue to seek further education, the increase in the early 1990s of the number of federally funded employment training centres in Fairfield, the emergence of the University of Western Sydney in the region and by our population growth.

The Australian traineeship scheme is a particularly proud achievement of this government. Since 1985 more than 63,500 people have commenced traineeships and 90 per cent of the participants in the scheme are still employed in their chosen fields two years later. This is one of the most impressive success rates for a labour market program that I have ever seen.

PARA.TAB: The traineeship system is particularly important because Australia is almost alone in the world in its continued reliance on apprenticeships. Australia and the Germanic nations are the only countries where apprenticeships are still a dominant form of training. The traineeship scheme complements the apprenticeship system and ensures that we have a training regime that caters for all aspects of our society.

Traineeships cater very much for service industries, whereas apprenticeships have traditionally been for manual labour training. With the service sector employing an ever expanding percentage of the work force, the importance of the Australian traineeship system is plain for all to see. The days of large numbers of people working in a service industry with no training are, I am pleased to say, over. Computers now dominate design and information. The prevalence of computers and the achievement of multiskilling through award restructuring mean that our workers in services undertake a wide variety of tasks and must be highly skilled.

Traineeships have also opened up formally structured training to females. Apprenticeships have, of course, traditionally been male domains. As recently as 1991, more than 90 per cent of apprenticeships accounted for half of teenage male employment. The traineeship system has formalised training in fields traditionally dominated by females, where on the job experience used to be the only training and there was no recognition of those skills obtained. Much emphasis, I am pleased to say, has been given to encouraging women in the upper echelons of business and the public sector, and this is justly important.

But more important for the majority of women is the opportunity for females to gain entry level training in the field of their choice. I am glad that the Australian traineeship system is assisting in this regard. The situation for females will improve even further when the Australian vocational training certificate system is up and running. The introduction of the vocational training system was a major recommendation of the Carmichael report.

Some of the additional places provided under this bill are career start traineeships. Career start traineeships are a bridge. They are a bridge between the Australian traineeship system and the vocational certificate trainee training system. The career start positions are more versatile than the normal traineeships. They allow recruitment from a very wide age group and certainly enable more industries to tailor the traineeships to their needs. Career start traineeships allow young people to enter the work force while obtaining accredited training. The trainees can spend as much as 50 per cent of their time in training in their second year. The career start program shows the potential of a vocational certificate training program.

The introduction of the vocational certificate will, I believe, be an improvement to the training system and certainly is of major importance. I am particularly impressed with the concept of pathways that will be introduced with the Australian vocational certificate training system. A pathway is a combination of training, education and work experience that leads to a qualification. A pathway is what we need. It gives persons about to finish compulsory education a broad choice of ways in which to reach their particular goals.

Perhaps more importantly, the Australian vocational certificate training system will allow trainees to switch between pathways to suit their needs and the needs of their particular employers. For example, a person who studies until year 12 and does not wish to go on to university could undergo three years of training and work experience, or could first undergo a vocational year at a TAFE or senior college. This could comprise training for about 60 per cent of the year, and structured work experience for the remainder of the year.

If someone does not complete year 12, the AVC will provide vocationally oriented education, equivalent to the last two years of school. Apprenticeships and traineeships will be merged into one qualification—the Australian vocational certificate. There will be four nationally recognised levels of attainment: AVC levels 1, 2, 3 and 4. By 2001, the government hopes to have 90 per cent of our 20-year-olds completing AVC level 2 or proceeding to a higher level; and also to have 60 per cent of our 22-year-olds holding AVC level 3 or higher, or be proceeding to a higher qualification. That is not a bad goal.

One important change from the current system is that the new certificates will be competency based, not time based. So trainees will move on to the next level when they have achieved competency at the previous level. This system is much more efficient than the current time based system. It allows trainees to work at their own pace and ensures that they do not graduate until they have proved competency in all of the fields they will need to call on in their future vocation.

The other major improvement to be introduced with the Australian vocational certificate training system is that it will be available to people of all ages. Unlike our normal traineeships and apprenticeships, people who wish to be retrained and adults re-entering the work force after some time will be eligible to become trainees. Thus, Australia will have an integrated trainee and education system to meet the demands placed on us by our ever changing world economy—a world economy that will be much more service orientated and where information will be the primary commodity.

The term `information superhighway' has probably been overused. However, it is an undeniable fact that the ability of our work force to capitalise on high technology will be the major determinant of our national wealth over the coming decades. We will need a work force which is highly skilled in the information technology which increasingly is dominating the service industries.

This government has improved Australia's training system beyond recognition. The introduction of the Australian traineeship system itself in 1985 was a major innovation. The 16,000 new traineeship places created in this bill will be of invaluable assistance, both to our young people seeking employment and to the drive to increase the skills base of our Australian work force. The steps toward the Australian vocational certificate taken in this bill are steps in the process of making the Australian trainee system equal to the best in the world. That is not a bad thing to achieve, and that is why I commend this excellent bill to the Main Committee and to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity to participate in this debate on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1994. The opposition has no real problems with the basic thrust of the bill. A year and a half ago, the government made a commitment to shift funding from the tertiary sector to the training sector. It made a commitment to energise the vocational training market in Australia. It made a commitment to vocational training far beyond any national commitment that had ever been made before. I support, in general, the thrust of those moves.

PARA.TAB: Under the Prime Minister's direction, the government made a fundamental decision to increase the funding to vocational education and training without establishing either a clear goal or the mechanisms to be able to accomplish it. ANTA, the Australian National Training Authority, was a compromise. The concept of ANTA was that it would act as a bank. It would take the government's expanded funding and the state's funding for vocational training and send it back to the states to allow them to fund TAFE and other institutions. This concept is a difficult one to come to grips with. I must admit that I still have some problem with the concept and in coming to grips with how this really works and how the central bank concept will, in fact, encourage additional training. I will be pleasantly surprised if, in fact, it works.

It seems to me that the training market in Australia is really at a crossroads. This is a complex issue, because there are many players and there are not necessarily clear outcomes specified in my view at the moment. We have a system of technical colleges called TAFE; these have grown up across Australia over a very long time. We have some private providers of vocational education and training; in particular, the ACM facility in Richmond comes to mind as being an excellent private provider of vocational training.

We have senior secondary schools or secondary schools around the country, many of which provide some degree of entry into vocational training and/or direct competing vocational education courses. Also we have industry itself. There are not only industry bodies like ACM who supply vocational training but also other companies—generally larger companies and some medium sized companies—who have their own training facilities, their own training personnel and run their own training agenda.

At the moment there is no consistency within the system. The honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) spoke in the debate before me about the apprenticeship system and how it had fallen out of favour around the world, but that it was still in general use in Australia. One of the reasons it is in use in Australia is that employers value it. It is valued not only by employers but also by apprentices themselves. These are the people who wish to work in trades: they value the apprenticeship and they value the certificate that they get as a result of their apprenticeship which generally takes four years but sometimes less.

There are a number of competing interests. As well there are the industry training advisory boards. There is a Department of Employment, Education and Training in Canberra; there are training departments of one form or another in the states; and there are other bureaucratic organisations that impinge on how all this operates.

Theoretically, ANTA is supposed to bring it all together and make it work under the new Australian vocational certificate system. In concept, that system itself is rather simple. There are four levels of certification. But once we get beyond that simple level of certification, the system, as it exists today, is really quite complex. In reviewing the system, the so-called Fitzgerald report of the Allen Consulting Group has said that it is so complex it is not going to work. Rather than being driven by the market—that is, by the people who want the training, by the institutions who are there to provide it and by the industry which will use it—it is so bureaucratic and so top-driven that the system is in danger of not even getting off the ground. It is like trying to load a Boeing 707 with five elephants and expecting it to make it off the ground at Mascot.
At this point, I refer to a portion of the summary of Dr Fitzgerald's report and his letter to Mr Brian Finn. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: We encountered a wide range of attitudes and experiences and some strongly held and conflicting views of the reforms—
that is, the reforms in the vocational education and training system—

While much has been achieved, we were left in no doubt that there are significant implementation difficulties. We agree with the recent statement by the Honourable Ross Free that, without decisive action by all parties to rectify the difficulties, the reform process is in danger of stalling.

From my contacts in the training market around the country—indeed, as I have participated in inquiries with the Deputy Speaker in the chair today, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), into group training in various states around the country—it seems to me that what is said in that letter I have quoted is inevitably true: everyone seems confused abut the great range of initiatives that are available and how they should work.

PARA.TAB: If you think about it in simple terms, it seems to me that we need a relatively simple system that will allow young people in secondary school to decide on some general career path and to be able to take courses that will direct them in a technical or a vocational direction rather than for 100 per cent of those students to be directing their energies at a totally general academic education designed as an entry point to university. Certainly, we are never going to be able to afford to educate every Australian at university.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you want them to keep options open?
—Always keep options open. It is a matter of not only whether we can afford it but also whether it is appropriate for every Australian.

PARA.TAB: The jobs that are available today and will be available in the future will not be able to support a 100 per cent tertiary educated population. I refer to the country that I was born in where a decision was made a long time ago, back in the 1950s, that industry would do the training if the school system in the States supplied young people with 12 years of high quality general education in a general academic degree. But that system has not worked well because the industry has not provided the vocational education and training that it might have. Technologically, in many instances, that country has not grown to the heights it might have, had it adopted more of a dual stream approach along the lines of Austria or Germany, or some combination of those approaches.

Australia is finally coming to grips with this matter. We have finally decided as a nation that we value education. So young people are staying on at school in greater numbers to year 12 and finishing 12 basic years of primary and high school education. Many want to go on to university and there are not enough places for them.
A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension, I think I was talking about the normal progression through the training system. It would be highly desirable if we could offer a broad range of technical and vocational courses across the country in our secondary schools. Those courses, the skills that are gained and the qualifications gained should be certified and transferable. People could continue their education at a TAFE or at a private training institution, or go on to a university, or whatever. People could stop the training at any point, but they would be able to have a record of the modules that have been studied and the competencies that have been gained.

PARA.TAB: However, the system that we have now set up is so highly bureaucratised and so difficult to manage that it is not going to work. That, essentially, is what Dr Fitzgerald has told Brian Finn, the Chairman of ANTA. I will continue quoting from Dr Fitzgerald's letter to Brian Finn. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The lack of strong commitment to the reforms by business—many enterprises of all sizes and many business organisations—is a key concern. At the core of this concern is what we feel is the key problem: that the reforms to date have lacked any strong focus on the demand side—that is, on what is actually needed to deliver to Australian enterprises, especially small and medium sized enterprises, the skills they need in order to compete in the new more open market environment. The reforms cannot succeed unless business values them. engages with them and leads them.

The fundamental point is that there is no sense in adopting the attitude that we, as trainers, know better than industry what skills we need to teach trainees now and in the future. It is a nonsense; it has always been a nonsense. However, there is still that ingrained attitude in some of the training bureaucracies that the bureaucracy itself knows better than industry what industry needs. Unless industry is given a strong voice in the development of a simple system, the system will fail. There is no way that the system can operate properly. We cannot just abandon apprenticeships or the emerging traineeship system. They are well accepted throughout the business community. If we abandon them in favour of a certification system, which business has not accepted and does not understand, we will likely destroy the training market altogether. That will be of no use to anyone.

PARA.TAB: These industry training advisory boards are a real mixed bag. Some of them are very good—they have good industry people who understand the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises, and they try to work on simple solutions in terms of course structure, curriculum and certification—but some of them are just an absolute nonsense. They are driven totally by bureaucrats and/or a union agenda, or whatever, to the point that they are failing their constituency. Dr Fitzgerald's letter goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: In our view, the key to successful reform is to re-configure the reforms starting from the demand side, and to re-design them around a richer concept of the training market (than has so far been in use), centred on direct client relationships between enterprises and individuals and trainee providers.
That is the key and it is what I have said. Dr Fitzgerald's next sentence is very interesting. It reads:

Introducing `User Buys'—allowing enterprises and individuals investing in recognised, contractual training to direct public funds for off-the-job training to a provider of their choice—is, we believe, a critical step to shift the drive to the demand side and to lift the performance and responsiveness of trainee providers.

That is a very simple concept. We can call it a voucher system. Basically, if we empower those who are going to be trained to take their Commonwealth-state contribution—the money that they receive from ANTA—to a training institution of their choice, we will find that the institutions develop courses that are wanted by the clients. And why do the clients want those courses? Because industry says, `This is what we need to be able to give you a job.' It seems to me that we have to move in that direction, regardless of the ideological difficulties of, say, the Australian Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: If we do not consider funding the student, we are unlikely to get the best mix of course structuring curriculum that the student needs for real certified training that means something to employers. Dr Fitzgerald goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: With the same demand side perspective, we feel that a new national competency standards framework is needed, which is less detailed and prescriptive and gives considerably more flexibility to enterprises and individuals to meet the skill formation needs they require to compete, but within a nationally consistent system in which skills can be widely recognised and portable. This is especially important at entry level.

Boy, is it ever! During our tours around the country, we spoke to group training companies, employers, trainees and apprentices employed by group training companies. Everywhere we went, they told us about the importance of pre-vocational training. People in small business—be it a hairdresser, a motor mechanic, a car wrecker or whatever—told us that if a person comes to them as a first-year apprentice with pre-vocational training they are ready to go to work and they are useful to the small business. The small businesses can then afford to hire apprentices and help train the people that their industry will need in the future. It is important that our system is nationally consistent.

PARA.TAB: Earlier this year I used study leave money to go to Scotland and Austria to examine their vocational education and training systems. Some might say that Scotland and Austria are a strange mix. I went to Scotland because my understanding was that in the English-speaking world the Scottish have developed a system supervised by Scotvec—the Scottish Vocational Education Council—which is possibly the model that Australia might use to fabricate a simple system.Scotvec is the certifying authority: it says that the course structure is satisfactory and the curriculum is all right. Then it certifies the certifiers. It says that this individual is now qualified to certify people who come and say, `I have had this kind of training.' So Scotvec certifies high schools, the national training institutes like our TAFEs, industries which train themselves and private providers. It also certifies the course structure or curriculum. It is made up in modules.

If people in Scotland who have been through the system in the last few years want to tell a prospective new employer what skills they have, they simply ring Scotvec and ask for a fax. The computer then prints the sheet that says, `John Jones who lives at this address has had these courses. He has passed them all.' There is no A, B, C, D. It is, `You are competent in this or you are not. You can weld mild steel or you cannot.' People can get a complete print-out. One assumes that in the future it will be cradle to grave so everything will keep adding to it. It is a simple system; there is one piece of paper to tell every employer what the person has been through, what qualifications they have, what range of skills they have and what mix of skills they have. It seems to me that we should look very closely at the Scottish system. I think it might offer us some advantage. Mr Deputy Speaker, I could speak on this bill and on this topic for hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want an extension?

—Thank you very much, but I think probably not. Before I quit I would simply make a plea about the group training system in Australia which is unique to Australia and which is so valuable to us. I strongly believe that it should be expanded and used further in order to advantage both apprentices and trainees. This would give us a base to supply small and medium-sized business with trained people and would allow them to participate in the training market and in training people for their own future needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor Mr G.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to speak on this bill before the committee, the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1994. Might I commend some of the previous speakers who have spoken in this debate on their contribution to the committee and the debate on this topic. I think it is one where we can genuinely have a bipartisan debate about the training needs of the Australian work force. There may well at times be some controversy about the means by which we go about training our work force and educating our work force but the baseline is that all members of this committee have a very strong interest in providing the structures, the institutions and the systems that will provide their electors with the maximum opportunity to participate in the economic system.

PARA.TAB: I was very interested in some of the comments that were made by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) and the contribution that he has made to this debate. As he said himself, it is an area of particular concern. He does come from a business background and he is very well qualified to speak from a business perspective on these sorts of issues. I will take up some of those matters that the honourable member raised a little bit later in the debate.

If we go back to basics, economic growth is simply about the production of goods and services and the employment of human beings in the process. To be a productive unit in a modern industrial society requires a great degree of skill and, to acquire the required skills in that economy, one must undertake substantial education and training. In the society that we have at the moment, you can acquire those skills yourself, undertake a discrete training course which sets out in a programmed way the paths to the acquisition of those skills, or do on-the-job training within an enterprise and develop some specialised skills within that enterprise. Indeed, you can have a combination of all of those methods.

The massive investment that Australia has made in education and training over the past two decades is absolutely necessary if this country is to maintain its competitive advantage in the international marketplace. It is up to every individual to develop skills in an ongoing sense. I came into this parliament in 1993 and, once I had got over the initial shock wave of being in the national parliament, I had to sit down and make an inventory of the skills that I had and the skills that I would require to merely survive in this job, let alone to be an effective representative of my constituents.

I believe that the honourable member for La Trobe was on the speed reading course that many members undertook to try to get through the volume of paper that was coming across our desks. I have had to look at my organisational skills. Being a global thinker, as is the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), I find that sometimes the itsy-bitsy details of things require some organisation and attention, and I have had to look at my own organisational skills. I have certainly had to pay some attention to my public speaking skills and, of course, my people handling skills have had to be worked on, as well. So even in the job of parliamentarian—

TALK.START.PARA: —You handle people, do you?

—I handle people, but not with an iron bar! Whatever occupation we are in, be it as a member of the national parliament or as a young person entering the work force, we really do have to assess the skills that we require to perform the tasks that we are asked to do, and we have to set about acquiring and improving those skills. Therefore, I am very pleased that the federal government is putting resources into vocational education and training. We have made a substantial commitment over the past decade in the resources that we have provided to up-skill the Australian population and to give all Australians an adequate opportunity to be educated and trained and to participate in the work force.

PARA.TAB: But I must express some disappointment with the Victorian government for the way that they have handled the education issue in that state. There may be elements of what I am about to say that the honourable member for La Trobe might disagree with. But, in essence, Victoria's competitive advantage has always been in the high quality of its educational and training institutions. What we are seeing today in the state of Victoria is a very dangerous running-down in the educational assets of the state.

The numbers of very experienced teachers who have left the education system, and the loads that are now being carried by teachers in those institutions—and, indeed, the way in which the government has gone about its rationalisation process—have all left me with some deep concerns about the future of education in the state of Victoria. I am not saying that the educational system, from time to time, does not need reform. I am not saying that it ought not be examined by the government of the day, nor that measures should not be taken by that government to achieve its expressed, legitimate objectives.

I would say this to the Kennett government: `Think very carefully about the way in which you institute your rationalisation of this particular sector because, if you do not, you may well destroy the economic advantage that the state of Victoria currently enjoys.' We are, if I might be so arrogant to say this, the intellectual powerhouse of the Commonwealth. Indeed I have, sitting beside me, one of the nation's priceless intellectual assets who I hope will participate in this debate—and, of course, the honourable member for La Trobe is doing his apprenticeship in that regard.

If we look at Australia in the 1990s and beyond the year 2000, it is very clear what sort of work force Australia will need to maintain that competitive position that I alluded to before. Now these are words that educationalists fling about, politicians fling about and business leaders fling about with gay abandon—if I might use that particular word these days in the House—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in Tasmania.

—Not in Tasmania. I am glad the honourable member reminded me that I do have the licence to say that in the national parliament. These people say that we do need a highly skilled work force; we do need a flexible work force; we do need an adaptive work force. Now they are very fine words, but what do they mean in practice? We do need a stock of human capital that is very comfortable with the new technologies that are emerging in industry. We need a work force that is capable of developing the new workplace attitudes and the workplace relationships that are absolutely critical and vital to progress the economic future of the enterprises in which people work. So we know the sort of work force that we need, and we have some very strong educational and training assets in this country that position us well for achieving those sorts of qualities and skills for our work force.

PARA.TAB: This particular bill before the committee today, the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1994, really sets the level of Commonwealth vocational and educational training funding over the years 1994 to 1996. It provides payment to ANTA for additional trainees under the Australian traineeship system and under the career start traineeships. The Commonwealth provides grants to the states and territories for vocational education. Prior to 1 January 1994, that funding was provided under the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act, the act which was replaced by the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act that we are debating here today.

This act directs all funds to ANTA, which was established by the Australian National Training Authority Act. The functions of ANTA are, quite simply, the allocation of this funding and the administering of national training programs. The object of the Australian National Training Authority Act is to establish the national vocational educational and training system and to develop closer interactions between industry, vocational education and training providers. I will take up that particular point in a minute, Mr Deputy Speaker, but the act also has other objectives of developing effective training markets and improving cross-sectoral links in the economy.

Now the member for La Trobe, who preceded me in this debate, made some reference to and comment on the need for industry to participate to a greater degree in identifying training needs and communicating these to training institutions. I do not think anybody would disagree with the basic premise that he articulated here before the committee. But, in saying that, he ought not confuse short-term and long-term considerations. The education system—indeed, education itself—has whole-of-life goals. Industry tends to concentrate on the here and now. We need to encourage flexibility in providing training and education to our work force. I think, though, that the honourable member for La Trobe makes a very valid point. I was in Western Australia recently, and I had the good fortune to visit Oceanfast, one of the premier boat builders in this country at the moment. In talking to the proprietor, John Farrell, about how the company has developed a young and very skilled work force, there is a very interesting story.

Mr Farrell made some very interesting comments about youth in the work force. As we travel out through our electorates and speak to employers, we often hear people saying that young people today are lazy, that they talk back and give a bit of lip, and that really they do not want to work. That is a common view which is often expressed by employers when they are talking about the young people who are coming out of the educational institutions into the work force.

Mr Farrell said that he employs a lot of prima donnas in his enterprise—long-haired prima donnas, with rings through their noses and bells in their ears, and all sorts of things. However, he then went on to say that he produces an exotic product and so he needs exotic workers. He said that the problem that he faced in developing the skills over time of the young people that he now employs in his enterprise was the fact that they did not want to undertake apprenticeship training. They preferred to be in his enterprise.

Those young people loathed going to the TAFE institution in Perth because the curriculum that they were encouraged to undertake at the TAFE had them learning how to plane wood when the enterprise itself was working with rather exotic metals. So the training that the apprentices were undertaking in these institutions did not match the demands and the needs of the enterprise.

Oceanfast is an enterprise that is going to double its productive capacity over the next three years. The exports from that particular industry will, according to Mr Farrell, be worth a billion dollars by the turn of the century. This is the sort of niche productive area of manufacturing that we need to be in, but it took a rather long time for Oceanfast and the TAFE in question in Perth to negotiate an appropriate training set-up for the young people who are employed in that enterprise.

That highlights the point that the honourable member for La Trobe was alluding to when he talked about a bureaucratised and difficult to manage training system that will not work. It is very important that industries' needs are correctly identified by the training institutions and the training providers. It is very important that that communication occurs between them.

The Working Nation statement makes quite clear the objectives of the government's training reforms. The bill before this committee and the House provides for extra payments to ANTA. Clause 4 of the bill inserts a new section, section 9A, which provides for additional funding in 1995-96. In 1994 there will be an increase from $639 million to $673.6. In 1995 there will be an increase from $719 million to $755 million. In 1996 a set amount payable will be made at $835.5 million. This funding will be made available to ensure that the Working Nation promise of 50,000 new training places is achieved.

In Geelong, a very interesting training experiment is being undertaken by both Alcoa and the Gordon Technical College. The Australian vocational certificate is being developed there in partnership between Alcoa and the Gordon Technical College. That is in keeping once again with the problem that the honourable member for La Trobe raised about the need to provide alternative pathways for young people to get into the work force, and those should really begin at years 11 and 12.

The Alcoa-Gordon TAFE partnership in the Australian vocational certificate program provides that VCE students get on-the-job engineering training. Some 16 students from James Harrison Secondary College in Geelong are currently participating in the program. The students complete a two-year traineeship at Alcoa's Point Henry plant. The program is, indeed, a first. Teenagers earn industry qualifications during their VCE and they also earn award based wages.

This scheme is subsidised by the federal government and it greatly enhances the work prospects of the young people who are engaged in it. When completed, the students have two-thirds of an engineering production certificate and their VCE. They can then choose their future paths, either university or apprenticeships, with a degree of confidence in the skills that they have acquired. The benefits are quite clear for the students. When I visited Alcoa quite recently, I was greatly encouraged by the enlightened management at Alcoa. I was also greatly encouraged by the attitude among the young people who were undertaking that vocational training certificate.

Before I close, I would like to pick up on some of the training issues that were raised in a speech given by the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) on 25 August 1994. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Corangamite occupies the electorate on the other side of the Barwon River. He made some very interesting comments. I was very surprised at the comments that the honourable member made. In his speech, which generally dealt with training issues and the case management system, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The initiatives dealt with by this bill—
he is referring to the Employment Services Bill here, but it relates to training—
are simply more costly and bureaucratic attempts to diffuse the political issue of unemployment in time for the 1996 federal election.

Let me say that that is not the government's intention in that bill or this bill. Our intentions in the education and training area are quite clearly stated in the white paper and have been articulated by ministers in the House.

PARA.TAB: If, indeed, unemployment was an issue at the last election, one would have expected that I would have suffered a decrease in my vote and that he would have experienced an increase in his, but the opposite was the case: I got an increase and he suffered a decrease. The reason that the honourable member for Corangamite suffered a decrease in his vote was that he went to that particular election articulating policies that would have created more unemployment in the Geelong region. He certainly is a disciple of Fightback. He is really into the sort of backwards industrial relations policy that we do not need in this country. He was also into massive cuts to government expenditure. On the issue of the case management system, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The case management strategy represents a total misunderstanding of what is required to create new employment opportunities and reduce the impact of long-term unemployment.
Jobs are created when the government provides an environment in which businesses want to invest, expand and employ people.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that we have a very good economic environment here in Australia today that will encourage firms to invest and to provide employment opportunities. The case management system is not simply a focus on the long-term unemployed to the detriment of the short-term unemployed. It is an attempt to come to grips with the human needs of those who find themselves in unemployment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I grew up in a period when pretty well everybody had a job and education and training was not as important as it is today. I am still old-fashioned enough to believe that three per cent unemployment is desirable and, hopefully, over the medium term, achievable. I am somewhat bewildered when I hear the continuing discussion about vocational education and training over the long term. My first contact with the political realities of education came when I was chairman of a school council, then in local government and then in my industry association. When I was a member of the Rural Training Council of Australia I had many visits to Canberra during which I had to find my way around the maze of the various training authorities and industry bodies. However, I still cannot overcome that nostalgia I feel for that three per cent figure—that full employment figure. That is where I am coming from and I offer those remarks as a preface to the main body of the issues I want to discuss.

PARA.TAB: While the coalition supports the amendments contained in the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1994, it does not support this government's attitude towards training. I fully support, of course, the motion of the member for Braddon (Mr Miles), to condemn the government for its lack of direction on training.

It is clear that this government does not live up to its rhetoric on the importance of training and education. I refer, for example, to my speech earlier this week, outlining the financial differences between Austudy and the jobsearch allowance. People on Austudy are clearly worse off in the short term than are their counterparts on unemployment benefits. If the government really wanted to match its claim to support training and education, it would make Austudy match the jobsearch allowance.

Sadly, the government is more concerned with public perception. Of course, all governments and oppositions have to be concerned about that, but it is that emphasis on public perception which sometimes distracts all of us away from the real job that we should be doing—that is, getting this unemployment rate down, particularly the rate of unemployment amongst young people.

Take another example: the government proposes to abolish the jobsearch allowance for 15- to 17-year-olds, from January next year, and replace it with a youth training allowance. What will be the difference? Unfortunately, not that much difference at all. It is just a name change, and part of this government's continual marketing campaign. I can just imagine the government press release in the middle of next year: `So many thousands of young people are receiving the youth training wage. Training in this country is really taking off.' Of course, it is all smoke and mirrors. These will still be young people without jobs on the training treadmill.

The coalition supports the funding of ANTA to enable it to carry out its roles and responsibilities. We also support increased funding to provide further places for traineeships. However, we are disappointed with the Labor government's record on vocational education, particularly apprenticeships. Here, we must look at the figures. I am sure they have been much quoted, but they bear quoting again. I had to get them checked to satisfy myself that they were right. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, in 1990 we had 162,600 apprentices. What is our target for 1994? It is only 46,000 apprenticeships. It sounds a lot, but when we look at the needs of Australia it is nowhere near enough. While the 1995-96 target of 60,000 new apprenticeships is an improvement, it will still not meet the level seen in 1990. We believe that ANTA needs to be given more direction from this government, as does training in this country in general. ANTA, itself, has requested more direction and re-examination of government training policy.

The Fitzgerald report, commissioned by ANTA, is extremely critical of government training reform policies. The report concluded that the current approach to reform will not bring about the fundamental outcomes desired. However, the government does not seem to want to listen. It has, of course, sought to bury this report. The government has had this report for some time, but whereas the government can respond to a Bulletin article immediately, it takes time to respond to matters of urgency such as training for our million unemployed. ANTA's criticism does not sit well with the government's rhetoric on Working Nation and the training initiatives which Working Nation supposedly contains.

Some Labor ministers are quite fond of quoting from the press, so I might follow this trend myself for a moment. Here are some newspaper headlines which followed the release of Working Nation, headlines which are undoubtedly echoed in the ANTA report which the government is trying to hide: `Working Nation: a crutch or a cure?', `Grand plan: but how sound is the planning?', `Results unlikely to match the claims,' `Jobs, for how long?' and `White Paper draws a costly blank on new jobs.'

Let us have another look at the rhetoric of Working Nation. It introduced a youth training initiative, another program to crow about. And what does the youth training initiative offer? It will offer intensive case management so that people under 18 will have the assistance of a case manager in the search for suitable work. My question is: what has the CES been doing for the past couple of years? Correct me if I am wrong, but is it not the role of the CES to assist people to find suitable jobs? This is just more smoke and mirrors, more potential publicity for the government next year to announce that it is taking action on training.

The government has been in power for 11 years. It has been there so long that it does not seem to think that it needs to implement policy any more. This government believes it can fool the Australian people if it continues its relentless publicity campaign. The government thinks that all it has to do to keep the Australian people happy on the unemployment issue is change the names of its training programs.

That is the constant theme that I hear around the country. Are we just going to be recycled? When are we going to see those real jobs? Personally, I wonder when Australians will have the employment security that my country gave to me. I guess I took it for granted then and I have to feel for those young people now.

I do not believe that Australian people are so silly that they cannot see the lack of effect that government policies are having on their own lives. Australian families can see that increasingly their children, their parents, are out of work. They can see that it is increasingly difficult to get into university or get an apprenticeship.

The government's treatment of the ANTA report is typical of the government's approach, typical of a government that has been in power for too long and does not know how to fix the mess it has created. I fully support the motion of the member for Braddon (Mr Miles) that the government be condemned for the lack of direction in its approach to training reform and its mismanagement of this vitally important area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to add my voice in this debate but I will not take quite as negative an approach as some of my colleagues. I think that there is, within this whole regime—albeit skewed somewhat by some of the hype of the white paper—the ability to achieve quite a number of outcomes for training and apprenticeships in Australia.

PARA.TAB: We are examining today the Vocational Education and Training Amendment Bill of 1994, which sets the level of vocational education and training from the years 1994 to 1996. As several members have stated, this bill in essence takes over from the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act of 1989 and supplements the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act of 1992. The bill appropriates funding to 1996 in accordance with the Commonwealth's undertakings to the heads of government agreement.

I have no problem with the general thrust of the bill, but I have several reservations about implementation and the government's real commitment to the vocational training outcomes. There have been massive changes in training in Australia over the last two decades, which have been influenced by technological change and mistakes made in block training and apprenticeships. Block training became a turn-off to employers, and the states that had seven-week block training will know just what I mean. Employers just got to the point where they would not take these kids but, strangely, the system persisted with it. Rather than adapting to needs of industry, it persisted with it and, to my way of thinking, that became the point from which apprenticeships started to drop off.

Balanced with this has been the need for competency based training and the need for training in areas not necessarily associated with the formally recognised trades. All those things began to impact on apprenticeships and what we know today as traineeships.

As the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) has said, training needs to be demand driven, and that does not happen in many areas. Some of the apprenticeships are driven—this might be a bit of an outrageous statement, but I will make it nonetheless—by some of the politically correct agenda setters, especially in the fields of conservation programs. I am not knocking conservation programs and I think traineeships in this field can be quite appropriate, but I think some of them have become an end in themselves rather than being the basis of some real training.

Some other traineeships are driven by pressure groups and by those pressure groups' expectations rather than the outcomes for the students or the clients in the programs. A great deal of development still needs to go into traineeships if they are to be relevant to business and to industry. It says something about the program that only 70 per cent of traineeships, which are generally only one year in length, come to fruition. Without in any way disparaging them, there is not a hard intellectual edge to traineeships; and if kids and even mature adults who take on traineeships are pulling out before they get to the end of their programs I think we have to say there is a lack of expectation in their minds and perhaps a feeling that they are on Mickey Mouse courses.

That then begs the question as to who is the most appropriate deliverer of traineeship schemes. I have had a lot of experience in this field over 10 or more years, and during that time I have seen TAFE almost lose direction in most of its fields. I know there are some very highly focused TAFE colleges around Australia, but I know there are others that seem to have totally lost focus. I can cite the fact, for example, that in Queensland the state government now tends to put all the diesel courses in one TAFE college, the plumbing courses in another and the automotive courses in another. While there may be some short-term financial gains in that, we are seeing the slow erosion of the idea of a TAFE college being a repository of the skills of the particular community or region.

On the other side of TAFE training there are some excellent courses in secretarial studies, computer technology and management in general. Sadly, I think that has possessed some of the TAFE colleges to want to become what the CAEs were. They want to become de facto colleges of advanced education. I have even heard senior personnel of those TAFE colleges speak disparagingly about vocational training. That is part of the crisis. If the recognised deliverer, the TAFE college, is now starting to move away from its prime role as the deliverer of the technical side of vocational training, then indeed we have a crisis. I notice, too, that, because of this void in some areas of Australia, skillshare has picked up the role in many traineeship areas that a decade ago one might reasonably have expected would have been carried out by TAFE. This is not said with any criticism of skillshare. I think it is a marvellous program.

Earlier, the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) outlined the government's expectation of this program. I cite the 50,000 places that she spoke about: 14,000 apprenticeship places, 15,000 for the ATS and CST traineeships, 1,000 Commonwealth trainees, 5,000 off-the-job training places, 5,000 new pre-vocational places and 10,000 new places within the current labour market programs. I think that is quite a worthy objective, but again it is all a bit soft. It requires the Commonwealth itself to pick up 1,000 of these traineeships.

A chart that is available to coalition members in an additional explanatory paper shows that between 1990 and 1994, apprenticeships in Australia had dropped from 162,600 to an anticipated 46,000. The thing that really staggers me, Mr Deputy Speaker, is to think that in just five years apprenticeships have gone down to less than a third of what they were. To me that says there is a crisis in vocational training.

We have to ask ourselves: what organisations around Australia have done something about arresting that problem? Group Training Australia, which has some official and unofficial affiliates, has done a great deal to consolidate the position of apprenticeships. At present, Group Training Australia delivers 32 per cent of all the apprenticeships in Australia.

We might ask: why has it been successful? It has increased its apprenticeships by 21 per cent whereas other apprenticeships are going down at a rate of 21 per cent. As I have said, perhaps technology, block training problems and the economic downturn of the last four or five years have all played a part. I think group training is more successful because it offers its clients a greater depth of experience. A person is not saddled with one builder, one plumber or one automotive workshop for the whole of his or her three or four years of training. In group training, the apprentices have the experience of moving from one employer to another, so their breadth of experience is increased.

With this comes the responsibility that someone has to oversee the clients and make sure that they are not just moved physically from one employer to another employer. Their general wellbeing and their focus as a student, as well as the fact that they are an employee, all have to be nurtured. To do that, group training is required to have quite a few employees; it has to have appropriate staff. It requires apprenticeship masters and a basic administration structure if it is responsible for their salaries. It is responsible to government to see that salaries, tax, workers compensation, tool allowances, and a whole raft of things, are properly paid. One of the reasons employers find the group apprenticeship scheme attractive is that they can take over a group apprentice and know that all that sort of work is being handled by the scheme. The scheme bills the employer on a weekly, fortnightly or monthly basis and it takes the responsibility and worry away from the employer.

The other thing that the group apprenticeship scheme offers is pastoral care. I think that is another reason that it has such a great strike rate in getting its apprentices through. Finally, there is another feature, and those of us who have been on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, and who have been interested in the field, will know that the group apprenticeship scheme is now at the forefront of delivering meaningful—and I stress the word `meaningful'—competency based training, to the point now where it has a form of accelerated training that is delivered on site by TAFE teachers.

What they are now doing is on the site with TAFE and other teachers. Take building, for example: they are learning the whole minutiae of the trade in their first year. All those blocks of six and seven weeks that bedevilled employers in the past are being done under the supervision of the group apprenticeship scheme. There are apprentice masters and contracted TAFE teachers, all in the first year. In the second, third and fourth years, all that work is behind them and they become a very valuable commodity to the employer.

I am sure that that is the field where the government should be directing its funding. That is the proven field. It is proven for a number of reasons. Firstly, the clients are better cared for. Secondly, they are being better trained. Thirdly, they are receiving a variety in their training. Fourthly, they are getting their block training and their general academic work condensed into one year's intensive training. As I said, it is on-the-job training. If a problem crops up in the classroom, the young people can be taken immediately from that classroom on to the site and shown the problem first hand. They can look at it, understand it, come back into the classroom and move on. At the end of a year of doing that, that particular student is very valuable to an employer.

The other thing is that it means that the employer knows that, for the second, third and fourth year, not only are clients or students better trained but they will have no distractions in carrying out their duties. Because of this accelerated form of training, it is possible now for an apprentice, say, in the building industry—and I am talking about a bright apprentice; I am not just talking about run of the mill—who wants to commit himself or herself to some pretty hard work to get through the course in 2 3/4years. That is a huge saving to government and a huge input into the vocational skills profile of Australia. I would recommend to the minister or to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Snowdon), who is here today representing him, that that might be the way we should go.

Without being a killjoy, I will bet pounds to peanuts the government will not get 14,000 new apprentices up this year unless it accesses something like a group apprenticeship scheme. In fact, I think it might be hard pressed to get more than a couple of thousand on. It is going to be no easier for it to get those apprentices into the system than it has been for individual kids to get themselves into the system over the last two decades unless there is another carrot, unless there is another conduit that makes life easy.

Having said that—and this is where we start coming back to traineeships—there was a move two years ago to withdraw funding from group apprenticeship schemes. I am sure honourable members know that those schemes were set up jointly with Lend Lease in conjunction with the ACTU and called ACTU Lend Lease. It was a great combination of union and business in a very highly focused program. They would set up each scheme, get the mechanisms in place and, from that, the actual individual schemes around Australia merged. As honourable members are probably also aware, as well as delivering apprenticeships, these have also become the vehicle for traineeships. I must say it will be an outrage if the government withdraws funding from the core activity of those organisations, namely, the group apprenticeship program. There is a body of thought in DEET and in government that that should happen.

I will again predict what will happen if that course of action is taken. I have been on one of these schemes through the recession. I know what it is like for a group of directors to be jointly and severally responsible for debts of $300,000 to keep a whole group of apprentices in jobs. That is a very stressful time for voluntary workers. If the government wants men and women of high profile in business to run these schemes, to be the white knights for the government, to deliver its programs because they cannot all be delivered through TAFE and through skillshare, it is going to have to rely on organisations like ACTU Lend Lease. It is going to have to fund their core activities properly.

Far too often we see the work of the group apprenticeship schemes being diluted. This is because the schemes are spending more time trying to access the government traineeship programs, for which they receive fees and with which they subsidise their core activity of delivering apprenticeships.That situation is back to front, Mr Deputy Speaker. I accept that the employment, education and training committee is examining this problem—and I do not want to anticipate its report—but the core activities of group apprenticeship schemes, and apprenticeships in general, must be corralled from the other activities of traineeship schemes.

When that agenda has been achieved it is not to say that the group apprenticeship scheme should not deliver traineeships. Once we secure the core activities, core focus and core outcomes of group apprenticeship schemes, it is quite appropriate that people should then bid on a performance and outcomes basis for government programs. I am quite in favour of that. However, I think it is a travesty to waste the skills and intelligence of those very committed people, and the focus of apprenticeship schemes, so that we can earn a few bob out of a traineeship scheme to prop up our other activities. That would mean that we were doing the whole thing back to front.
I support the amendment moved by the opposition in this debate. Nevertheless, the bill has a great deal to commend it and, in that respect, I support its broad thrust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adams The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major amendments proposed by the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill will set the level of Commonwealth vocational education and training funding for 1994-96. The bill will provide for payments to the Australian National Training Authority and it will also provide for additional traineeships under the Australian traineeship scheme and career start traineeships.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth provides grants to the states and territories for the provision and support of vocational education and training. The grants are primarily in the technical and further education scheme through the TAFE system. Prior to 1 January 1994, grants to the states and the territories contributed to general operating costs and infrastructure. With effect from 1 January, the funding arrangements were replaced by a single pool of funds comprising those that were previously separated.

Recurrent expenditure grants and capital expenditure grants are passed to ANTA for allocation among the states and the territories. The main provision is to enable the new section to be inserted in the act. There is currently provision for payments to ANTA for an allocation under the act of $638.960 million in 1994, and that figure will increase to $719.741 million in 1995. The new section will increase the amount payable for 1994 from $638.960 million to $673.612 million. In 1995 the amount payable to ANTA will increase from $719.741 million to $755.711 million, which sets the 1996 figure at well over $800 million.

The second section provides for payments to ANTA for additional trainees. The payments are conditional on the minister being satisfied that there is an increase in the number of people receiving training in the states and territories. We have a performance condition operating there in order that the states and the territories ensure that they pick up some of the extra apprenticeships that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), may have been mentioning. In fact, the act is allowing for an increase in funds to be allocated to this very important area of education, but increased conditional to the states performing.

Out of this money $20 million was provided to the states' adult literacy funds. All ministers agreed to split $13 million from the Commonwealth to use for language and literacy through the DEET labour market programs for people who needed or wanted to improve their literacy skills before seeking work in the marketplace. The remaining $7 million of that money went to ANTA on a population share basis, of which Tasmania received $182,336. A training profile was to be provided to address the use of this sum, and added to that was a sum of $50,000 in growth funds, making the total proportion of Commonwealth funds $232,000. Another allocation of growth funds is expected next financial year, taking the figure up to approximately $292,000.

Overall, ANTA Tasmania is receiving $9,976,000 in 1994 for recurrent funding to the TAFE system. Of that, $5.25 million is for building and equipment. There is some major building construction work going on in the Launceston TAFE area. Further, the states are being given $1,688,000 for performance based training that can be allocated as they see fit, which is where the growth in funds fits in. So if the states are performing and going ahead, they should be able to increase their funds. Next year there will be a similar allocation along those lines.

I know that the voluntary adult literacy program in Tasmania is being told that the Commonwealth has cut funds to adult literacy. This is simply not true. It is a furphy and a reflection on the political operations of the Tasmanian state government. Allocations to specific parts of vocational education and training have changed. Some $535,000 was formerly allocated to workplace programs and general community literacy. They appeared to share administration and capital costs. Since the funding situation has changed, the state is saying that it has to put on specific labour market programs that are larger and require additional funds to run. It believes it has to spend more money to cover these costs.

The tendering process requires it to be more open and transparent in what it is doing. The trouble is that this has caused the community literacy program to suffer. People were told that they had lost funding, and that is not so. Funds have been reallocated to cover the costs of those expanded labour market programs. However, these funds are now being built up again.

Literacy is vital for people of any age to participate in today's world. In these times, without basic reading, writing and arithmetic skills, we are denied access to computers, televisions and all the electronic gadgetry that we have, with more to come in the future. Many people in our community have been passed by in the learning of these skills and realise that they need some help. Many adults who are not in a working situation, who are self-employed or who work on the land or in isolated situations have not been picked up by, or do not have access to, any training programs.

This is where the voluntary adult literacy program comes in. It is a one to one program where people in the community take on one student and take him or her through to a stage where he or she can join a class or take on workplace training. The program requires only a few full-time staff to coordinate the overall volunteer system around the state, but its usefulness is enormous and we need to recognise that. Some of us do, but it looks like the state government in Tasmania does not.

I want to quote to you from some letters received from students who were being assisted under the program. I have kept most of those letters that I have received but there are two that I would like to read into the record. The first states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am getting help from ALBE—
the local adult literacy program—

I have heard from my tuter that the money may be stopped. I think that a lot of people will be disivatiged and my self. I have started to learn to read and write. That is some think that I have not been able to do. Until I heard about the ALBE program.
I am a voleenter fire fighter—
so this chap is a really community minded individual—
and I need to read and write to fill out reports about the fires that I atend. And I need to read and write to atend the training senter at Cambridge.
I hope that the ALBE program can continue for my needs and other peoples.
The second says:

I wood like to keap doing liters program. It will help me to get work in the future at some time. I have truble filing out forms. I dont have much cofdens in my self. I would like to help my son with his hom work. But he hast to help me and I think if I was to lean to read and rite beater I wood give me a lot of cofdens in my self.

The Tasmanian government puts $250,000 to $300,000 to cover the administration, wages, buildings and equipment in the area but, to cover the changes it has had to make, it is pretending it is not receiving the additional money and saying that the Commonwealth has cut back on the funds. That is not true. The figures speak for themselves. The money is there according to the need and the government can seek allocation through the tendering process if it feels that one area is particularly missing out.

PARA.TAB: This program is one through which many people have been able to change the course of their lives. I know, because I am one of those people. Adult literacy programs delivered by any form is very important. The volunteer programs in particular have played a very big part in the state of Tasmania. I would urge all levels of government to recognise this and to make sure that this program does not suffer in the changes and restructuring that have taken place to maximise the use of the funds. Sometimes these smaller but vital programs can suffer in all those changes. I am very happy to support these bills as they make my argument much simpler.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: What is the total number of goods which are subject to wholesale sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: It is not possible to answer the honourable member's question.

The wholesale sales tax (WST) does not operate by exhaustively listing the goods to which it applies. Rather, the WST legislation operates on the basis that all goods sold under assessable transactions are subject to WST at the standard rate (currently 21 per cent), unless there is a specific exemption or unless the goods are specifically assigned to a rate class other than 21 per cent. Thus while there are schedules of the broad types of goods that are exempt or taxed at other than 21 per cent, there is no comprehensive list of all the goods subject to WST. The majority of revenue raised by the WST in fact arises from goods taxed at the 21 per cent rate, and there is no schedule of even the broad types of goods taxed at that rate.

The Australian Taxation Office collects statistics on the revenue raised by the WST, but those statistics are compiled on the basis of the broad industry class of the taxpayer, not the particular goods on which the tax has been collected. Any particular taxpayer (such as a grocery wholesaler) may of course pay WST at several rates on hundreds or even thousands of goods.

It would not be feasible to compile a listing of all goods subject to WST. Apart from the large costs of any attempt, such a listing would serve no useful policy or analytical purpose and would quickly be out of date, due to the introduction of new products and discontinuation of old products.
